abstract: To commemorate a banner year for deals, we raised a glass to some of the notable names of 2006 in DealBook’s annual “closing dinner” column. We toasted the likes of Lloyd Blankfein, who ascended to the role of chief executive at investment banking giant Goldman Sachs, and Stephen Schwarzman, whose Blackstone Group raised record sums of money for its buyout fund. We also lobbed zingers at some of the players who failed to wow Wall Street in the past year. To them, we say better luck in 2007.

abstract: Is one of France’s biggest corporate raiders looking to break up a government-engineered energy merger? According to The New York Times, François Pinault, the billionaire investor who owns the luxury fashion house Gucci, is exploring a bid for the French utility Suez that could be as high as 70 billion euros ($92 billion). In an e-mailed statement Tuesday, Mr. Pinault’s holding company, Artemis, said that “all options remain open” for a possible bid, sending shares of the world’s second-largest water company to a record.

abstract: China, which is aggressively seeking overseas energy assets to run its booming economy, said Sunday that one of its biggest conglomerates had bought the Kazakhstan oil assets of a Canadian company for $1.91 billion. The CITIC Group of China bought the oil assets of the Nations Energy Company of Canada and granted KazMunaiGas, Kazakhstan’s state-owned oil company, an option to a 50 percent interest in Nations Energy, the official Xinhua Agency said.

abstract: The Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, which had a record initial public offering in October, said Monday that it had agreed to acquire Bank Halim of Indonesia in its first such overseas purchase. Industrial & Commercial, which did not disclose the deal price, said it would buy 90 percent of Bank Halim and take an option to buy the rest from shareholders in three years.

abstract: Will 2007 be the year that the tech I.P.O. makes its comeback? A steadying of interest rates and inflation, a recent rally in the tech-heavy Nasdaq, and exceptional performance of tech offerings since the summer of 2006 have given observers hope of a significant rise in initial public offerings of technology start-ups this year, BusinessWeek writes. Already, 2006 saw a 31 percent rise in I.P.O. filings, with 67 tech companies filing to go public.

abstract: The London Stock Exchange is planning to tighten regulations in a move that would make it easier to take disciplinary action against brokers that bring unsuccessful companies to the Alternative Investment Market. The change is part of a bid to toughen rules governing the nominated advisers, or nomads, that oversee companies coming to the alternative market, which is administered by the London exchange.

abstract: They are known as “hedge fund hotels”: Offices that investment banks lease out to upstart hedge-fund traders, usually in hopes that the traders-in-residence will become big clients. As The New York Times’s Jenny Anderson reports, they often come with luxurious amenities, such as receptionists, espresso machines and consultants to help manage their information systems. But, Ms. Anderson wrties, they are also raising questions. William F. Galvin, the Massachusetts secretary of state, has subpoenaed UBS, the leader in this business, and is examining other banks with hedge fund hotels in Boston to determine how they are charging for their services.

abstract: How far will uptsarts go to try and topple popular web starts like YouTube and MySpace? Quite a bit further, it seems. Increasingly, new Web sites like Stickam.com, Dailymotion, and LiveLeak are building their businesses by going where others fear to tread: into the realm of unmonitored downloading, depictions of nudity and violence and unfiltered live broadcasts from Web cameras, writes The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: How far will uptsarts go to try and topple popular web starts like YouTube and MySpace? Quite a bit further, it seems. Increasingly, new Web sites like Stickam.com, Dailymotion, and LiveLeak are building their businesses by going where others fear to tread: into the realm of unmonitored downloading, depictions of nudity and violence and unfiltered live broadcasts from Web cameras, writes The New York Times.

headline.main: Using Web Cams but Few Inhibitions, the Young Turn to Risky Social Sites

abstract: One of Europe’s largest private equity houses plans to carry out hostile bids on public companies. The fund, CVC Capital Partners, has changed the terms of agreement with its investors so that it can attempt to take over businesses without the support of management, The Telegraph reported. The move will no doubt be unwelcome for directors of many publicly quoted companies who had previously thought they could resist a private equity bid, so long as they declined to play ball.

abstract: After helping to drive a record year for mergers and buyouts, will deal makers take a breather in 2007? Don’t count on it, several market watchers are saying this week. Among these M&A bulls is talk-show host and former hedge-fund manager James Cramer, who writes in the latest issue of New York magazine that “2007 will be even bigger than 2006″ in terms of deals. He also ticks off a series of well-known companies that he thinks are logical targets.

abstract: There has been a lot of talk about Wall Street’s many winners in 2006. It was a record year for worldwide merger activity and for profits at the bulge-bracket investment banks. Goldman Sachs‘s chief executive, Lloyd Blankfein, received the largest annual bonus ever awarded to a Wall Street chief. But there is at least one person on Wall Street who was probably very glad to ring out the old year: Bill Miller, the legendary mutual-fund manager from Legg Mason.

abstract: Nucor, the second-largest steel producer in the United States, agreed to acquire the Harris Steel Group of Canada for about $1.07 billion as the steel industry continues to see record consolidation. Nucor agreed to pay 46.25 Canadian dollars ($39.76) for each Harris Steel share, or 6.3 percent above the closing price Dec. 29.

abstract: Private equity firm Lone Star Funds has lined up a new buyer for Shoney’s, after a previous deal to sell the restaurant chain reportedly fell through. A unit of Royal Capital said Tuesday it would acquire the chain, known across the South for its buffets, for an undisclosed price. In July, Lone Star announced that it would sell Shoney’s, which it took private in 2002, to an affiliate of a Chicago real estate developer, Centrum Properties. But the Nashville Post reported in September that the deal collapsed, prompting a lawsuit.

abstract: Management of Hard Rock International, the chain of music-themed restaurants, hotels and casinos, rigged the $965 million sale of the company to favor the Seminole Tribe of Florida, a would-be bidder alleged in court filings Friday. The suit was filed by Cordish, a real-estate developer that worked with the Seminoles in developing its Hard Rock properties, accusing the franchise and its chief executive, Hamish Dodds, of collaborating with the tribe on the sale to insure that management was kept in place.

abstract: In a long profile of the NYSE Group‘s chief executive, John Thain, New York magazine says Mr. Thain’s modus operandi has “always been to give the coming technocracy a human face.” It can be a tricky strategy to pull off, however. The essential functions of Wall Street, like trading on the New York Stock Exchange, are increasingly being handled by machines, threatening to uproot many of the Street’s long-standing traditions, the article notes.

abstract: Democrats take control of Congress this week, and many in the financial services industry are wondering what legal or regulatory changes are in store. On Tuesday, the Associated Press suggested that Mr. Dodd’s potential presidential ambitions may temper any zeal to slap additional regulations on Wall Street.

abstract: It was a hardly a bad year for the NYSE Group, whose shares have roughly doubled since June. But 2006 did bring one unhappy milestone for the NYSE, which operates the New York Stock Exchange. Thomson Financial notes that for the first time ever, the NYSE’s New York Stock Exchange was bested in the global market for initial public offerings. Both the London Stock Exchange and the Hong Kong Stock Exchange were bigger venues for public floats in 2006, as measured by the volume of proceeds raised, the research firm said.

abstract: Last year “will be remembered for introducing the phrase ‘stock options backdating’ to the general public,” law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen and Katz declared in a recent letter to clients. But it added that the year’s more-important legal catch phrase may be the “McNulty Memo,” which did not get quite as much attention in the media. Wachtell Lipton suggests that the memo was part of a “significant retreat” by the Justice Department, which was reacting to “the beginning of a true push-back against what have come to be perceived as overly aggressive government enforcement policies and practices.”

abstract: Michael Cera, who played George Michael, the would-be scion of the Bluth family, on the late, lamented TV show “Arrested Development,” has found new work: He is starring in an online video that parodies the egomaniacal video resume of Alexey Vayner. Mr. Vayner, a Yale student, sent his video, called “Impossible Is Nothing,” to investment banks in hopes of securing a job. But it was leaked to YouTube and beyond last summer, prompting a flood of ridicule and many comments on DealBook.

abstract: The top trade negotiators for the United States and Brazil will meet in New York to discuss global trade talks that collapsed last year, Brazil’s Foreign Ministry said. The foreign minister, Celso Amorim, and the United States trade representative, Susan C. Schwab, will talk today about how to reopen the negotiations and overcome obstacles that have prevented a World Trade Organization deal aimed at strengthening the global economy. A round of talks began in 2001 in Doha, Qatar, but they collapsed last year over disagreements on farm subsidies and tariffs.

abstract: Singapore’s economic growth unexpectedly accelerated in the fourth quarter to the fastest pace in a year as a record number of tourists and an all-time high stock market spurred service industries and helped offset lower electronics exports. Its economy grew an annualized 7.6 percent in the final three months of 2006, after expanding a revised 5.6 percent in the third quarter, the trade ministry said. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said in his New Year’s message that the pace of expansion may ease in 2007 because of an economic slowdown in the United States and weaker global demand for electronics, which account for about half the $118 billion economy’s exports. The economy may expand between 4 percent and 6 percent this year, Mr. Lee said.

abstract: William F. Galvin, Massachusetts’ secretary of state, said yesterday that his investigation of UBS‘s relationship with certain hedge funds, reported in Tuesday’s New York Times, stems from broader concerns about the practices of a lightly regulated corner of the financial services industry, The Boston Globe reported. He said UBS officials have agreed to provide testimony about the firm’s relationship with hedge fund traders who operate out of UBS’s Boston office.

Galvin, Massachusetts’ secretary of state, said yesterday that his investigation of UBS‘s relationship with certain hedge funds, reported in Tuesday’s New York Times, stems from broader concerns about the practices of a lightly regulated corner of the financial services industry, The Boston Globe reported. He said UBS officials have agreed to provide testimony about the firm’s relationship with hedge fund traders who operate out of UBS’s Boston office.

headline.main: Galvin Sees Broader Hedge-Fund Concerns

abstract: The German mobile phone unit that the Taiwan company BenQ bought from Siemens will shut down, after no investor stepped in to rescue it. Once among the top phone brands, the phone maker first stumbled under Siemens and then collapsed under BenQ because both owners failed to compete on a global scale with rivals like Nokia.
lead_paragraph: The German mobile phone unit that the Taiwan company BenQ bought from Siemens will shut down, after no investor stepped in to rescue it. Once among the top phone brands, the phone maker first stumbled under Siemens and then collapsed under BenQ because both owners failed to compete on a global scale with rivals like Nokia.

headline.main: BenQ to Liquidate German Unit As White Knight Fails to Emerge

abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

abstract: Stock markets worldwide rallied on the first trading day of 2007 on speculation that profit growth and takeovers would support global equities for a fifth year. Share indexes in all 16 West European markets gained, while benchmarks in Australia, Hong Kong and Indonesia climbed to records. In Latin America, equity gauges in Brazil, Argentina and Mexico headed toward all-time highs.
lead_paragraph: Stock markets worldwide rallied on the first trading day of 2007 on speculation that profit growth and takeovers would support global equities for a fifth year. Share indexes in all 16 West European markets gained, while benchmarks in Australia, Hong Kong and Indonesia climbed to records. In Latin America, equity gauges in Brazil, Argentina and Mexico headed toward all-time highs.

headline.main: Global Rally on First Day of Trading in New Year

abstract: The Eastern European division of Unicredit of Italy agreed Tuesday to buy a 20 percent stake in a Russian lender, the International Moscow Bank.
lead_paragraph: The Eastern European division of Unicredit of Italy agreed Tuesday to buy a 20 percent stake in a Russian lender, the International Moscow Bank.

headline.main: Unicredit Buys Stake in Moscow Bank

abstract: CheckFree, an Atlanta-based provider of electronic bill payment and electronic banking services, said Tuesday it had agreed to acquire Carreker for $8.05 a share, or a total of $206 million. CheckFree said the deal for Carreker, a Dallas-based provider of payments technology and consulting services for the financial services industry, will help it expand in software and consulting.

CheckFree said the deal for Carreker, a Dallas-based provider of payments technology and consulting services for the financial services industry, will help it expand in software and consulting.

abstract: While times may be good for venture capitalists and the start-ups they fund, things are not looking so hot for firms like Sherwood Partners, long known in the industry as “the undertaker.” Firms like Sherwood are in the business of shutting down failed start-ups, and The San Jose Mercury News reports that Sherwood wound down 180 start-ups in its heyday during the dot-com bust.

abstract: Now that Eliot Spitzer, whom some called the Sheriff of Wall Street, has moved into the New York governor’s mansion, financial-industry observers are turning their eyes to his successor as New York attorney general, the freshly sworn-in Andrew Cuomo.

abstract: The number of venture-backed initial public offerings awaiting their stock market debut more than doubled at the start of 2007 with a tech filing from Omneon Video Networks marking a late-entry addition to the roster. Hailing largely from the tech sector, the ranks of venture-backed I.P.O.’s swelled to 36 as of Tuesday, up from 16 in the same period last year, according to a survey by the National Venture Capital Association and Thomson Financial. The numbers, however, are down from the start of the busy fourth quarter of 2006, when 51 were waiting to take a crack at the public markets.

abstract: Refco, the commodities broker that filed for bankruptcy protection in 2005, has exited Chapter 11 and is starting to make initial payouts to creditors. The firm formally emerged on Dec. 26 under a liquidation plan, although its estate still faces disputed claims and expected lawsuits from creditors, The Deal reported.

abstract: EGL, a manager of freight services for customers, said yesterday that its chief executive, James R. Crane, and a private equity firm had offered to buy the company for $1.2 billion. Mr. Crane, EGL’s founder and largest shareholder with an 18 percent stake, and the equity firm General Atlantic want to pay $36 a share for the rest of the stock, EGL said yesterday.
lead_paragraph: EGL, a manager of freight services for customers, said yesterday that its chief executive, James R. Crane, and a private equity firm had offered to buy the company for $1.2 billion. Mr. Crane, EGL’s founder and largest shareholder with an 18 percent stake, and the equity firm General Atlantic want to pay $36 a share for the rest of the stock, EGL said yesterday.

headline.main: EGL Gets Buyout Bid From Its Chief

abstract: The Philadelphia Inquirer is expected to announce Wednesday that it will lay off 68 to 71 employees, or about 17 percent of the newsroom staff, just seven months after a group of local businessmen took over the newspaper and its sister publication, The Daily News. The Philadelphia papers were sold in March by Knight Ridder to the McClatchy newspaper group, which in turn sold them to a group of businessmen, led by Brian P. Tierney, an advertising and public relations executive.

Tierney, an advertising and public relations executive.

headline.main: Layoffs Imminent at Philadelphia Inquirer

abstract: After beating out the New York Stock Exchange in initial public offerings this year to take the I.P.O. crown, Hong Kong’s stock market might see itself outdone by its mainland competitor. Shanghai’s bourse is expected to attract $26 billion in fundraising this year, overtaking Hong Kong, as more of the nation’s largest companies sell shares domestically, according to a report from PricewaterhouseCoopers. Hong Kong, by contrast, is expected to receive 150 billion Hong Kong dollars ($19.3 billion) in I.P.O.’s in 2007.
lead_paragraph: After beating out the New York Stock Exchange in initial public offerings this year to take the I.P.O. crown, Hong Kong’s stock market might see itself outdone by its mainland competitor. headline.main: Shanghai May Overtake Hong Kong in I.P.O.’s This Year

abstract: Making a further move into the market for cardiovascular drugs, the biotechnology giant Amgen has formed an alliance with Cytokinetics, a smaller company developing an experimental drug to treat heart failure. Under the agreement, which is expected to be announced Wednesday, Amgen will pay Cytokinetics $75 million to gain an option on the drug, which is about to enter the second of three stages of clinical trials.
lead_paragraph: Making a further move into the market for cardiovascular drugs, the biotechnology giant Amgen has formed an alliance with Cytokinetics, a smaller company developing an experimental drug to treat heart failure. Under the agreement, which is expected to be announced Wednesday, Amgen will pay Cytokinetics $75 million to gain an option on the drug, which is about to enter the second of three stages of clinical trials.

headline.main: Amgen Acquires Option for a Heart Failure Drug

abstract: Venture capitalists are expected to pump even more money into energy ventures in 2007 after doubling their bets last year amid shifting politics and global-warming worries. Venture capital investment in energy start-ups exploded in the first three quarters of 2006, hitting $536 million, compared with $224 million in all of 2005, according to industry tracker Dow Jones VentureOne. Now, V.C.’s are returning to the sector, following a “sea change” of interest in alternatives to conventional energy sources, John Denniston, a partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, told USA Today.

Now, V.C.’s are returning to the sector, following a “sea change” of interest in alternatives to conventional energy sources, John Denniston, a partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, told USA Today.

headline.main: Energy Investments Likely to Burn Even Hotter This Year

The sale allowed ICV and Palladium to pocket 2.5 times their original money and yielded an internal rate of return of more than 30 percent.

abstract: The specialty retailer Sharper Image chopped more than $3 million from the severance pay of its founder and recently departed chief executive, Richard Thalheimer, to offset his past windfalls from favorably priced stock options. The package, disclosed in a regulatory filing late last week, includes retirement benefits of $3.9 million and a severance payment of $1.78 million, below the $5 million minimum guaranteed to Mr. Thalheimer under a contract signed in 2002.

abstract: The South Korean antitrust agency has formed a task force to investigate the licensing and business practices of the wireless technology company Qualcomm, the latest in a string of legal battles for the company, officials said on Tuesday. In Japan, Europe and the United States, Qualcomm, which is based in San Diego, faces accusations by rivals that it has abused its market dominance in wireless technology to demand excessive royalties and block fair competition.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean antitrust agency has formed a task force to investigate the licensing and business practices of the wireless technology company Qualcomm, the latest in a string of legal battles for the company, officials said on Tuesday. In Japan, Europe and the United States, Qualcomm, which is based in San Diego, faces accusations by rivals that it has abused its market dominance in wireless technology to demand excessive royalties and block fair competition.

headline.main: Qualcomm Under Scrutiny by Korean Antitrust Agency

abstract: Class action lawsuits filed over securities fraud reached an all-time low in 2006, according to a Stanford Law School report. The drop is linked to tougher federal enforcement on securities fraud, a stronger stock market with lower price volatility and the settlements of the slew of securities fraud lawsuits filed in the late 1990s and early 2000s, the report said.
lead_paragraph: Class action lawsuits filed over securities fraud reached an all-time low in 2006, according to a Stanford Law School report. The drop is linked to tougher federal enforcement on securities fraud, a stronger stock market with lower price volatility and the settlements of the slew of securities fraud lawsuits filed in the late 1990s and early 2000s, the report said.

headline.main: Class Action Suits Hit All-Time Low in 2006

abstract: Richard A. Causey, Enron‘s former chief accounting officer, was on his way Tuesday to a federal prison in Bastrop, Tex., to begin a 5 1/2-year sentence for his role in the fraud that destroyed the company. Mr. Causey, 46, pleaded guilty to one count of securities fraud in December 2005, less than a month before he was to stand trial with former chief executives Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, both of whom were found guilty.

abstract: Home Depot, the giant home-improvement chain, said Wednesday that Robert L. Nardelli resigned as its chairman and chief executive. abstract: Two of the three names behind private equity behemoth Kohlberg Kravis Roberts weighed in on the state of the buyout industry in an interview with the Wall Street Journal. Henry Kravis and George Roberts told the newspaper that much has changed since the firm’s first leveraged buyout in 1979 (price: $355 million). These days, banks are eager to lend billions of dollars to help take companies private, although Mr. Roberts suggests that debt is used more judiciously than it was in the go-go 1980’s. He said:

abstract: Despite recommendations that federal regulations over corporate governance be lightened, American chief executives expect further challenges this year to their control over the companies they run, according to The Financial Times. Developments like stock-options backdating, anger over executive compensation and increased shareholder activism have contributed to a more hostile environment for chief executives, who have been departing in greater numbers.
lead_paragraph: Despite recommendations that federal regulations over corporate governance be lightened, American chief executives expect further challenges this year to their control over the companies they run, according to The Financial Times. Developments like stock-options backdating, anger over executive compensation and increased shareholder activism have contributed to a more hostile environment for chief executives, who have been departing in greater numbers.

headline.main: Should U.S. C.E.O.’s Prepare for a Tougher 2007?

abstract: Lloyd Blankfein appears to have little in common with Marie Antoinette, but readers of Michael M. Thomas’s fiery opinion column in this week’s New York Observer can be forgiven for thinking otherwise. Mr. Thomas, a former investment banker and observer of Wall Street manners, has produced an incendiary diatribe that focuses on the year-end bonuses recently doled out at Goldman Sachs, where Mr. Blankfein is chief executive. Using revolutionary imagery, Mr. Thomas suggests that Goldman’s bonuses could become a touchstone for a national (and possibly irrational) debate on the wealth gap.

abstract: After giving us a preview late last year, Thomson Financial this week sent DealBook its official tally of last year’s merger and acquisitions activity. Global M&A topped $3.8 trillion in 2006, a bump of nearly 38 percent over the previous year. Nearly 20 percent of the year’s deals involved private-equity buyers. And large swaths of the deal-making were handled by two investment banks, Goldman Sachs and Citigroup.
lead_paragraph: After giving us a preview late last year, Thomson Financial this week sent DealBook its official tally of last year’s merger and acquisitions activity. And large swaths of the deal-making were handled by two investment banks, Goldman Sachs and Citigroup.

headline.main: Goldman, Citi Top List of 2006 M&A Deal Makers

abstract: When you are carrying $210 million in goodies, it is hard to make a quiet exit. This is especially true when you are Robert Nardelli, whose pay as the chief executive of Home Depot has long been a source of controversy. Hours after his resignation was announced early Wednesday, there were some strong reactions to Mr. Nardelli’s severance package, which the company valued at $210 million.

abstract: The Federal Aviation Act prohibits foreign investors from owning more than 25 percent of an American airline. This, writes Daniel Gross at Slate, is an example of “sometimes misplaced hostility to foreigners, national-security paranoia, and plain-old protectionism.” The law may be old, but its relevance is new, as many analysts think the United States airline industry is due a round of transformational mergers.

abstract: The French stock market regulator, Autorité des Marchés Financiers, will set a deadline next week for the billionaire François Pinault to say whether he plans to make an offer for the utility Suez. Failure to meet the deadline would prevent Mr. Pinault’s holding company, Artemis, from bidding for the company for six months, unless there were “significant” changes in Suez’s situation or shareholder structure, the regulatory agency said. Suez, which supplies water and electric power, asked the regulator on Tuesday to set a deadline after reports surfaced that Artemis was considering the acquisition.

lead_paragraph: With the right equipment, future guitar virtuosos and “Stairway to Heaven” fanatics don’t have to be chained to bulky amplifiers in the basement to practice and record their riffs. Hammacher Schlemmer offers the PC Recording Studio Guitar, a six-string electric instrument that comes with a U.S.B. port to connect it directly to a PC or Mac.

headline.main: A Guitar That Plugs Into a Computer via U.S.B.? Oh, It Makes Me Wonder
headline.print_headline: A Guitar That Plugs Into a Computer Via U.S.B.? Oh, It Makes Me Wonder

abstract: Building a poor man’s home media network for less than $1,000.
snippet: Building a poor man’s home media network for less than $1,000.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM D. WATKINS has seven terabytes of data storage tucked into a cabinet in the media room of his beach home in Aptos, Calif. That is not a big thing for Mr. Watkins, the chief executive of Seagate, which makes hard disk drives. But it is enough space to hold 600,000 songs, 584,000 photographs and 1,000 hours of TV shows.

headline.main: Pulling It All Together
headline.print_headline: Putting It All Together

abstract: Brand mascots are everywhere these days, as marketers look for new ways to spread their messages across a variety of media.

headline.main: Who Is That Wearing That Milk Mustache?
headline.print_headline: Who Is That Wearing That Milk Mustache?

abstract: After seeing gas prices pass $3 a gallon last year, a great many folks wish the economy would go on a diet and stop using so much energy.
snippet: After seeing gas prices pass $3 a gallon last year, a great many folks wish the economy would go on a diet and stop using so much energy.
lead_paragraph: Well, another New Year’s Day has come and gone. A string of holiday meals and sitting on the couch have, no doubt, started another wave of resolutions to get some exercise and go on a diet. But after seeing gas prices pass $3 a gallon last year, hearing all the talk about global warming and having a bad feeling about all the bluster coming from the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, a great many folks wish the economy would go on a diet, too, and stop using so much energy.

headline.main: A Country Less Dependent on Oil Is Free to Make Other New Year’s Resolutions
headline.print_headline: A Country Less Dependent on Oil Is Free to Make Other New Year’s Resolutions

It is a concept that seems easy to apply to music, and that’s the idea behind the company’s $30 Kidz Bop to Go players, each featuring 20 songs aimed at children.

abstract: The board decided that Robert L. Nardelli should go — with a $210 million exit package.

lead_paragraph: In May, in a nearly empty basement ballroom at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del., Robert L. Nardelli, the chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, stood between huge timers, intended to limit questions from the handful of shareholders present. After dismissing questions about his compensation or the independence of the board, Mr. Nardelli abruptly ended the meeting after only 30 minutes.

headline.main: Home Depot Ousts Highly Paid Chief

abstract: SABMiller said its China venture would buy a local partner for $320 million to expand in the world’s biggest beer market. China Resources Snow Breweries, 49 percent owned by SABMiller, agreed to buy the shares it does not already own in the Blue Sword Group, which owns 38 percent stakes in 14 breweries in central Sichuan province. The remaining shares are owned by China Resources Snow. In October, SABMiller said that its China Resources Snow venture had become China’s largest brewer by sales volume, beating its domestic rival Tsingtao Brewery.

abstract: Tablet PCs have not gained much traction in the marketplace, but Lenovo’s latest may rev up the genre.
snippet: Tablet PCs have not gained much traction in the marketplace, but Lenovo’s latest may rev up the genre.
lead_paragraph: Tablet PCs have not gained much traction in the marketplace, but Lenovo’s latest may rev up the genre. The X60 ThinkPad Tablet has a 12-inch screen that flips around to fold flat, and it is brighter than usual, with a polarizing filter to cut glare — perhaps for those who would walk in the sun while Web surfing. There is a stylus for writing on the touch screen, and its other end has an electronic eraser for quick deletions.

headline.main: A ThinkPad Tablet Tries to Find Its Place in the Sun
headline.print_headline: A ThinkPad Tablet Tries to Finds Its Place in the Sun

abstract: Nestlé, the food company, agreed to sell a soil-composting unit in the United States to the Garick Corporation for an undisclosed price. Garick, which is based in Cleveland, said it would add the unit, New Milford Farms, to its reusable waste business. New Milford, part of a Nestlé unit in New Milford, Conn., turns processed food byproducts into compost. Terms were not disclosed. Nestlé is based in Vevey, Switzerland.

lead_paragraph: Push-to-talk, another name for walkie-talkie cellphone features, has been popular for years, but until recently it was largely available on Nextel phones. Now you can get push-to-talk from Cingular as well, and the LG CU400 cellphone it recently began offering adds high-speed data services to the mix.

lead_paragraph: Robert L. Nardelli’s rich compensation and poor performance at Home Depot have long been cited by shareholder activists as a prime example of what they view as excessive executive pay. abstract: The Bear Stearns Companies, Greenhill & Company and three other firms have invested $1 billion to create Ironshore Insurance, an insurer that will be based in Bermuda and will specialize in disaster-prone commercial properties along the Southeast and Gulf coasts of the United States. Robert Clements, who helped start various Bermuda-based insurers including ACE and XL Capital, arranged the financing with his son John Clements. “We see a marketplace that is starved for quality capacity,” Robert V. Deutsch, Ironshore’s chief executive, above, said in a telephone interview.

abstract: The proliferation of niche help-wanted Web sites, as well as networking sites like Craigslist and LinkedIn, could lead to consolidation among more general jobs sites like Monster, HotJobs, and CareerBuilder. Niche sites made up 64 percent of the market in 2005, according to BusinessWeek, up from 39 percent in 2004. And visits to the “big three” jobs sites are falling fast, though sales are rising thanks to the strength of the job market.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of niche help-wanted Web sites, as well as networking sites like Craigslist and LinkedIn, could lead to consolidation among more general jobs sites like Monster, HotJobs, and CareerBuilder. And visits to the “big three” jobs sites are falling fast, though sales are rising thanks to the strength of the job market.

headline.main: Online Job Sites: Ripe for Consolidation?

abstract: Adelphia Communications‘s plan to pay creditors and end one of the biggest bankruptcy cases in United States history was approved Wednesday by a judge in New York. Rigas, was arrested and charged with looting the company.

abstract: Hercules Technology Growth Capital, a specialty finance company, said Wednesday it had raised about $11 million when its underwriters exercised their option to buy an additional 840,000 shares of common stock. Hercules, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said the net proceeds will be used to reduce borrowings under its credit facilities, to originate new investments and provide funds for existing investments, and for general corporate purposes.

abstract: Whirlpool said Wednesday that it had sold a number of properties belonging to Maytag, including most of Maytag’s headquarters complex in Newton, Iowa. Whirlpool said it also had sold former Maytag manufacturing sites in Galesburg and Herrin, Ill.; Searcy, Ark.; and Ranson, W.Va. The company did not disclose the terms of the deals.

abstract: A United States research institute has sued three cellphone makers, accusing them of violating a patent for Bluetooth technology. The Washington Research Foundation, which markets technology from universities and other nonprofit research institutions in Washington State, is seeking damages from Nokia, Samsung Electronics and Panasonic, owned by Matsushita, contending that the three companies were using a radio frequency receiver technology patented by a University of Washington scientist in 1999.
lead_paragraph: A United States research institute has sued three cellphone makers, accusing them of violating a patent for Bluetooth technology. headline.main: 3 Cellphone Makers Are Sued Over Bluetooth Technology

abstract: Cisco Systems said Thursday it would buy a Web messaging and e-mail security company, IronPort Systems, for $830 million to tap growing demand for anti-virus and anti-spam software. The deal for IronPort would be Cisco’s biggest since its $6.9 billion purchase of Scientific-Atlanta, announced in 2005.
lead_paragraph: Cisco Systems said Thursday it would buy a Web messaging and e-mail security company, IronPort Systems, for $830 million to tap growing demand for anti-virus and anti-spam software. The deal for IronPort would be Cisco’s biggest since its $6.9 billion purchase of Scientific-Atlanta, announced in 2005.

headline.main: Cisco to Buy Network Security Firm IronPort

abstract: China Everbright Bank, which plans to hold an initial public offering this year, has hired China International Capital and Morgan Stanley to find a foreign investor before the offering, according to Bloomberg News. Everbright Bank, which in 1996 became the first Chinese bank to sell stock to an overseas financial institution, is trying to bolster its capital to comply with government guidelines, Bloomberg said.
lead_paragraph: China Everbright Bank, which plans to hold an initial public offering this year, has hired China International Capital and Morgan Stanley to find a foreign investor before the offering, according to Bloomberg News. Everbright Bank, which in 1996 became the first Chinese bank to sell stock to an overseas financial institution, is trying to bolster its capital to comply with government guidelines, Bloomberg said.

headline.main: Everbright Bank Said to Seek Investor

abstract: Macquarie Bank, Australia’s largest securities firm, plans to shift as many as 100 administrative jobs, including positions from payroll services in Sydney and London, to India, according to Bloomberg News. The bank plans to combine its global human resources functions as part of a “strategic review,” a Macquarie spokesman told Bloomberg. Macquarie joins the Credit Suisse Group and the Australia & New Zealand Banking Group among banks that are hiring in India to take advantage of the nation’s lower labor costs and pool of skilled workers.
lead_paragraph: Macquarie Bank, Australia’s largest securities firm, plans to shift as many as 100 administrative jobs, including positions from payroll services in Sydney and London, to India, according to Bloomberg News. The bank plans to combine its global human resources functions as part of a “strategic review,” a Macquarie spokesman told Bloomberg. Macquarie joins the Credit Suisse Group and the Australia & New Zealand Banking Group among banks that are hiring in India to take advantage of the nation’s lower labor costs and pool of skilled workers.

headline.main: Macquarie to Outsource Jobs to India, Report Says

abstract: A former Morgan Stanley regional director in wealth management sued the company on Wednesday, saying he was fired because of his age. The executive, Edward Sullivan, 56, who had been a managing director, accused human resources executives Jeffrey Brodsky and Eric Kayne of conspiring to end his employment, in part to make room for a friend of Mr. Brodsky’s who lacked an assignment.
lead_paragraph: A former Morgan Stanley regional director in wealth management sued the company on Wednesday, saying he was fired because of his age. headline.main: Morgan Stanley Faces Age-Bias Suit

abstract: Amazon.com‘s founder, Jeff Bezos, wants engineers to join his fledgling and secretive private aerospace business, Blue Origin, breaking a long silence about his operation by posting photos and videos on the company’s Web site of a test launch of a reusable spacecraft. The posting, dated Tuesday, shows a cone-shaped vehicle with four metal legs, launching in a cloud of smoke, reaching an altitude of about 285 feet, according to Blue Origin, then landing on its legs.
lead_paragraph: Amazon.com‘s founder, Jeff Bezos, wants engineers to join his fledgling and secretive private aerospace business, Blue Origin, breaking a long silence about his operation by posting photos and videos on the company’s Web site of a test launch of a reusable spacecraft. headline.main: Bezos Offers Glimpse into Space Venture

abstract: Bank of America is distancing itself from its venture capital arm, BA Venture Partners, to concentrate on its middle-market private equity unit, BA Capital Investors. BA Ventures said Wednesday that it would rename itself Scale Venture Partners as Bank of America repositions itself as a minority investor.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America is distancing itself from its venture capital arm, BA Venture Partners, to concentrate on its middle-market private equity unit, BA Capital Investors. abstract: Bankers enjoying their record bonuses from 2006 have, at least in part, private equity to thank, as the industry is poised to pay $11 billion in fees in an unprecedented year for leveraged buyouts. Taking the crown is Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which will pay out more than $837 million in fees to investment banks in 2006, more than any other private equity firm.
lead_paragraph: Bankers enjoying their record bonuses from 2006 have, at least in part, private equity to thank, as the industry is poised to pay $11 billion in fees in an unprecedented year for leveraged buyouts. headline.main: Private Equity Boom Racks Up Bankers’ Fees

abstract: The French financial markets regulator said Wednesday that it would decide Tuesday on a target date by which François Pinault, the billionaire investor who owns the fashion house Gucci, must make a bid for Suez or else abstain from bidding for six months. A bid could derail a government-orchestrated plan for an 80 billion euro ($106.2 billion) merger between Suez, a water and energy group, and the state-controlled Gaz de France.
lead_paragraph: The French financial markets regulator said Wednesday that it would decide Tuesday on a target date by which François Pinault, the billionaire investor who owns the fashion house Gucci, must make a bid for Suez or else abstain from bidding for six months. headline.main: Pinault Faces Deadline for 70 Billion Euro Suez Bid

abstract: AGL Energy, Australia’s biggest power and gas retailer, has made an initial approach to its biggest rival, Origin Energy, about a merger valued at 13 billion Australian dollars ($10 billion) to create the country’s biggest gas and electricity supplier.
lead_paragraph: AGL Energy, Australia’s biggest power and gas retailer, has made an initial approach to its biggest rival, Origin Energy, about a merger valued at 13 billion Australian dollars ($10 billion) to create the country’s biggest gas and electricity supplier.

abstract: As a big battle over global warming is unfolding in Texas, Fortune takes a look at how green Wall Street’s investment banks really are. At the heart of the controversy is a Dallas-based energy company that wants to build 11 coal-fired plants, which would emit about 78 million tons of carbon dioxide into the air. In an effort to stop the plants, environmentalists, along with a coalition of institutional investors, have turned their attention to Merrill Lynch, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley, the three lead arrangers of TXU‘s financing.

headline.main: Wall Street’s Not-So-Green Deal

abstract: Radio One, an urban-music radio broadcaster, has purchased the struggling magazine Giant for a song. The broadcaster, which owns 70 radio stations in 22 urban markets, paid $275,000 for the magazine, which was founded by Jamie Hooper, a one-time publisher of Stuff.

abstract: As shareholders, industry watchers and lawmakers continued to express outrage over the $210 million golden farewell that Home Depot awarded its ousted chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, The New York Times takes a look at where it all began: General Electric, which has become a kind of high-end boutique where company directors go when they are looking for the cream of the crop in chief executives.
lead_paragraph: As shareholders, industry watchers and lawmakers continued to express outrage over the $210 million golden farewell that Home Depot awarded its ousted chief executive, Robert L. abstract: GB Holdings, which is liquidating its assets, will seek approval of a plan anchored by Carl Icahn’s $53 million offer to buy the debtor’s stake in Atlantic City’s Sands Hotel & Casino. Chief Judge Judith Wizmur in United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Jersey in Camden set Jan. 30 for a confirmation hearing on GB’s eighth modified disclosure statement, records show. The plan requires Mr. Icahn to pay $53 million for GB’s remaining 28.2 percent interest in Atlantic Coast Entertainment Holdings, one of his affiliates.
lead_paragraph: GB Holdings, which is liquidating its assets, will seek approval of a plan anchored by Carl Icahn’s $53 million offer to buy the debtor’s stake in Atlantic City’s Sands Hotel & Casino. Chief Judge Judith Wizmur in United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Jersey in Camden set Jan. 30 for a confirmation hearing on GB’s eighth modified disclosure statement, records show. The plan requires Mr. Icahn to pay $53 million for GB’s remaining 28.2 percent interest in Atlantic Coast Entertainment Holdings, one of his affiliates.

headline.main: Icahn May Take Sands Stake from Troubled GB Holdings

abstract: Avista Capital Partners, fresh off last week’s purchase of the Minneapolis Star Tribune, agreed Wednesday to acquire a self-directed investment advisory firm, Phillips Investment Resources, for an amount The Deal.com put between $140 million and $160 million. Phillips, a well-known provider of independent advice, offers 23 different subscription-based services for delivery in digital forms as well as print newsletters.
lead_paragraph: Avista Capital Partners, fresh off last week’s purchase of the Minneapolis Star Tribune, agreed Wednesday to acquire a self-directed investment advisory firm, Phillips Investment Resources, for an amount The Deal.com put between $140 million and $160 million. abstract: A consortium led by the hedge fund Polygon Investment Partners said Thursday that it had dropped plans to make a bid for the British soccer club Newcastle United, which is valued at 91 million pounds ($177 million). Last month, the team confirmed that it was in talks with the consortium, St. James’ Park Group, about a possible bid, and rumors swirled that Polygon had approached the club’s former chairman, Sir John Hall, about buying his 28.8 percent stake. The Times of London said that the Belgravia Group, a British investment company, confirmed that it is still in talks with Newcastle about a possible bid.
lead_paragraph: A consortium led by the hedge fund Polygon Investment Partners said Thursday that it had dropped plans to make a bid for the British soccer club Newcastle United, which is valued at 91 million pounds ($177 million). abstract: Insurance broker Marsh & McLennan has been slimming down its business mix, and at least one analyst thinks that rival Aon will make a similar move. Credit Suisse analyst Charles Gates said Thursday that he expects Aon to sell its Combined Insurance unit as it “transitions completely away from retaining and underwriting risk.” In his research note, Mr. Gates estimates the unit, which sells accident, health and life insurance, could fetch $2.4 billion.

abstract: Spam pales in quantity compared to the number of e-mails you receive when you’re on the press list for the Consumer Electronics Show.
snippet: Spam pales in quantity compared to the number of e-mails you receive when you’re on the press list for the Consumer Electronics Show.
lead_paragraph: Spam pales in quantity compared to the number of e-mails you receive when you’re on the CES press list. Not only is the Consumer Electronics Show the biggest convention in the U.S., but it must also generate the largest number of electronic messages for any event. For six weeks prior to the show, anyone who’s registered begins to receive hundreds of e-mails from P.R. agents, practically begging you to check out their latest products. Unfortunately, many of the agencies don’t seem to do their homework because like spam, most of these messages don’t seem to have any particular target audience in mind.

headline.main: The Product E-Mails Pile Up

abstract: Here is a twist on the “biggest fund ever” stories that have become routine in the booming private-equity industry. abstract: Analysts are saying that the theme of this year’s Consumer Electronics Show will be home networking. But this time, they seem to really mean it.

lead_paragraph: Last year, when you asked industry analysts and marketing executives what the theme of the Consumer Electronics show was going to be they said, “home networking.” Yes, 2006 was the year we’d connect all our TVs in our homes to all our PCs and move movies and videos around between them.

headline.main: What’s the Theme?

abstract: In a move to expand beyond the search business in the world’s second-largest Internet market, Google has made an investment in Xunlei NetworkTechnology, a Chinese Internet video firm, the company said. A Google spokesman said that the investment in Xunlei would be announced today in Beijing, but he declined to give details. According to wire services, the China Daily reported that Google will team up with Ceyuan Ventures, a venture capital firm in Shangai, to buy a stake in Xunlei, which is in Shenzhen. According to the reports, Xunlei’s Web site attracts more than 50 million visitors a day and more than 80 million users have downloaded its software. The Xunlei deal would be Google’s second in as many days in China. Google is also teaming with China Mobile, that country’s largest mobile telecommunications carrier, to deliver search services to cellphones.

abstract: In a possible setback for the billionaire investor François Pinault’s takeover plan for the utility Suez, President Jacques Chirac and Albert Frère, Suez’s biggest investor, said they supported a merger with Gaz de France. “For me, G.D.F. and Suez is still the best thing,” Mr. Frère said in an interview after a New Year’s address to business leaders by Mr. Chirac in Paris. “It’s clear.” Suez is coveted as European utilities prepare for a full opening of power markets to competition later this year. ”We need a major actor in gas, that’s why the combination of Gaz de France and Suez is strategic for France and Europe,” Mr. Chirac said in his speech. Mr. Pinault signaled on Tuesday that he might consider a bid for Suez. France’s stock market regulator said it will set on Tuesday a deadline by which Mr. Pinault will have to declare plans to bid or be prohibited from making a takeover offer for six months.
snippet: In a possible setback for the billionaire investor François Pinault’s takeover plan for the utility Suez, President Jacques Chirac and Albert Frère, Suez’s biggest investor, said they supported a merger with Gaz de France. “For me, G.D.F. and Suez...
lead_paragraph: In a possible setback for the billionaire investor François Pinault’s takeover plan for the utility Suez, President Jacques Chirac and Albert Frère, Suez’s biggest investor, said they supported a merger with Gaz de France. “For me, G.D.F. and Suez is still the best thing,” Mr. Frère said in an interview after a New Year’s address to business leaders by Mr. Chirac in Paris. “It’s clear.” Suez is coveted as European utilities prepare for a full opening of power markets to competition later this year. ”We need a major actor in gas, that’s why the combination of Gaz de France and Suez is strategic for France and Europe,” Mr. Chirac said in his speech. Mr. Pinault signaled on Tuesday that he might consider a bid for Suez. France’s stock market regulator said it will set on Tuesday a deadline by which Mr. Pinault will have to declare plans to bid or be prohibited from making a takeover offer for six months.

headline.main: France: Setback for Pinault’s Suez Bid

abstract: The Marvell Technology Group said yesterday that it had found incorrect dating of some stock-option grants and that top executives had agreed to pay back extra money they received as a result. The company, which makes microchips for hard-disk drives, wireless networks and DVD drives, said an internal review of its stock-option accounting practices had found that the actual dates of some grants differed from the recorded dates.

abstract: Book publishers braced themselves for a financial blow this week after a bankruptcy filing by Advanced Marketing Services, a book distributor. The company filed for bankruptcy protection last Friday, reporting more than $200 million in debt to dozens of publishing companies. Its creditors included publishers large and small, among them Random House, which is owed $43.3 million, and Good Books of Intercourse, Pa.., which specializes in books about the Amish and the Mennonites and is owed nearly $1 million.

abstract: The QBE Insurance Group, Australia’s largest property and casualty insurer, has agreed to buy the United States arm of Winterthur for $1.16 billion, its biggest purchase ever and its second American acquisition in three weeks. The deal will add $1.45 billion in annual sales to QBE, which is based in Sydney, the company said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The QBE Insurance Group, Australia’s largest property and casualty insurer, has agreed to buy the United States arm of Winterthur for $1.16 billion, its biggest purchase ever and its second American acquisition in three weeks. The deal will add $1.45 billion in annual sales to QBE, which is based in Sydney, the company said Thursday.

headline.main: Australian Insurer Buys 2nd U.S. Firm

abstract: Northwest Airlines said Thursday that it had reached an agreement to buy the regional feeder airline Mesaba, although it was not clear that Mesaba’s parent company would accept it. Both airlines are in bankruptcy protection.
lead_paragraph: Northwest Airlines said Thursday that it had reached an agreement to buy the regional feeder airline Mesaba, although it was not clear that Mesaba’s parent company would accept it. Both airlines are in bankruptcy protection.

headline.main: Northwest Reaches Deal to Buy Feeder Airline

abstract: In 2006, a heady cocktail of rapidly growing emerging markets, floods of private equity and hedge fund money, buoyant chief executive confidence and a hungry debt market created an environment so fertile that mergers surpassed all records.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, a heady cocktail of rapidly growing emerging markets, floods of private equity and hedge fund money, buoyant chief executive confidence and a hungry debt market created an environment so fertile that mergers surpassed all records.

headline.main: Can the Deal Boom Continue in 2007?

abstract: Pesident Jacques Chirac of France threw his weight behind the planned merger of the utilities Suez and Gaz de France on Thursday amid doubts over the future of the government-backed tie-up, issuing a veiled warning to those who might interfere with the deal.
lead_paragraph: Pesident Jacques Chirac of France threw his weight behind the planned merger of the utilities Suez and Gaz de France on Thursday amid doubts over the future of the government-backed tie-up, issuing a veiled warning to those who might interfere with the deal.

headline.main: Chirac Issues Veiled Warning Over Suez Bid

abstract: Italy’s constitutional court has upheld the legitimacy of attempts by Parmalat to seek funds from banks that lent it money before the dairy company’s 2003 bankruptcy. The Dec. 28 court ruling affects several banks including Intesa Sanpaolo, Banco Popolare di Verona & Novara, Credit Suisse, Unipol Banca and Banca Popolare dell’Etruria & del Lazio.
lead_paragraph: Italy’s constitutional court has upheld the legitimacy of attempts by Parmalat to seek funds from banks that lent it money before the dairy company’s 2003 bankruptcy. The Dec. 28 court ruling affects several banks including Intesa Sanpaolo, Banco Popolare di Verona & Novara, Credit Suisse, Unipol Banca and Banca Popolare dell’Etruria & del Lazio.

headline.main: Parmalat Gets Green Light to Pursue Banks

abstract: German prosecutors brought charges Thursday against a second suspect in a corruption scandal at Volkswagen, accusing a federal lawmaker and former employee representative of involvement in events that featured prostitutes. Hans-Jürgen Uhl was accused of being an accessory to breach of trust over his alleged participation in events in Barcelona and Seoul in 2001 “during the course of which the services of prostitutes allegedly were called upon,” prosecutors in Braunschweig said in a statement.
lead_paragraph: German prosecutors brought charges Thursday against a second suspect in a corruption scandal at Volkswagen, accusing a federal lawmaker and former employee representative of involvement in events that featured prostitutes. Hans-Jürgen Uhl was accused of being an accessory to breach of trust over his alleged participation in events in Barcelona and Seoul in 2001 “during the course of which the services of prostitutes allegedly were called upon,” prosecutors in Braunschweig said in a statement.

headline.main: German Lawmaker Charged in Volkswagen Scandal

abstract: A former public prosecutor has started work at Siemens to help the company track down hundreds of millions of euros suspected of having been transferred illegally into foreign accounts and used for bribes. The former prosecutor, Daniel Noa, until recently a senior public prosecutor in Stuttgart, Germany, started Jan. 1 as the chief compliance officer for Siemens and will have direct access to the financial records needed for an internal company investigation. Mr. Noa managed “substantial white-collar crimes cases” for more than 20 years, the company, based in Munich, said.
lead_paragraph: A former public prosecutor has started work at Siemens to help the company track down hundreds of millions of euros suspected of having been transferred illegally into foreign accounts and used for bribes. The former prosecutor, Daniel Noa, until recently a senior public prosecutor in Stuttgart, Germany, started Jan. 1 as the chief compliance officer for Siemens and will have direct access to the financial records needed for an internal company investigation. Mr. Noa managed “substantial white-collar crimes cases” for more than 20 years, the company, based in Munich, said.

headline.main: Siemens Hires Former Prosecutor to Help Root Out Corruption

abstract: The chief executive of Ford Motor, Alan Mulally, has said he traveled to Japan last month to meet with Toyota Motor executives just to show his respect for what they had accomplished, not in an effort to bring the companies any closer. Reports that the chairman of Toyota, Fujio Cho, had met in Tokyo with Mr. Mulally at Mr. Mullaly’s request had sparked talk of a potential alliance. Mr. Mulally squelched that speculation again Wednesday, saying that manufacturing methods – along with safety engineering, fuel economy and environmental issues – were topics that all automakers discussed with one another.

headline.main: Ford Chief Squashes Talks of a Toyota Alliance

abstract: The high-stakes battle to acquire Caremark Rx, pharmacy benefits manager, escalated on Thursday when Express Scripts urged Caremark shareholders to reject an offer from the drugstore chain CVS. In a letter to Caremark shareholders, Express Scripts said that the CVS deal would have a “lasting negative impact” and called the CVS offer insufficient.
lead_paragraph: The high-stakes battle to acquire Caremark Rx, pharmacy benefits manager, escalated on Thursday when Express Scripts urged Caremark shareholders to reject an offer from the drugstore chain CVS. In a letter to Caremark shareholders, Express Scripts said that the CVS deal would have a “lasting negative impact” and called the CVS offer insufficient.

headline.main: Rival Caremark Suitors in War of Words

abstract: The New York Times Company has agreed to sell its nine local television stations to Oak Hill Capital Partners, a private equity firm, for $575 million, as the industry struggles to find ways to bolster the troubled newspaper business amid flagging advertising revenues. For The Times Company, which owns The New York Times, The Boston Globe and The International Herald Tribune as well as 15 local newspapers, in particular, total ad revenue has been down more than 3 percent every month since July compared with the same month in the previous year, reversing gains in the earlier months of 2006.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company has agreed to sell its nine local television stations to Oak Hill Capital Partners, a private equity firm, for $575 million, as the industry struggles to find ways to bolster the troubled newspaper business amid flagging advertising revenues. For The Times Company, which owns The New York Times, The Boston Globe and The International Herald Tribune as well as 15 local newspapers, in particular, total ad revenue has been down more than 3 percent every month since July compared with the same month in the previous year, reversing gains in the earlier months of 2006.

headline.main: Times Co. Sells TV Stations to Buyout Firm

abstract: Shares of Ecopia BioSciences fell more than 24 percent Thursday after the company announced a merger with Caprion Pharmaceuticals to create a new company specializing in developing treatments for cancer and infectious diseases.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Ecopia BioSciences fell more than 24 percent Thursday after the company announced a merger with Caprion Pharmaceuticals to create a new company specializing in developing treatments for cancer and infectious diseases.

headline.main: 2 Canadian Drug Companies to Merge

abstract: Much ink has been spilled on the banks that topped last year’s league tables (Goldman Sachs and Citigroup), but what about the losers? In a year when securities firms collected a record $36.7 billion for arranging stock and bond offerings, UBS and Deutsche Bank got left behind. Fees earned by the two banks climbed at less than half the pace of the world’s 25 top underwriters, which collectively posted a 23 percent increase in commissions in 2006, data compiled by Bloomberg News show.

Fees earned by the two banks climbed at less than half the pace of the world’s 25 top underwriters, which collectively posted a 23 percent increase in commissions in 2006, data compiled by Bloomberg News show.

headline.main: In Year of Record Fees, UBS and Deutsche Get Left Behind

abstract: Goldman Sachs has teamed up with CanWest Global Communications to make an offer for Alliance Atlantis Communications, a Canadian media company, The Globe and Mail said. The report said that the two could offer as much as 2.5 billion Canadian dollars ($2.1 billion) for Alliance, which was put on the block in December.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has teamed up with CanWest Global Communications to make an offer for Alliance Atlantis Communications, a Canadian media company, The Globe and Mail said. The report said that the two could offer as much as 2.5 billion Canadian dollars ($2.1 billion) for Alliance, which was put on the block in December.

headline.main: Goldman and CanWest Team Up for Alliance Bid, Report Says

abstract: In advance of the spring 2008 opening of their Broadway production of The First Wives Club–based on the popular book and movie–producers Paul Lambert and Jonas Neilson plan to start up First Wives World, an online social networking site for divorcees, according to BusinessWeek. The two producers will invest $8 million to $10 million to get the site, which will offer ticket sales, forums, blogs, and, soon after, a dating service, off the ground this spring.
lead_paragraph: In advance of the spring 2008 opening of their Broadway production of The First Wives Club–based on the popular book and movie–producers Paul Lambert and Jonas Neilson plan to start up First Wives World, an online social networking site for divorcees, according to BusinessWeek. The two producers will invest $8 million to $10 million to get the site, which will offer ticket sales, forums, blogs, and, soon after, a dating service, off the ground this spring.

headline.main: Producers to Start Club for Real First Wives

abstract: With no new income trust issues coming to Canada’s public markets after the Oct. 31 federal government announcement that it would begin taxing trusts in 2011, the country’s initial public offering activity slowed dramatically in the final quarter of 2006 and the outlook for 2007 looks “very dim,” according to PricewaterhouseCoopers Canada.
lead_paragraph: With no new income trust issues coming to Canada’s public markets after the Oct. 31 federal government announcement that it would begin taxing trusts in 2011, the country’s initial public offering activity slowed dramatically in the final quarter of 2006 and the outlook for 2007 looks “very dim,” according to PricewaterhouseCoopers Canada.

headline.main: Tax Plan on Income Trusts Slows Canadian I.P.O.s

abstract: Power Financial confirmed Thursday that it was in discussions to buy the money manager Putnam Investments of Boston, but it said no agreement had been reached. Media reports have been rife with the news that Power Financial, a unit of the holding company Power Corporation of Canada, has agreed to buy Putnam from its parent, the financial services company Marsh & McLennan, for $3.9 billion. A statement from Power said that because of “media speculation” and discussions with the Toronto Stock Exchange it was confirming the talks, but that “at this time, no agreement has been reached by the participants in the process.”
lead_paragraph: Power Financial confirmed Thursday that it was in discussions to buy the money manager Putnam Investments of Boston, but it said no agreement had been reached. A statement from Power said that because of “media speculation” and discussions with the Toronto Stock Exchange it was confirming the talks, but that “at this time, no agreement has been reached by the participants in the process.”

headline.main: Surprising No One, Power Confirms Talks for Putnam

abstract: The wireless chip maker Broadcom said Thursday it had reached agreement with a number of executives, including its acting chief financial officer, to increase the per share exercise prices previously in effect for certain stock options. The disclosure came after the company, which faces a federal investigation of the matter, announced late last year that an internal probe had found a number of option grants between 1998 and 2003 were improperly dated.
lead_paragraph: The wireless chip maker Broadcom said Thursday it had reached agreement with a number of executives, including its acting chief financial officer, to increase the per share exercise prices previously in effect for certain stock options. The disclosure came after the company, which faces a federal investigation of the matter, announced late last year that an internal probe had found a number of option grants between 1998 and 2003 were improperly dated.

headline.main: Broadcom Raises Options Price for Executives

abstract: Everyone who knows him says it: In a tough fight, Kenneth G. Langone is a guy you want in your corner. But when Robert L. Nardelli, the former chief executive of Home Depot, refused to bend to the will of an exasperated board and accept a pay cut, he lost the crucial support of a friend who as lead director not only recruited him but presided over his compensation contract that would later draw so much fire, according to a report in The New York Times.

headline.main: How Langone Lost Faith in Nardelli

abstract: The bidding war for Hutchison Essar, India’s fourth-largest cellular phone operator, may turn into a four-way battle, according to a report that India’s Hinduja Group has entered the fray. According to The Wall Street Journal, Hinduja Group, a conglomerate with interests in steel, trucks and telecommunications, has approached Hutchison Whampoa about buying its 67 percent stake in Hutchison Essar.
lead_paragraph: The bidding war for Hutchison Essar, India’s fourth-largest cellular phone operator, may turn into a four-way battle, according to a report that India’s Hinduja Group has entered the fray. headline.main: Rival Bidder Emerges in Battle for Hutchinson Essar, Report Says

abstract: Google, which recently closed its $1.65 billion purchase of the video-sharing Web site YouTube, has bought a stake in China’s Xunlei Network Technology, which provides file-sharing and other services. The move was widely seen as an attempt by Google, which dominates the Internet search market in the United States, to compete better with Baidu.com, which controlled nearly 57 percent of China’s search-engine market at the end of June, according to Analysis International, an information technology research company based in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Google, which recently closed its $1.65 billion purchase of the video-sharing Web site YouTube, has bought a stake in China’s Xunlei Network Technology, which provides file-sharing and other services. headline.main: Google Buys Stake in Chinese Multimedia Site

abstract: Industrial Bank, which is part-owned by a unit of HSBC Holdings, plans an initial public offering in China after shares of rival banks soared. The China Securities Regulatory Commission’s listing committee will meet on Jan. 8 to review the bank’s plan to sell as many as 1.33 billion new shares. The lender, 16 percent owned by Hang Seng Bank the HSBC unit, plans to sell 20 percent to 25 percent of its share capital in the so-called A-share offering.
lead_paragraph: Industrial Bank, which is part-owned by a unit of HSBC Holdings, plans an initial public offering in China after shares of rival banks soared. The China Securities Regulatory Commission’s listing committee will meet on Jan. 8 to review the bank’s plan to sell as many as 1.33 billion new shares. The lender, 16 percent owned by Hang Seng Bank the HSBC unit, plans to sell 20 percent to 25 percent of its share capital in the so-called A-share offering.

headline.main: Industrial Bank Plans China I.P.O.

abstract: Pirate Capital, a $1.7 billion hedge fund, plans to solicit proxies in support of its push to persuade Brink’s, the armored-truck and security provider, to hire an investment bank for a possible sale. In a regulatory filing yesterday, Pirate Capital also proposed electing its founder and another Pirate executive to Brink’s board. Pirate owns 8.5 percent of Brink’s and is its largest shareholder. Both Pirate and MMI Investments, which owns 8.3 percent of Brink’s shares, want the company to hire an investment bank for a possible sale, in the belief that it is undervalued.
lead_paragraph: Pirate Capital, a $1.7 billion hedge fund, plans to solicit proxies in support of its push to persuade Brink’s, the armored-truck and security provider, to hire an investment bank for a possible sale. In a regulatory filing yesterday, Pirate Capital also proposed electing its founder and another Pirate executive to Brink’s board. Pirate owns 8.5 percent of Brink’s and is its largest shareholder. Both Pirate and MMI Investments, which owns 8.3 percent of Brink’s shares, want the company to hire an investment bank for a possible sale, in the belief that it is undervalued.

headline.main: Brink’s Investors Pushing for Sale of Company

abstract: The founder of Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that is winding down after losing more than $6 billion last year, is considering launching a firm with some former colleagues, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people close to the matter.
lead_paragraph: The founder of Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that is winding down after losing more than $6 billion last year, is considering launching a firm with some former colleagues, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people close to the matter.

headline.main: Amaranth Founder Said to Plan New Firm

abstract: For decades, activist shareholders were an entertaining, but largely ignored, Wall Street sideshow. Today, however, it seems that activists have captured the center ring and are directing the main event. On Wednesday, shareholder advocates like Relational Investors‘ Ralph V. Whitworth could claim one of their biggest prizes yet when Home Depot announced the resignation of its chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, long a target of shareholders’ ire for his large compensation and the company’s flagging stock price.
lead_paragraph: For decades, activist shareholders were an entertaining, but largely ignored, Wall Street sideshow. Whitworth could claim one of their biggest prizes yet when Home Depot announced the resignation of its chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, long a target of shareholders’ ire for his large compensation and the company’s flagging stock price.

headline.main: Gadfly Investors Get Respect

abstract: The McCormick Tribune Foundation, the second-largest shareholder in Tribune, said Thursday that it had hired the Blackstone Group to advise it on a course of action while the media conglomerate is on the block. The foundation’s five directors are all current or former members of Tribune management and could influence the company’s decision whether to sell some or all of its assets. The foundation and the company said they had taken steps to avoid any conflicts of interest.
lead_paragraph: The McCormick Tribune Foundation, the second-largest shareholder in Tribune, said Thursday that it had hired the Blackstone Group to advise it on a course of action while the media conglomerate is on the block. The foundation’s five directors are all current or former members of Tribune management and could influence the company’s decision whether to sell some or all of its assets. The foundation and the company said they had taken steps to avoid any conflicts of interest.

headline.main: Foundation Hires Blackstone to Advise on Tribune Moves

abstract: One of the biggest proposed law firm mergers of the last year has been called off, the victim of too many insurmountable issues. Dewey Ballantine and Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe, who jointly announced the news Thursday, had been in talks to create one of the nation’s largest legal advisers, with 1,500 lawyers based in New York and San Francisco. But questions about a variety of problems, ranging from management seniority to Dewey’s unfunded pension system, undermined the deal.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest proposed law firm mergers of the last year has been called off, the victim of too many insurmountable issues. Dewey Ballantine and Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe, who jointly announced the news Thursday, had been in talks to create one of the nation’s largest legal advisers, with 1,500 lawyers based in New York and San Francisco. But questions about a variety of problems, ranging from management seniority to Dewey’s unfunded pension system, undermined the deal.

headline.main: 2 Law Firms Call Off Their Plans for a Merger

abstract: Merck of Germany said Friday that it is considering the sale of its generic drugs business, which could fetch more than $5 billion, according to some estimates. Reuters reported that the German drugs and chemicals group seems eager to cut debt from its recent $13.3 billion acquisition of Serono, which it is financing largely through loans.
lead_paragraph: Merck of Germany said Friday that it is considering the sale of its generic drugs business, which could fetch more than $5 billion, according to some estimates. Reuters reported that the German drugs and chemicals group seems eager to cut debt from its recent $13.3 billion acquisition of Serono, which it is financing largely through loans.

headline.main: Germany’s Merck May Sell Generic Drugs Unit

abstract: Douglas Fuchs, an assistant United States attorney in Los Angeles, will join the white-collar crimes practice at Gibson Dunn & Crutcher, starting Monday, The Los Angeles Times said. Mr. Fuchs led the prosecution of 11 former executives of Homestore, an online real estate listings company, for a $67 million accounting fraud scheme. The company’s founder and former chief executive, Stuart Wolff, was sentenced last October to 15 years in federal prison after being found guilty of inflating revenue.
lead_paragraph: Douglas Fuchs, an assistant United States attorney in Los Angeles, will join the white-collar crimes practice at Gibson Dunn & Crutcher, starting Monday, The Los Angeles Times said. Mr. Fuchs led the prosecution of 11 former executives of Homestore, an online real estate listings company, for a $67 million accounting fraud scheme. The company’s founder and former chief executive, Stuart Wolff, was sentenced last October to 15 years in federal prison after being found guilty of inflating revenue.

headline.main: Former Prosecutor Joins Gibson Dunn

abstract: Despite increasing interest from private equity firms, Akzo Nobel insisted Thursday that it would push for an initial public offering of its 8 billion euro ($10.4 billion) pharmaceutical unit, Organon Biosciences, The Financial Times reported. While the Dutch conglomerate said an I.P.O. of Organon Biosciences was its preferred option, at least three consortiums may be preparing bids, the paper said. These include a group of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Warburg Pincus and CVC Capital Partners; another led by the Blackstone Group; and a third headed by Cinven. The Carlyle Group has also expressed interest.
lead_paragraph: Despite increasing interest from private equity firms, Akzo Nobel insisted Thursday that it would push for an initial public offering of its 8 billion euro ($10.4 billion) pharmaceutical unit, Organon Biosciences, The Financial Times reported. While the Dutch conglomerate said an I.P.O. of Organon Biosciences was its preferred option, at least three consortiums may be preparing bids, the paper said. These include a group of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Warburg Pincus and CVC Capital Partners; another led by the Blackstone Group; and a third headed by Cinven. The Carlyle Group has also expressed interest.

headline.main: Akzo Insists on an I.P.O. for Drug Unit, as Buyout Firms Circle

abstract: The year is starting with another underwhelming showing from Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor and corporate agitator who backed out of his General Motors investment late last year. Tracinda, Mr. Kerkorian’s holding vehicle, said Friday its offer to buy up to 15 million shares of MGM Mirage ended with a paltry 445,000 shares tendered, potentially quelling for now speculation that Mr. Kerkorian will mount a takeover of the casino operator.
