headline.main: Kerkorian’s MGM Offer Comes Up Short

abstract: As if YouTube  did not have enough trouble with its users posting clips that violate copyrights, the video-sharing site, newly acquired by Google, must now find a way to remove a video depicting a Merrill Lynch banker and a supermodel in what the Associated Press calls “intimate scenes.” A Brazilian judge this week ordered YouTube to filter out the video, which was the talk of Brazil when it first surfaced last fall.
lead_paragraph: As if YouTube  did not have enough trouble with its users posting clips that violate copyrights, the video-sharing site, newly acquired by Google, must now find a way to remove a video depicting a Merrill Lynch banker and a supermodel in what the Associated Press calls “intimate scenes.” A Brazilian judge this week ordered YouTube to filter out the video, which was the talk of Brazil when it first surfaced last fall.

headline.main: Amorous Brazilian Banker Wins Round With YouTube

abstract: Stanislav Shpigelman, the former Merrill Lynch analyst who pleaded guilty to leaking confidential information to a $6.7 million insider-trading ring, was sentenced to three years and one month in prison in Manhattan federal court Friday. He was the second person and the first banker sentenced in connection with the conspiracy. Mr. Shpigelman, 24, admitted in July that he had given material nonpublic information about upcoming deals to Eugene Plotkin and David Pajcin, both former Goldman Sachs employees.
lead_paragraph: Stanislav Shpigelman, the former Merrill Lynch analyst who pleaded guilty to leaking confidential information to a $6.7 million insider-trading ring, was sentenced to three years and one month in prison in Manhattan federal court Friday. Mr. Shpigelman, 24, admitted in July that he had given material nonpublic information about upcoming deals to Eugene Plotkin and David Pajcin, both former Goldman Sachs employees.

headline.main: Former Merrill Analyst Sentenced in Insider-Trading Case

abstract: The former investment banker who has overseen Viacom‘s acquisition strategy for the past year just got a longer title for his business card. Wade Davis, the media group’s senior vice president of mergers and acquisitions since December 2005, has become senior vice president of strategy, mergers and acquisitions, Viacom said Friday.

abstract: A takeover bid is usually seen as something that props up a company’s share price. But a Pali Research analyst, Richard Greenfield, argues that just the reverse is true for Cablevision, the giant cable operator. In a research report on Friday, he suggests that Cablevision’s stock is worth far more than what its controlling family, the Dolans, has said it is willing to pay.

abstract: February 2 is likely to be a happy day for Michael Lynch. That is when shareholders of Readers Digest Association are set to vote on Ripplewood Holdings‘ offer to take the publishing company private. If the deal closes, Mr. Lynch, who advised Readers Digest alongside his former employer, Goldman Sachs, is individually eligible for a $2.75 million fee. TheStreet.com wrote about the fee Friday, labelling it “quite a coup” for Mr. Lynch and calling the tag-team advisory arrangement “highly unusual.”
lead_paragraph: February 2 is likely to be a happy day for Michael Lynch. TheStreet.com wrote about the fee Friday, labelling it “quite a coup” for Mr. Lynch and calling the tag-team advisory arrangement “highly unusual.”

headline.main: Windfall Awaits Readers Digest Banker

abstract: Some venture-capital types are sounding awfully weary about Web 2.0, a much-hyped term that The New York Times’s David Pogue recently defined as “participatory Web sites, like YouTube, MySpace, Wikipedia, Digg and Flickr, which [rely] on material supplied by the audience itself.”

abstract: Carlyle Group, the giant private equity firm based in Washington, D.C., said this week it promoted 16 professionals to managing director, including three members of its New York office. It also promoted 18 people to principal or director, titles it said are equivalent in rank, principal being used in the United States and director in Europe and Asia.

abstract: Japan, the most energy-efficient developed country, offers a lesson in using technology to reduce energy consumption.

lead_paragraph: AES, the big power company, is branching out to wind power generation and other alternative energy. The company, which generates and distributes electricity in 26 countries, is also entering the $28 billion carbon trading market, where credits are exchanged to reduce or offset greenhouse gas emissions. Its chief executive, Paul Hanrahan, sat down in his office at the company’s sleek new headquarters in Arlington, Va., to discuss these developments. Following are excerpts:

headline.main: A Future With the Wind

Crowded high-end malls, political stability and the country’s designation as host of the 2010 World Cup reflect a sense of optimism and progress. abstract: CONFERENCE SEASON Three major consumer-oriented business conferences will be vying for headlines this week, with new product announcements from participating companies expected to be flying thick and fast. New cars, computers, televisions, electronic gadgets — there will be plenty for nearly any taste. The 2007 North American International Auto Show started yesterday in Detroit; press previews are through Tuesday and industry previews are on Wednesday and on Thursday. The auto show opens to the public on Saturday, through Jan. 21. The 2007 International C.E.S. (consumer electronics show) takes place on Monday through Thursday in Las Vegas. Apple’s Macworld conference opens on Tuesday in San Francisco. Among possible new products is a combination iPod and cellphone.

abstract: Studies found unhappy eat larger amounts of foods they consider tasty, but unhealthy.
snippet: Studies found unhappy eat larger amounts of foods they consider tasty, but unhealthy.
lead_paragraph: Test subjects watching “Love Story,” the lachrymose 1970 romance, ate on average almost 125 grams of buttered, salty popcorn (the amount found in a medium-size bag at the movies) — about 28 percent more than did those watching “Sweet Home Alabama,” the 2002 fish-out-of-water comedy about a fashion designer going home to the rural South. The experiment, which involved 30 subjects watching each film over two days, was described in a paper in the January issue of the Journal of Marketing about the connection between people’s moods and the type and quantity of food they eat. The studies found that compared with happy people, people who are feeling unhappy eat larger amounts of foods they consider tasty, but unhealthy.

headline.main: Balms for Sadness: Salt, Grease, Sugar ...

lead_paragraph: Shares of Time Warner Cable, the second largest cable company in the nation, could hit the market within the next few weeks, analysts said. But Time Warner may bring its cable unit to market without having to go through the costly and time-consuming process of an initial public offering.

headline.main: Time Warner Cable May Come to Market Without an I.P.O.

abstract: As many newspapers across the country are cutting their staffs and trimming back on Washington coverage, The Politico — the (mostly) online political news venture starting publication in two weeks — is finding younger journalists and some veterans who are willing to leave the once-secure confines of traditional print to join a start-up. And if The Politico succeeds, it could signal that the Web has become a more plausible alternative for mainstream journalists, says The New York Times. But, it notes, there are skeptics who say that the focus of The Politico is too narrow and that the marketplace too crowded with sources of political news.

And if The Politico succeeds, it could signal that the Web has become a more plausible alternative for mainstream journalists, says The New York Times. But, it notes, there are skeptics who say that the focus of The Politico is too narrow and that the marketplace too crowded with sources of political news.

headline.main: For Journalists, Politics Not as Usual

The move represents a public-relations coup for NetSuite, an Internet-based maker of business management software preparing for an initial public offering later this year.

Caxton said in a filing that it had raised its stake to 11.2 percent from 9.9 percent after discussions with InFocus management in the fourth quarter of last year had yielded unsatisfactory results.

abstract: The announcement Thursday by two foundations with close ties to the Tribune that they had hired New York’s Blackstone Group to advise them as they consider alternatives for their combined 13.1 percent stake in Tribune stock, has put the focus on what role, if any, Tribune management will have in a possible deal for the media company.
lead_paragraph: The announcement Thursday by two foundations with close ties to the Tribune that they had hired New York’s Blackstone Group to advise them as they consider alternatives for their combined 13.1 percent stake in Tribune stock, has put the focus on what role, if any, Tribune management will have in a possible deal for the media company.

headline.main: Will Tribune Managers Enter the Bidding Fray?

abstract: A group of Equity Office Properties Trust bondholders said Friday that they had received commitments from enough investors to block the Blackstone Group‘s tender offer for $725 million of their bonds. Investors owning a majority of bonds have agreed not to tender their securities, according to a statement from the law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison in New York. While Equity Office can still move ahead with the sale without approval from the bondholders, the group could force Blackstone to increase its offer, raising the $36 billion cost of what would be the biggest leveraged buyout ever.
lead_paragraph: A group of Equity Office Properties Trust bondholders said Friday that they had received commitments from enough investors to block the Blackstone Group‘s tender offer for $725 million of their bonds. Investors owning a majority of bonds have agreed not to tender their securities, according to a statement from the law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison in New York. While Equity Office can still move ahead with the sale without approval from the bondholders, the group could force Blackstone to increase its offer, raising the $36 billion cost of what would be the biggest leveraged buyout ever.

headline.main: Equity Office Bondholders Pressure Blackstone for More Money

abstract: Delphi is facing objections to its bid for a six-month extension of its right to develop its bankruptcy-reorganization plan without interference from creditors or investors. Delphi, an auto parts supplier, said it needs the extra time to meet the terms of a “framework agreement” that proposes a $3.4 billion capital infusion from a pair of hedge funds and a private equity firm.

abstract: Weinberg Capital Partners, a French buyout fund headed by the former head of luxury goods group PPR, Serge Weinberg, said Friday it had agreed to buy 60 percent of French baking equipment maker Sasa Industrie in a deal that values the group at 80.7 million euros ($106 million). The acquisition is the fourth by Weinberg Capital, which was founded in July 2005 by Mr. Weinberg, one of France’s highest-profile managers, and three partners, Guillaume d’Angerville, Henri Gagnaire and Philippe Klocanas.

abstract: Robert L. Nardelli’s unceremonious departure from Home Depot may spell the end of the era of super-size pay packages for chief executives of public companies, but a new refuge for lavish compensation is emerging elsewhere. Private equity firms are beginning to offer compensation on a previously unimaginable scale to the chief executives who run the once-public companies that the firms have bought out.

abstract: With the end of the holidays comes a fresh start and new resolve to lead a loftier, healthier, simpler life. Then, before you know it, everyone in the media business hops on planes to Las Vegas and swarms the Consumer Electronics Show, which started Saturday. More than big awards shows or investment bank conferences and guru gatherings, C.E.S. has emerged as the Super Bowl of cluster-huddles, writes The New York Times’ Richard Siklos. And it has increasingly become a conference not just for tech aficionados, but for the heads of the media companies who create the content for said gadgets as well.
lead_paragraph: With the end of the holidays comes a fresh start and new resolve to lead a loftier, healthier, simpler life. Then, before you know it, everyone in the media business hops on planes to Las Vegas and swarms the Consumer Electronics Show, which started Saturday. And it has increasingly become a conference not just for tech aficionados, but for the heads of the media companies who create the content for said gadgets as well.

headline.main: At Electronics Show, A Cool Gadget Here, an A-List Chieftain There

abstract: State Farm is said to be the in final stages of settling hundreds of lawsuits for homes wrecked by Hurricane Katrina.
snippet: State Farm is said to be the in final stages of settling hundreds of lawsuits for homes wrecked by Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: State Farm, the biggest home insurer in the nation, is in the final stages of settling hundreds of lawsuits over its payments for homes wrecked by Hurricane Katrina along the Mississippi Gulf Coast, lawyers briefed on the talks said yesterday.

headline.main: State Farm Negotiating Gulf Claims Settlement

abstract: An appeals court on Friday overturned convictions against two former executives of Westar Energy who were accused of “looting” the Kansas utility and said the most serious charges cannot be retried. The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit said the case against the former chief executive, David Wittig, and the former chief strategy officer, Douglas Lake, “hung by a thin legal thread,” based on claims that the men tried to hide their personal use of corporate aircraft from securities officials.
lead_paragraph: An appeals court on Friday overturned convictions against two former executives of Westar Energy who were accused of “looting” the Kansas utility and said the most serious charges cannot be retried. headline.main: Appeals Court Reverses Convictions of 2 Westar Energy Executives

abstract: It’s time to put the record Wall Street bonuses you’ve heard about in perspective. Yes, a few investment stars did reap tens of millions, topped by Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chairman of Goldman Sachs, who received $53.4 million. But these people were the exception, writes The New York Times’ Phyllis Korkki, pointing to data that show the average 2006 bonus in the New York securities industry was about $137,000, an increase of 15 percent from the year before.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to put the record Wall Street bonuses you’ve heard about in perspective. Yes, a few investment stars did reap tens of millions, topped by Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chairman of Goldman Sachs, who received $53.4 million. But these people were the exception, writes The New York Times’ Phyllis Korkki, pointing to data that show the average 2006 bonus in the New York securities industry was about $137,000, an increase of 15 percent from the year before.

headline.main: Jumbo Bonuses: Dial Your Envy Down a Notch

abstract: In a series of appointments expected to solidify the management at Viacom, the company named Robert M. Bakish as president of MTV Networks International. He will report to William H. Roedy, who is global chairman of MTV Networks and has oversight of MTV’s international operation.

abstract: HSBC‘s chairman, Stephen Green, told The Financial Times he planned to run the bank as a ”double act” with the chief executive, Michael Geoghegan, who would lead its management team to deliver the strategy. In an interview in Monday’s edition of the newspaper, Mr. Green also said the bank, the biggest in Europe, did make mistakes but always moved to fix the problem. He detailed the division of labor between the post of chairman and the chief executive, calling it an evolution of the respective roles under his predecessor, John Bond.

headline.main: HSBC Tries Tag-Team Approach

abstract: Ford Motor‘s British luxury division Jaguar is not for sale, the chief executive, Alan Mulally, told reporters on the sidelines of an auto show on Sunday. Mr. Mulally, who became Ford’s chief execlutive in September, had earlier declined to rule out the sale of money-losing Jaguar and other premium brands in its portfolio.

abstract: Citigroup has raised $3.3 billion for private equity investments, highlighting the growing eagerness of Wall Street banks to take part in the high-risk, high-return boom in leveraged buyouts. The fresh pool of money, to be announced on Monday, exceeds the bank’s $2.5 billion target and includes commitments from clients and employees, as well as $1 billion of the bank’s own balance sheet. The fund, Citigroup Capital Partners II, will be used to strike deals in a variety of industries and regions alongside other private equity firms.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup has raised $3.3 billion for private equity investments, highlighting the growing eagerness of Wall Street banks to take part in the high-risk, high-return boom in leveraged buyouts. The fresh pool of money, to be announced on Monday, exceeds the bank’s $2.5 billion target and includes commitments from clients and employees, as well as $1 billion of the bank’s own balance sheet. The fund, Citigroup Capital Partners II, will be used to strike deals in a variety of industries and regions alongside other private equity firms.

headline.main: Citigroup Raises $3.3 Billion for Buyout Fund

abstract: NCR, the world’s largest maker of automated-teller machines, said it would split into two public companies, spinning off its Teradata data warehousing business. The spinoff should be completed in six to nine months, separating their businesses into NCR’s banking and checkout systems and Teradata’s corporate data storage operations, NCR said in a statement Monday. J.P. Morgan Chase is serving as financial adviser in the move.
lead_paragraph: NCR, the world’s largest maker of automated-teller machines, said it would split into two public companies, spinning off its Teradata data warehousing business. abstract: United Surgical Partners International agreed Monday to be acquired by Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe, the buyout firm that helped create the surgery center operator, for $1.8 billion in cash. UNCN Acquisition, a unit of the New York private-equity firm, offered $31.05 a share for United Surgical, a 13 percent premium over Friday’s closing price.

abstract: Houston Exploration agreed Sunday to be acquired by Forest Oil for $1.5 billion. A natural-gas driller, Houston Exploration had put itself up for sale after rejecting an unsolicited $62-a-share bid by a hedge fund, Jana Partners, last year. Jana Partners, the largest shareholder of Houston Exploration with a 14.7 percent stake, supports the transaction, Houston Exploration said.

abstract: The day when consumers can download content from the Internet directly to their TV may not be that far off.
snippet: The day when consumers can download content from the Internet directly to their TV may not be that far off.
lead_paragraph: The day when consumers can download content from the Internet directly to their TV may not be that far off. Last night, Sony announced a plan to sell a module that, when connected to their next generation of flat panel TVs, will allow customers to watch music, short videos, and other high-def content that’s streaming off the Internet.

headline.main: Sony Dips Its Toes Into Internet TV

abstract: Portugal Telecom, the country’s largest network operator, is expected to receive a $14 billion hostile bid from a rival, Sonae, this week, after a private-equity consortium dropped out of the running, The Financial Times reported Monday. That group, comprising Texas Pacific, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the Blackstone Group, Cinven, Permira and Providence, was formed last March.
lead_paragraph: Portugal Telecom, the country’s largest network operator, is expected to receive a $14 billion hostile bid from a rival, Sonae, this week, after a private-equity consortium dropped out of the running, The Financial Times reported Monday. abstract: A former employee of Spinner Asset Management, a $200 million New York hedge fund, has been accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of illegal short selling as part of trades in private investments. The former executive, Joseph Spiegel, paid a $110,000 fine and accepted a three-year ban for trades meant to hedge investments in private investments in public equity, or PIPEs. In December, the S.E.C. sued Edwin Buchanan “Bucky” Lyon IV of Gryphon, a Dallas-based hedge fund, for similar violations.

abstract: A few months after announcing his resignation as HSBC‘s European head of investment banking, David Livingstone has resurfaced as Credit Suisse‘s head of mergers and acquisitions in Europe. Mr. Livingstone started his new position in Credit Suisse’s London office on Monday, the firm said. Susan Kilsby, who had been Credit Suisse’s head of European M&A since 2002, was named chairman of European M&A at the investment bank, Credit Suisse said Monday.
lead_paragraph: A few months after announcing his resignation as HSBC‘s European head of investment banking, David Livingstone has resurfaced as Credit Suisse‘s head of mergers and acquisitions in Europe. Mr. Livingstone started his new position in Credit Suisse’s London office on Monday, the firm said. Susan Kilsby, who had been Credit Suisse’s head of European M&A since 2002, was named chairman of European M&A at the investment bank, Credit Suisse said Monday.

headline.main: Credit Suisse Names Head of European M&A

abstract: Quadrangle Group, an investment firm that focuses on media and communications companies, said Monday it had promoted several professionals in its private equity and distressed debt groups. Jeffrey Nordhaus, who joined the firm from Goldman Sachs in 2001, was promoted to managing principal from principal. Mr. Nordhaus leads several of Quadrangle’s investment sectors, including cable and leisure, the firm said.

abstract: The London Stock Exchange snagged more initial public offerings than the New York Stock Exchange in 2006, putting a dent in an otherwise impressive year for the NYSE Group, which runs the New York exchange. But there may be a downside for the L.S.E. as well: British regulators are fighting a 40 percent spike in business fraud, according to the New York Post. Citing a report by BDO Stoy Hayward, problems such as stock swindles and profit-rigging have cropped up in increasing numbers, costing at least $2.7 billion.

abstract: Remember Zenith? It used to be one of America’s premiere television brands, but it’s now described as a “promotional” product by company officials.
snippet: Remember Zenith? It used to be one of America’s premiere television brands, but it’s now described as a “promotional” product by company officials.
lead_paragraph: Remember Zenith? It used to be one of America’s premiere television brands, along with Magnavox and RCA. The company invented the remote control and was part of an early experiment in pay TV back in the 1960s. When every other company was bought up by overseas rivals, Zenith prided itself on the fact it was still American-owned and American-made.

abstract: Is Silicon Valley getting a bit too ghoulish? Fred Wilson, a well-known venture capitalist, seemed to suggest as much as he criticized the “dead pool” on TechCrunch, a closely watched blog that focuses on the technology business. Mr. Wilson’s comments came soon after TechCrunch’s editor, Michael Arrington, wrote that the number of entries in his dead pool has been growing more quickly and “startup ranks are starting to thin.”

abstract: Flush with record-breaking bonuses, investment bankers and hedge funders are said to be driving up demand for all kinds of luxury goods, including expensive cars and multimillion-dollar apartments. (Whether or not that is true is another story.) Now, Bloomberg News suggests that Wall Street’s very good year could be raising prices in another area: office space rents. The cost of renting commercial space in Manhattan has jumped by as much as 35 percent, according to reports by two commercial brokers, which Bloomberg traces in part to the expanding financial-services sector.

abstract: When the time came to hammer out legal issues in last year’s megadeals, chances are someone from Skadden Arps Slate Meagher and Flom was there. abstract: Manufacturing orders rose for the first time in three months in November, led by an increase in demand for trucks and cars. Demand for consumer goods advanced 2.7 percent.

abstract: The Samsung Electronics Company forecast record profit from consumer electronics this year, helped by television sales. Profit this year from the digital media division, including earnings from overseas affiliates, will probably exceed 1 trillion won ($1.1 billion) for the first time, Choi Gee Sung, president of the division, said in a statement. Samsung plans to sell 11 million L.C.D. televisions in 2007, up from 6.2 million units last year, the company said. Samsung, which is based in Suwon, South Korea, also forecast its shipments of plasma TVs to rise to 2.5 million units this year, compared with 1.3 million sets in 2006.

abstract: Dracula’s castle may sell for 60 million euros ($78 million) after the local government offered to buy the Transylvanian fortress to increase tourism revenue. The Brasov County Council in central Romania is in talks with a foreign bank on a 10-year loan for that amount to get back the castle from its current owners living abroad, Aristotel Cancescu, president of the municipality, said in a telephone interview. Built in 1212 by Teutonic knights, the castle was briefly used two centuries later by the Romanian ruler Vlad the Impaler, who inspired Bram Stoker’s legend of Count Dracula. The castle’s current owners are Dominic von Habsburg, an industrial designer who lives in New York, and his sisters, Elisabeth Sandhofer and Maria-Magdalena Holzhausen, who both live in Austria.

abstract: The former chief executive of the software company Aspen Technology surrendered Monday to face charges that he inflated the company’s software revenues as he competed to become its chief executive. The executive, David L. McQuillin, 48, of Sudbury, Mass., was accused in Federal District Court in Manhattan of plotting to exaggerate the company’s software revenue from January 2001 to September 2002. In court filings, prosecutors accused Mr. McQuillin of trying to inflate the revenue while he was competing against the company’s other chief operating officer to become chief executive. He became chief executive in October 2002.

abstract: Conrad Black engaged in insider trading with the help of Toronto-based Brascan in 1998 to prop up the share price of Hollinger International, according to part of an expanded series of allegations by prosecutors in the United States Attorney’s office in Chicago. The filing alleges that Lord Black split profits from the trading with a group of associates and Brascan, and that he circumvented securities laws. Lord Black and three other former Hollinger executives face a variety of criminal charges over allegations they looted more than $80 million from the media company.

abstract: Yahoo has purchased MyBlogLog, a social-networking site that aims to build communities among like-minded blog readers. Yahoo did not disclose what it paid for the Florida-based MyBlogLog, first launched in July, but the report put the price tag at a little over $10 million. Mybloglog also looks at reader behavior inside blogs, like what is being read and where readers go next, delivering information it can sell to web advertisers.

abstract: US Airways Group said Monday that it has enlisted Morgan Stanley to join Citigroup in providing the financing for its hostile $8.5 billion bid for Delta Air Lines. US Airways, which made its unsolicited bid for Delta in November, said at the time that it had tapped Citigroup for a $7.2 billion debt package intended to provide the cash portion of its offer as well as to refinance the merged company. Delta management strongly opposes the bid, seeking instead to exit bankruptcy as a stand-alone company.

US Airways, which made its unsolicited bid for Delta in November, said at the time that it had tapped Citigroup for a $7.2 billion debt package intended to provide the cash portion of its offer as well as to refinance the merged company. Delta management strongly opposes the bid, seeking instead to exit bankruptcy as a stand-alone company.

headline.main: Morgan Stanley Gets on Board US Airways Bid

abstract: Fidelity Investments said on Monday that Stephen P. Jonas, who engineered a makeover in less than two years as head of the investment management unit of the giant mutual fund firm, would retire at the end of this month. The news surprised analysts and investors, who said Mr. Jonas was the engine that drove Fidelity’s makeover, doubling the size of its United States team of equities analysts, appointing new fund managers at some critical portfolios, including the flagship Magellan fund, and overseeing the move to new offices in Boston. As one of the world’s largest investors, with more than $1.3 trillion in assets, Fidelity has often played a role in pushing for change in the industry, and changes within its executive ranks draw attention.

As one of the world’s largest investors, with more than $1.3 trillion in assets, Fidelity has often played a role in pushing for change in the industry, and changes within its executive ranks draw attention.

headline.main: Leader of Revived Fidelity Unit to Retire

abstract: ABN Amro Capital, the private equity arm of the banking giant ABN Amro, has spun its life-sciences division off into an independent venture capital firm, Forbion Capital Partners, the new group said Monday, while announcing the close of a 200 million euros ($260 million) fund to take advantage of the company’s successful track record in a difficult sector.
lead_paragraph: ABN Amro Capital, the private equity arm of the banking giant ABN Amro, has spun its life-sciences division off into an independent venture capital firm, Forbion Capital Partners, the new group said Monday, while announcing the close of a 200 million euros ($260 million) fund to take advantage of the company’s successful track record in a difficult sector.

headline.main: ABN Amro Spins Off Biotech Venture

abstract: Home Depot, the home improvement store chain, said Monday that its board would require that two-thirds of its independent directors approve any compensation granted to Robert L. Nardelli, the former chairman and chief executive. The decision, made last Thursday but not disclosed until Monday in a regulatory filing, follows an uproar over Mr. Nardelli’s pay.
lead_paragraph: Home Depot, the home improvement store chain, said Monday that its board would require that two-thirds of its independent directors approve any compensation granted to Robert L. Nardelli, the former chairman and chief executive. The decision, made last Thursday but not disclosed until Monday in a regulatory filing, follows an uproar over Mr. Nardelli’s pay.

headline.main: Home Depot to Review Nardelli’s Pay

abstract: Anheuser-Busch has cut an importing and distribution deal with a Czech brewer — the same one it has been warring with for years over who owns the rights to the Budweiser trademark. Budejovicky Budvar and Anheuser-Busch have been fighting for almost 100 years in a country-by-country spat over the brand — and the deal will not stop that — but the two have now joined hands in a pact that will make the St. Louis-based brewer the importer of Czechvar, the name under which Budvar has been sold in the United States since 2001.
lead_paragraph: Anheuser-Busch has cut an importing and distribution deal with a Czech brewer — the same one it has been warring with for years over who owns the rights to the Budweiser trademark. Budejovicky Budvar and Anheuser-Busch have been fighting for almost 100 years in a country-by-country spat over the brand — and the deal will not stop that — but the two have now joined hands in a pact that will make the St. Louis-based brewer the importer of Czechvar, the name under which Budvar has been sold in the United States since 2001.

headline.main: A Bud by Any Other Name

abstract: The New York Stock Exchange is a little behind schedule, it seems. Its parent, the NYSE Group, requested Monday that the Securities and Exchange Commission postpone the implementation date of Regulation NMS, a series of sweeping changes designed to update United States markets for new, rapid trading technologies, from Feb. 5 to March 5.
lead_paragraph: The New York Stock Exchange is a little behind schedule, it seems. headline.main: N.Y.S.E. Asks S.E.C. To Delay New Trading Rules

abstract: Vodafone will start examining Hutchison Essar‘s books on Tuesday as it mulls a bid of $18 billion to $19 billion for the company, India’s fourth-largest mobile phone operator, The Financial Times reported. The newspaper said Vodafone had appointed Ernst & Young to help it with the due diligence process. The report said that fifteen Vodafone executives flew to Mumbai over the weekend to undertake parallel due diligence on the operational side of the business.

The report said that fifteen Vodafone executives flew to Mumbai over the weekend to undertake parallel due diligence on the operational side of the business.

headline.main: Vodafone Gets Exclusive Look at Essar’s Books, Report Says

abstract: A Dutch billionaire, John de Mol, has taken a 5.15 percent stake in a television production company, Endemol, a business he founded in 1994 and sold to the Spanish telecom giant Telefonica six years later. The small holding in the company, which produces the “Big Brother” and “Deal or No Deal” television shows, was announced Monday by de Mol’s investment vehicle, Cyrte Investments, and could mark the first step in a campaign to regain control of the company.
lead_paragraph: A Dutch billionaire, John de Mol, has taken a 5.15 percent stake in a television production company, Endemol, a business he founded in 1994 and sold to the Spanish telecom giant Telefonica six years later. The small holding in the company, which produces the “Big Brother” and “Deal or No Deal” television shows, was announced Monday by de Mol’s investment vehicle, Cyrte Investments, and could mark the first step in a campaign to regain control of the company.

headline.main: Is de Mol Looking to Take Back Endemol?

abstract: Mergers and acquisitions in the software industry, once characterized by multibillion-dollar transactions, entered into a phase of “leftover consolidation” in 2006, a report from The 451 Group, a research firm, concludes. While the number of transactions increased 20 percent from 2005 to 947, the aggregate value of those deals dropped 20 percent to $27 billion. Many of last year’s software deals involved second-tier vendors and vertical-market specialists, the report said.
lead_paragraph: Mergers and acquisitions in the software industry, once characterized by multibillion-dollar transactions, entered into a phase of “leftover consolidation” in 2006, a report from The 451 Group, a research firm, concludes. While the number of transactions increased 20 percent from 2005 to 947, the aggregate value of those deals dropped 20 percent to $27 billion. Many of last year’s software deals involved second-tier vendors and vertical-market specialists, the report said.

headline.main: In Software, More Deals But Smaller Prices

abstract: Xerox options trading surged Monday as trader speculation spread that Eastman Kodak could acquire the printer maker, options analysts told Reuters. But analysts downplayed the speculation, noting that such a transaction is unlikely to occur because film maker Kodak is less than half the size of Xerox by market capitalization and is in the midst of a restructuring following years of turmoil in its business.
lead_paragraph: Xerox options trading surged Monday as trader speculation spread that Eastman Kodak could acquire the printer maker, options analysts told Reuters. But analysts downplayed the speculation, noting that such a transaction is unlikely to occur because film maker Kodak is less than half the size of Xerox by market capitalization and is in the midst of a restructuring following years of turmoil in its business.

headline.main: Analysts Left Cold by Xerox Takeover Speculation

abstract: McAfee, the security software developer, said late Monday that it expects to record charges of $25 million to $45 million over “several periods commencing with the fourth quarter of 2006″ related to the improper granting of stock options. In October, McAfee announced that it had discovered the improper accounting of up to $150 million in option grants, and Chairman and Chief Executive George Samenuk subsequently resigned.
lead_paragraph: McAfee, the security software developer, said late Monday that it expects to record charges of $25 million to $45 million over “several periods commencing with the fourth quarter of 2006″ related to the improper granting of stock options. headline.main: McAfee to Take Charges Related to Stock Options

abstract: Nasdaq and the London Stock Exchange traded trans-Atlantic insults on Monday, as London exchange shareholders consider Nasdaq’s $5.3 billion hostile takeover offer. Nasdaq has been trying to take over the London exchange since March, but has failed to lure London executives to the negotiating table.
lead_paragraph: Nasdaq and the London Stock Exchange traded trans-Atlantic insults on Monday, as London exchange shareholders consider Nasdaq’s $5.3 billion hostile takeover offer. Nasdaq has been trying to take over the London exchange since March, but has failed to lure London executives to the negotiating table.

headline.main: Barbs Traded in Nasdaq Bid for Exchange in London

abstract: Alinta, Australia’s biggest energy transmission company, has received a management buyout proposal backed by Macquarie Bank in what would be the country’s largest utility buyout. Alinta shares surged as much as 14 percent, valuing the company at 6.3 billion Australian dollars ($4.9 billion). Macquarie, Australia’s biggest investment bank, is advising the group and may take a stake in the buyout, Alinta said in a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Alinta, Australia’s biggest energy transmission company, has received a management buyout proposal backed by Macquarie Bank in what would be the country’s largest utility buyout. Alinta shares surged as much as 14 percent, valuing the company at 6.3 billion Australian dollars ($4.9 billion). Macquarie, Australia’s biggest investment bank, is advising the group and may take a stake in the buyout, Alinta said in a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange on Tuesday.

headline.main: Australian Energy Giant Receives Buyout Offer

abstract: Smelling buyout opportunities in Asia, the law firm Kirkland & Ellis announced Monday that it has opened an office in Hong Kong after receiving regulatory approval. The bureau will be led by David Patrick Eich, a partner specializing in private equity deals who played a key role in the the $10.2 billion buyout of Philips Semiconductors by a consortium of private equity funds.
lead_paragraph: Smelling buyout opportunities in Asia, the law firm Kirkland & Ellis announced Monday that it has opened an office in Hong Kong after receiving regulatory approval. abstract: Investors appeared pleased with Monday’s announcement by NCR, the largest maker of automated teller machines and airport check-in kiosks, that it is planning to spin off its data management business, driving up the company’s stock. Shares of NCR rose as much as 7.1 percent, to $45.42, before falling back to close at $43.79, an increase of $1.39, or 3.3 percent, over Friday’s close, after NCR said it would spin off Teradata in what it expects to be a tax-free deal.

headline.main: Investors Applaud NCR’s Spin-Off Plan

abstract: Richard Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, whose pay package has been the subject of a legal battle, is getting hit on another front as well. The New York Post reports that the New York State Department of Taxation wants to impose a $1.8 million penalty on Mr. Grasso related to New York City tax returns it believes he should have filed in 2002 and 2003. The dispute, according to the Post, hinges on the location of Mr. Grasso’s main residence during that time.
lead_paragraph: Richard Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, whose pay package has been the subject of a legal battle, is getting hit on another front as well. The dispute, according to the Post, hinges on the location of Mr. Grasso’s main residence during that time.

headline.main: Grasso Spars With New York Over Taxes

abstract: If Gap, the casual clothing chain, ends up putting itself on the block, the potential buyer may end up shelling out more than $18 billion, in a deal that could be one of the largest buyouts in retail history, according to The New York Times. The company’s current market value is $16.4 billion, but analysts expect that a buyer would have to pay more than $18 billion.

abstract: Express Scripts opened a proxy war in the pharmacy benefits industry on Monday, saying it would nominate four directors to the 11-member board of Caremark Rx, which has agreed to merge with the drugstore chain CVS. The Financial Times’s Lex column suggested that in rejecting Express Scripts’s unsolicited takeover offer, Caremark may be blinded by its vision of transforming the industry.

abstract: Stifel Financial said Tuesday it had agreed to acquire Ryan Beck Holdings, a financial firm that postponed its initial public offering last summer. Stifel, which is based in St. Louis, will pay about $91.1 million in stock for Ryan Beck, a unit of a Florida regional bank, BankAtlantic Bancorp, and will additional payments if certain performance targets are met.

abstract: Shutterfly, an online photo service, said Monday that the chairman, Jim Clark, co-founder of Web pioneer Netscape Communications, had resigned. In explaining his departure, Mr. Clark said securities regulations, and more specifically the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, had “gone too far.” The harsh comments from one of Silicon Valley’s best-known entrepreneurs are likely to add to the debate about whether tougher laws are stifling innovation in the United States.

abstract: Caremark Rx seems to be girding for a serious fight. The pharmacy benefits manager, which recently rejected a $26 billion takeover bid from its rival Express Scripts in favor of a deal with the drugstore chain CVS, has hired Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz as a legal adviser. Wachtell Lipton is well-versed in the art of the takeover feud, having advised Walt Disney as it sought to fend off Comcast‘s hostile bid (which was withdrawn) and drug giant Sanofi in its hostile offer for Aventis (which succeeded).

abstract: The French billionaire François Pinault has until Feb. 2, or about three weeks, to decide whether to bid for the water and energy utility Suez, France’s stock-market regulator said Tuesday. If his holding company, Artemis, decides against a bid, he must steer clear of making a bid for Suez for six months unless there are “significant changes in the environment, situation or shareholder structure” in the company.
lead_paragraph: The French billionaire François Pinault has until Feb. 2, or about three weeks, to decide whether to bid for the water and energy utility Suez, France’s stock-market regulator said Tuesday. abstract: Investors sent Gap‘s stock surging 7 percent on Monday amid reports that it might be considering a sale. But Wall Street analysts quickly pointed out some obstacles to an acquisition of the retail chain, whose casual fashions have been languishing on the racks in recent months. These include a generally lackluster demand for retail companies (as shown by last year’s failed auctions for Jones Apparel and Pep Boys) and Gap’s relatively small amount of real-estate assets, which could be used to defray the cost of a buyout.

abstract: The London Stock Exchange, seeking to fend off a hostile takeover by the Nasdaq Stock Market, reported a 9.9 percent increase in third-quarter profit and forecast a “strong performance” in fiscal 2008. Net income rose to £31 million ($59.8 million) in the three months ended Dec. 31, up from £28.2 million a year earlier, the exchange said. Revenue increased 11 percent, to £89.9 million ($173.5 million). The third-quarter results “support the board’s rejection of Nasdaq’s offer, which significantly undervalues the business and the exchange’s unique strategic position,” the exchange’s chief executive, Clara Furse, said. “Our strong growth prospects will continue to enhance the quality of our markets.” The exchange, Europe’s biggest equity market, released its earnings about three weeks ahead of schedule and two days before Nasdaq’s offer to pay £12.43 a share expires.

abstract: A United States diplomat warned the European Commission against adopting rules that would impose emission controls on all flights landing at European airports, a signal that Washington may take legal action if the measure became law. The diplomat, John R. Byerly, left, deputy assistant secretary of state for transportation affairs, called the proposal “unworkable and unlawful.” The plan would force foreign airlines flying in Europe to pay for carbon dioxide emissions. Under the proposal, airlines would have to meet emissions targets starting Jan. 1, 2011, for all flights landing within the 27-member European Union. Mr. Byerly’s comments came on the eve of two days of formal talks with European officials aimed at concluding an “open skies” treaty to open up the trans-Atlantic aviation market.

abstract: Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, is planning to cut jobs at Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva to reduce overlap between the news groups. The number of positions to be eliminated will be announced at a company meeting Wednesday, and employees who will lose their jobs were to be contacted yesterday. The cuts follow Dow Jones’s purchase in October of the Reuters Group‘s 50 percent stake in the Factiva.com news database for $153 million.

abstract: The United States, moving to raise pressure on Iran, on Tuesday barred American financial institutions from doing business with a major Iranian bank after concluding that it had been involved in illicit weapons programs. In May, 15 brokerage firms agreed to settle accusations of violations in the same market.

abstract: After crunching the numbers on US Airways‘ latest bid for Delta Air Lines, several equity analysts said Wednesday that it seemed to present a better payout for creditors than Delta’s standalone reorganization plan. Their estimates were slightly different, but three of them calculated that US Airways was offering at least $2 billion more than Delta would be worth if it emerged from bankruptcy on its own. Their analysis suggests that US Airways’ new offer, consisting of $10.2 billion in cash and stock, may get serious consideration from Delta’s creditors.

abstract: For the second time since 2003, Odyssey Investment Partners is selling an aircraft parts maker to a rival buyout shop, Warburg Pincus. A Warburg Pincus portfolio company, TransDigm Group, said late Tuesday it would acquire Aviation Technologies, a Seattle parts producer, from Odyssey for $430 million in cash. Warburg Pincus bought TransDigm itself from Odyssey for $1.2 billion in June 2003, producing nearly a 300 percent gain on a $100 million equity investment for Odyssey in five years.
lead_paragraph: For the second time since 2003, Odyssey Investment Partners is selling an aircraft parts maker to a rival buyout shop, Warburg Pincus. A Warburg Pincus portfolio company, TransDigm Group, said late Tuesday it would acquire Aviation Technologies, a Seattle parts producer, from Odyssey for $430 million in cash. Warburg Pincus bought TransDigm itself from Odyssey for $1.2 billion in June 2003, producing nearly a 300 percent gain on a $100 million equity investment for Odyssey in five years.

headline.main: Another Aircraft Odyssey for Warburg Pincus

abstract: Two former executives at an online advertising company, Fastclick, have launched Great Pacific Capital, a locally focused venture firm based in Santa Barbara, Calif. Managing partner Dave Gross, the founding chief executive of Fastclick, told The Deal.com the firm’s first fund, Great Pacific Capital Partners I, had not yet closed, but that it would be capped at less than $50 million. In addition to putting in their own money, Mr. Gross and co-founder Rusty Reed have tapped primarily individuals in the region for funds, although Mr. Gross said other high-net-worth individuals from elsewhere could contribute as well.
lead_paragraph: Two former executives at an online advertising company, Fastclick, have launched Great Pacific Capital, a locally focused venture firm based in Santa Barbara, Calif. Managing partner Dave Gross, the founding chief executive of Fastclick, told The Deal.com the firm’s first fund, Great Pacific Capital Partners I, had not yet closed, but that it would be capped at less than $50 million. In addition to putting in their own money, Mr. Gross and co-founder Rusty Reed have tapped primarily individuals in the region for funds, although Mr. Gross said other high-net-worth individuals from elsewhere could contribute as well.

headline.main: Former Fastclick Executives Open Venture Capital Firm

abstract: Property in France, the United States and Italy is topping the shopping lists of bankers in London’s City this bonus season, with many putting down large deposits to reserve their second homes without even bothering to view the house, according to a report in The Guardian. About 51 percent of City bankers plan to invest in overseas property in 2007, according to a poll by Populus for the property agency PURE International, with France topping the list with 28 percent, followed by the United States with 21 percent.
lead_paragraph: Property in France, the United States and Italy is topping the shopping lists of bankers in London’s City this bonus season, with many putting down large deposits to reserve their second homes without even bothering to view the house, according to a report in The Guardian. About 51 percent of City bankers plan to invest in overseas property in 2007, according to a poll by Populus for the property agency PURE International, with France topping the list with 28 percent, followed by the United States with 21 percent.

headline.main: New Chateaux for London Bankers?

abstract: Earlier this week, several blogs and the New York Post picked up a funny and harrowing anecdote about the billionaire financier Carl Icahn that appeared in a profile in Avenue magazine: Aboard his leased aircraft, the activist investor (or “corporate raider” as he was known in the 1980’s) had just finished instructing Apollo‘s Leon Black on the virtues of leasing jets as compared to buying them when he saw smoke coming from the engine.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, several blogs and the New York Post picked up a funny and harrowing anecdote about the billionaire financier Carl Icahn that appeared in a profile in Avenue magazine: Aboard his leased aircraft, the activist investor (or “corporate raider” as he was known in the 1980’s) had just finished instructing Apollo‘s Leon Black on the virtues of leasing jets as compared to buying them when he saw smoke coming from the engine.

headline.main: Icahn on Chiefs, Morons and Leased Jets

abstract: Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor who controls MGM Mirage and led a failed bid to push General Motors into an alliance with Nissan and Renault, is more deeply involved in the federal case against the Hollywood private detective Anthony Pellicano than previously known, according to The New York Times. The Times has tapes of telephone conversations between Mr. Pellicano, who is currently in jail awaiting trial, and Mr. Kerkorian’s long-time lawyer that suggest that Mr. Kerkorian was aware that the private detective was listening in on his ex-wife’s conversations.
lead_paragraph: Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor who controls MGM Mirage and led a failed bid to push General Motors into an alliance with Nissan and Renault, is more deeply involved in the federal case against the Hollywood private detective Anthony Pellicano than previously known, according to The New York Times. The Times has tapes of telephone conversations between Mr. Pellicano, who is currently in jail awaiting trial, and Mr. Kerkorian’s long-time lawyer that suggest that Mr. Kerkorian was aware that the private detective was listening in on his ex-wife’s conversations.

headline.main: Kerkorian Caught Up in Pellicano Wiretapping Case

abstract: CanWest Global Communications and the private equity arm of Goldman Sachs said late Wednesday that they had reached a deal to acquire Alliance Atlantis for 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($2 billion). Under the terms of the long-anticipated takeover, CanWest will put down just 132 million Canadian dollars to gain control of the company’s specialty cable television channels valued at 1.5 billion Canadian dollars, according to The Globe and Mail.
lead_paragraph: CanWest Global Communications and the private equity arm of Goldman Sachs said late Wednesday that they had reached a deal to acquire Alliance Atlantis for 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($2 billion). Under the terms of the long-anticipated takeover, CanWest will put down just 132 million Canadian dollars to gain control of the company’s specialty cable television channels valued at 1.5 billion Canadian dollars, according to The Globe and Mail.

headline.main: Goldman and CanWest Win Alliance

abstract: the steelmaker Arcelor Mittal on Wednesday said it would not take legal action to force the sale of Dofasco of Canada to Germany’s ThyssenKrupp, leaving Dofasco’s ownership unchanged for now. During Mittal Steel’s contentious acquisition of Arcelor last year, the company pledged to sell the Dofasco unit to ThyssenKrupp if the merger was successful. But Arcelor, in a bid to stymie the Mittal bid, put 89 percent of Dofasco into a Dutch legal entity, called a stichting, to prevent its sale.
lead_paragraph: the steelmaker Arcelor Mittal on Wednesday said it would not take legal action to force the sale of Dofasco of Canada to Germany’s ThyssenKrupp, leaving Dofasco’s ownership unchanged for now. During Mittal Steel’s contentious acquisition of Arcelor last year, the company pledged to sell the Dofasco unit to ThyssenKrupp if the merger was successful. But Arcelor, in a bid to stymie the Mittal bid, put 89 percent of Dofasco into a Dutch legal entity, called a stichting, to prevent its sale.

headline.main: Arcelor Mittal Won’t Force Dofasco Sale

abstract: A California accountant pleaded guilty on Wednesday to charges of conspiracy, tax fraud and obstructing a federal investigation, and pledged to help prosecutors as they conduct a widening criminal investigation of questionable tax shelters. The accountant, Steven Michael Acosta, the fourth person in the inquiry to plead guilty, is a relatively minor figure in the investigation, which has led to the indictment of 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG. The inquiry has also ensnared Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, and other banks, accounting, law and investment firms.

The accountant, Steven Michael Acosta, the fourth person in the inquiry to plead guilty, is a relatively minor figure in the investigation, which has led to the indictment of 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG. The inquiry has also ensnared Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, and other banks, accounting, law and investment firms.

headline.main: Accountant Pleads Guilty in KPMG Shelter Case

abstract: Malden Mills Industries, the maker of Polartec cold-weather fabrics, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, less than four years after an earlier reorganization, and said it would be sold to the Gordon Brothers Group for $44 million. Gordon Brothers, a Boston-based firm that advises restructuring companies, will also assume an unspecified amount of debt. Any sale of the company, which employs 835 workers, is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court.
lead_paragraph: Malden Mills Industries, the maker of Polartec cold-weather fabrics, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, less than four years after an earlier reorganization, and said it would be sold to the Gordon Brothers Group for $44 million. Gordon Brothers, a Boston-based firm that advises restructuring companies, will also assume an unspecified amount of debt. Any sale of the company, which employs 835 workers, is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court.

headline.main: Malden Mills Returns to Bankruptcy

abstract: Comverse Technology’s former general counsel, William F. Sorin, will pay $3.1 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission accusations he conspired with the company’s former chief executive, Jacob Alexander, to backdate stock options. Mr. Sorin will forfeit $1.7 million in profit, plus $818,000 in interest, and will pay a $600,000 fine, according to an agreement filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. He played a “critical role” in backdating options at Comverse, the world’s biggest maker of voice-mail software, the agency said.
lead_paragraph: Comverse Technology’s former general counsel, William F. He played a “critical role” in backdating options at Comverse, the world’s biggest maker of voice-mail software, the agency said.

headline.main: Former Comverse Counsel to Settle Suit

abstract: Attorneys for the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, Richard A. Grasso, argued Wednesday that Mr. Grasso had fulfilled his fiduciary duty to the exchange and should be allowed to keep his $187.5 million compensation package. “[He acted] as a reasonably prudent person would act,” Gerson A. Zweifach, a Washington D.C.-based partner at Williams & Connolly, who represents Mr. Grasso, said in oral arguments before a New York appeals court panel.

abstract: A private investigator accused of posing as a journalist to read the reporter’s private phone records as part of the boardroom spying scandal at Hewlett-Packard was charged Wednesday with federal identity theft and conspiracy charges. The investigator, Bryan Wagner, is accused of using the Social Security number of the unidentified journalist to gain access illegally to the phone logs, according to the criminal charges filed by a United States attorney, Kevin V. Ryan, in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif.

abstract: EBay said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy the online ticket reseller StubHub for $310 million to bolster its share in the multibillion-dollar market for secondary sales of seats to concerts and sporting events.
lead_paragraph: EBay said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy the online ticket reseller StubHub for $310 million to bolster its share in the multibillion-dollar market for secondary sales of seats to concerts and sporting events.

headline.main: EBay Will Buy StubHub for $310 Million

abstract: The three principals of the KL Group in West Palm Beach, Fla., a firm that operated many hedge funds that collapsed in early 2005, were indicted Wednesday, accused of orchestrating an extensive fraud that raised more than $194 million from at least 250 investors. The three, Won Sok Lee, Yung Bae Kim and his brother Jung Bae Kim, who was also known as John B. Kim, are accused of promoting the KL hedge funds as successful, when, in fact, some of the funds suffered losses every quarter of their existence.

Kim, are accused of promoting the KL hedge funds as successful, when, in fact, some of the funds suffered losses every quarter of their existence.

abstract: The biggest leveraged buyout in history may get even bigger. A consortium of investors is considering making an offer worth more than $38 billion for Equity Office Properties Trust, the real estate investment trust that is controlled by Samuel Zell, The New York Times reported. The bid may not happen, but if it does, it would challenge the record-setting deal that Equity Office and the Blackstone Group agreed to in November.
lead_paragraph: The biggest leveraged buyout in history may get even bigger. abstract: A possible merger of XM Satellite Radio Holdings and its rival, Sirius Satellite Radio, snagged another believer Wednesday when a Citigroup analyst raised her price target on XM. Shares of the company made a double-digit leap Wednesday after the analyst, Eileen Furukawa, lifted her 12-month price target on the company to $21 from $16 a share, telling clients that she believed a merger between the two companies could happen before the fall.

headline.main: Satellite Radio Merger Talk Gets a Lift from Citigroup

abstract: Doom and gloom surrounded hedge funds last year as lawmakers threatened increased regulation and several high-profile players were blown out, but at least one bright spot for fans of the unregulated pools of capital has emerged. A “stellar” fourth quarter by Deephaven Capital Management will likely incresae earnings of the broker Knight Capital Group, which owns the $4 billion hedge fund firm, according to an analyst’s report.

abstract: Newspapers may have lost their luster for yet another media company. E. W. Scripps, the parent company of The Rocky Mountain News, The Commercial Appeal in Memphis and 18 other dailies, told an investor conference Wednesday that it was exploring separating its newspaper business from its more profitable cable television and syndication ventures.

abstract: A public pension fund in Louisiana has sued the directors of Caremark Rx, contending that their unanimous backing of the company’s $21 billion merger with CVS over a rival $26 billion bid from Express Scripts improperly benefits Caremark executives at the expense of shareholders.
lead_paragraph: A public pension fund in Louisiana has sued the directors of Caremark Rx, contending that their unanimous backing of the company’s $21 billion merger with CVS over a rival $26 billion bid from Express Scripts improperly benefits Caremark executives at the expense of shareholders.

headline.main: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx

abstract: In fighting off a hostile offer from one rival, it seems Delta Air Lines has been talking about linking up with another. As US Airways increased its unsolicited merger bid to $10.2 billion Wednesday, reports said that Delta has been holding talks with Northwest Airlines and United Airlines about a possible combination with either of those carriers, according to reports. Discussions between Delta and Northwest, both of which filed for bankruptcy the same day in 2005, have apparently been occurring regularly for weeks. A Northwest bid would probably be preferable to Delta managers because the two airlines’ route networks overlap less than with Delta and US Airways, leading to fewer grounded planes, if any.

headline.main: A New Focus on Delta Air as Deal Bait

abstract: Kelso and Company is investing $140 million in Global Geophysical Services in a deal that is expected to give the buyout shop a substantial minority stake in the energy services business, Moody’s Investors Service said. Global Geophysical. which also has offices in Lima, Peru, Boumerdes, Algeria, and Buenos Aires, provides hydrocarbon reservoir location services to oil and gas exploration and production companies via three-dimensional seismic-mapping services.

headline.main: Kelso Gets Global Geophysical Stake

abstract: Nimsoft, a Norwegian infrastructure software maker, raised $10.3 million from JMI Equity of San Diego and Oslo-based Northzone Ventures. The company will use the venture funding to increase sales and marketing of products in the fast-growing service-level management market.
lead_paragraph: Nimsoft, a Norwegian infrastructure software maker, raised $10.3 million from JMI Equity of San Diego and Oslo-based Northzone Ventures. The company will use the venture funding to increase sales and marketing of products in the fast-growing service-level management market.

headline.main: Software Maker Nimsoft Raises $10.3 Million

abstract: Madison Dearborn Partners has sold Peter Piper Pizza, a restaurant chain, to Acon Investments for an undisclosed price, TheDeal.com reported. Peter Piper said its annual revenue is expected to exceed $200 million in 2007.
lead_paragraph: Madison Dearborn Partners has sold Peter Piper Pizza, a restaurant chain, to Acon Investments for an undisclosed price, TheDeal.com reported. Peter Piper said its annual revenue is expected to exceed $200 million in 2007.

headline.main: Madison Dearborn Sells Pizza Chain

abstract: Contributing to a record-breaking fund-raising year in 2006, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has now closed on $16.1 billion for its newest buyout fund, according to LBO Wire. The New York-based buyout shop has yet to hold a final closing for the fund, KKR Associates 2006 Fund LP, which has a cap of $16.625 billion, the report said.
lead_paragraph: Contributing to a record-breaking fund-raising year in 2006, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has now closed on $16.1 billion for its newest buyout fund, according to LBO Wire. The New York-based buyout shop has yet to hold a final closing for the fund, KKR Associates 2006 Fund LP, which has a cap of $16.625 billion, the report said.

headline.main: Kohlberg Kravis Said to Be Near Cap in $16 Billion Fund

abstract: Ameriquest, the largest subprime mortgage lender in the United States, may be sold to a bond hedge fund as it and its competitors face an increasingly difficult business environment, reports said. J.P. Morgan Securities, which owns the lender, has approached several buyers recently, including Ellington Capital Management, a $4.5 billion fund with a specialty in hedging mortgage credit risk. Sources told The New York Post that Ellington executives have not yet decided if they want to receive an offering circular. A price has not been given.
lead_paragraph: Ameriquest, the largest subprime mortgage lender in the United States, may be sold to a bond hedge fund as it and its competitors face an increasingly difficult business environment, reports said. J.P. Morgan Securities, which owns the lender, has approached several buyers recently, including Ellington Capital Management, a $4.5 billion fund with a specialty in hedging mortgage credit risk. Sources told The New York Post that Ellington executives have not yet decided if they want to receive an offering circular. A price has not been given.

headline.main: Ameriquest Looks for Hedge-Fund Buyer, Reports Say

abstract: Just after US Airways bumped up its unsolicited bid for Delta Air Lines, AirTran Airways has applied the gas to its own efforts to acquire Midwest Air Group. AirTran, a discount airline based in Orlando, Fla., raised its bid 19 percent, to $345 million Thursday, making the offer directly to shareholders and putting pressure on Midwest Air’s management. Last month, Midwest rejected AirTran’s initial offer of $290 million as too low, and on Wednesday, the airline unveiled a plan to add routes and update its fleet to help convince shareholders it should remain independent.
lead_paragraph: Just after US Airways bumped up its unsolicited bid for Delta Air Lines, AirTran Airways has applied the gas to its own efforts to acquire Midwest Air Group. AirTran, a discount airline based in Orlando, Fla., raised its bid 19 percent, to $345 million Thursday, making the offer directly to shareholders and putting pressure on Midwest Air’s management. Last month, Midwest rejected AirTran’s initial offer of $290 million as too low, and on Wednesday, the airline unveiled a plan to add routes and update its fleet to help convince shareholders it should remain independent.

headline.main: AirTran Raises Midwest Offer to $345 Million

abstract: EMI Group is said to have sacked its recorded music chief, Alain Levy, ahead of a reorganization aimed at reviving the flagging company.
snippet: EMI Group is said to have sacked its recorded music chief, Alain Levy, ahead of a reorganization aimed at reviving the flagging company.
lead_paragraph: In an unexpected shakeup, the British music giant EMI Group has sacked its recorded music chief, Alain Levy, ahead of a broad reorganization aimed at reviving the flagging company, according to executives briefed on the plan.

headline.main: EMI Group Said to Dismiss Its Music Chief

abstract: Following on a pledge by California’s governor to increase solar-energy production, the outspoken billionaire Ted Turner has partnered with Dome-Tech Solar of New Jersey to create a solar-energy venture to address the state’s power needs. Mr. Turner and Dome Tech intend to make the venture, DT Solar, one of the biggest solar power system integrators in California. Financial terms of the venture were not disclosed, but Dome-Tech’s chief operating officer told The Los Angeles Times that Mr. Turner “won’t be a passive partner.”
lead_paragraph: Following on a pledge by California’s governor to increase solar-energy production, the outspoken billionaire Ted Turner has partnered with Dome-Tech Solar of New Jersey to create a solar-energy venture to address the state’s power needs. Mr. Turner and Dome Tech intend to make the venture, DT Solar, one of the biggest solar power system integrators in California. Financial terms of the venture were not disclosed, but Dome-Tech’s chief operating officer told The Los Angeles Times that Mr. Turner “won’t be a passive partner.”

headline.main: Turner Warms Up to Solar Venture

abstract: The management of Julius Baer‘s fixed income investment boutique in London bought the $9 billion unit, less than two years after Julius Baer bought it when it acquired the global asset management operation from UBS. The division, now Augustus Asset Managers, will continue running hedge funds for Julius Baer and intends to expand in the United States. The first task for the unit and its new nonexecutive chairman, Howard Carter, will be to right a listing ship in which its two flagship funds generated anemic returns in 2006.
lead_paragraph: The management of Julius Baer‘s fixed income investment boutique in London bought the $9 billion unit, less than two years after Julius Baer bought it when it acquired the global asset management operation from UBS. The first task for the unit and its new nonexecutive chairman, Howard Carter, will be to right a listing ship in which its two flagship funds generated anemic returns in 2006.

headline.main: Julius Baer Sells Fixed-Income Unit in M.B.O.

abstract: In a deal valued at $36 billion, quibbling over $100 million or so may seem absurd. But that is just what is happening in the background as Blackstone Group tries to acquire Equity Office Properties Trust in what would be the largest leverage buyout in history. A group of Equity Office’s bondholders, including insurance giant American International Group, say they are being shortchanged under a proposed debt buyback that would facilitate the sale. And at least one analyst points to the dispute as one of the reasons that Equity Office may be put back in play.
lead_paragraph: In a deal valued at $36 billion, quibbling over $100 million or so may seem absurd. But that is just what is happening in the background as Blackstone Group tries to acquire Equity Office Properties Trust in what would be the largest leverage buyout in history. A group of Equity Office’s bondholders, including insurance giant American International Group, say they are being shortchanged under a proposed debt buyback that would facilitate the sale. And at least one analyst points to the dispute as one of the reasons that Equity Office may be put back in play.

headline.main: Will Bondholders Play Spoiler in Blackstone Deal?

abstract: Microsoft has so far failed to fire the imagination of the buying public since the Zune digital music player’s release last fall.
snippet: Microsoft has so far failed to fire the imagination of the buying public since the Zune digital music player’s release last fall.
lead_paragraph: Despite the Redmond, Wash., giant’s famously deep pockets and well-documented commitment to the success of its first digital music player, the Zune, Microsoft has so far failed to fire the imagination of the buying public since the player’s release last fall. I overheard a litany of disparaging remarks (“It’s kinda clunky,” for example) from would-be consumers shuffling past a Zune display at the Consumer Electronics Show yesterday.

headline.main: Knock, Knock, Microsoft. It’s SanDisk

abstract: Six Flags said Thursday that it had agreed to sell seven of its amusement parks for $312 million, and the news sent its stock on quite a ride. Shares of Six Flags, which is struggling with falling attendance at its parks, surged 9 percent in late-morning trading after the deal was announced. Six Flags was the subject of a bitter proxy battle in 2005, which resulted in a former ESPN executive, Mark Shapiro, being named chief executive. Since then, the company has sought to make its parks more family-friendly and to pay down some of its debt.

Since then, the company has sought to make its parks more family-friendly and to pay down some of its debt.

headline.main: Six Flags to Sell Seven Parks

lead_paragraph: Oil prices were falling fast before President Bush added tough talk on Iran to his speech last night, in ways that had commentators wondering if a military confrontation loomed.

headline.main: Who’s Worried About Iraq?

abstract: Is Goldman Sachs being unusually careful to avoid group bids as it shops General Electric‘s plastics unit to potential buyers? PE Week Wire’s Dan Primack says no. abstract: If a substantial number of private-equity deals do not eventually “crash and burn,” it would be “a complete historical aberration,” Steve Rattner of Quadrangle Group tells Fortune magazine, offering a completely reasonable but rather dire observation for the magazine’s 2007 outlook piece. Fortune asked players such as Mr. Rattner and the Carlyle Group‘s David Rubenstein to assess where things stand. Mr. Rubenstein repeated what seems to be a favorite phrase of his, telling Fortune, as he told the Financial Times in December, that private equity is “the face of 21st-century American capitalism.”

abstract: EBay is paying a rich price for the online ticket vendor StubHub, Bear Stearns analyst Richard S. Peck suggests, writing in a research note that the deal “could be dilutive to eBay’s valuation.” His comments come as eBay is still trying to convince Wall Street that its $2.6 billion acquisition of the Internet-phone service Skype in September 2005, a deal whose final price tag could eventually hit $4.1 billion if bonuses are paid, was worth it.
lead_paragraph: EBay is paying a rich price for the online ticket vendor StubHub, Bear Stearns analyst Richard S. Peck suggests, writing in a research note that the deal “could be dilutive to eBay’s valuation.” His comments come as eBay is still trying to convince Wall Street that its $2.6 billion acquisition of the Internet-phone service Skype in September 2005, a deal whose final price tag could eventually hit $4.1 billion if bonuses are paid, was worth it.

headline.main: eBay’s Latest Deal Looks Expensive, Analyst Says

abstract: Eric Jackson is not happy that Yahoo has lost more than a third of its market value over the past year. But since he holds fewer than 1,000 shares of the Internet giant, he lacks the muscle of big-time activist shareholders such as Carl Icahn, Nelson Peltz or Ralph Whitworth, who have wrested concessions from the likes of ImClone Systems, Wendy’s International and Home Depot in recent months. Still, Mr. Jackson hopes to use the Internet to consolidate the anger of other small shareholders, attempting to become what TheStreet.com’s Vishesh Kumar describes as a “virtual activist investor.”

abstract: The Picasso painting that nearly inspired hedge fund billionaire Steven Cohen to shell out $139 million has inspired something else: a lawsuit. Casino mogul Stephen Wynn, who accidentially poked a silver-dollar-size hole in the painting shortly after agreeing to sell it to Mr. Cohen, has sued insurer Lloyd’s of London over the damaged painting, called “Le Reve.” If the deal with Mr. Cohen had gone through, it would have been the most-expensive sale of a work of art in history. (What Mr. Wynn reportedly said after discovering he had torn the painting is not fit for a family blog.)

abstract: What do business schoolers want these days? A job in private equity, apparently. But their dreams of high payouts may not come true, according to BusinessWeek, which reports that there are fewer private equity jobs out there than one might think. While many of the biggest funds will hire about 20 percent more M.B.A.’s this year, there are about five candidates for each job available, the magazine said. And the positions typically go to those with experience.

abstract: A former accountant pleaded guilty Thursday to one felony count of lying to federal investigators as part of a widening criminal inquiry into questionable tax shelters. The former accountant, Michael Grandinetti, entered his plea before Judge Thomas P. Griesa in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Mr. Grandinetti, 49, is expected to serve as a witness for the prosecution in a mammoth tax shelter case against 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG. Mr. Grandinetti, a resident of the Northern Mariana Islands, a United States territory in the Pacific, becomes the fifth person to plead guilty and agree to cooperate with prosecutors in the inquiry, which has also ensnared major accounting firms, banks, law firms and investment boutiques.

abstract: After two men won their appeal to have their convictions overturned in a case referred to as the Enron of Kansas, The New York Times takes a look at the latest in a recent series of setbacks for the government in white-collar cases. In September 2005, David C. Wittig, a former star investment banker, and his lieutenant, Douglas T. Lake, were convicted of looting the company they ran, Westar Energy of Topeka, the largest electric utility in Kansas. Mr. Wittig was sentenced to 18 years in prison, and Mr. Lake, 15 years. But last Friday, a federal appeals court overturned the convictions of the two men on all 40 counts – most of which cannot be retried.

headline.main: A Setback for Prosecutors in the ‘Enron of Kansas’ Case

abstract: The Nasdaq stock market on Thursday extended by two weeks the deadline for shareholders to accept its offer to buy the London Stock Exchange after the New York bourse got a tepid response. The Nasdaq bid for the London exchange was to have ended Thursday, but it said the new deadline would be Jan. 26. The Nasdaq, which is offering 12.43 pounds ($24.22) a share for the London exchange, said it had received acceptances from investors holding 0.61 percent of the exchange’s shares outstanding.
