abstract: National CineMedia, the advertising network for theater chain operators, on Thursday outlined plans to offer 38 million shares at $18 to $20 apiece in a bid to raise about $722 million in its initial public offering. The planned I.P.O. raises the number of offerings set to kick off in the $500 million to $1 billion range, joining theater chain AMC Entertainment, Time Warner Cable and MetroPCS, a wireless broadband provider. The I.P.O. backlog in the United States stands at a healthy level of 104 deals expected to raise $16 billion, down from 106 deals expected to raise $17.4 billion in the year-ago period, according to Dealogic.

abstract: CVC Asia Pacific and Macquarie Bank may offer to buy the Sino-Forest Corporation, the largest foreign-owned lumber company in China, according to Bloomberg News. An acquisition of Sino-Forest, which has a market capitalization of $1 billion, would give the buyout firms control of a wood-products maker that increased sales 34 percent annually between 1994 and 2005. Shares in Sino-Forest, which is based in Toronto, are poised for the biggest weekly gain since September 2005.

headline.main: CVC and Macquarie Said to Eye Chinese Lumber Firm

abstract: Whether you’re among those who believe that hedge funds are Satan (much of the news media and the Connecticut attorney general) or savior (hedge fund employees and investors), it looks like they’re here to stay, writes The New York Times’s Jenny Anderson. The money continues to flow into hedge funds. Hedge Fund Research, a Chicago-based research firm, estimates that $110 billion flowed into new funds through November. A study released by Deutsche Bank yesterday surveyed investors who represent $900 billion of the total $1.4 trillion in the industry and predicted that $110 billion will flow into the sector in 2007.

abstract: The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb brings to mind that vacant colonial for sale down the street. In real estate parlance, both are expensive and might seem to need too much tender loving care. The company’s leaders all but announced it was for sale last September. Four months later, though, no potential suitor has emerged – at least not publicly. Instead, Bristol-Myers has entered several comparatively small deals, including one yesterday in which it announced a $1.35 billion partnership with the British company AstraZeneca to develop two diabetes compounds.

abstract: Spurred on by Warren E. Buffett’s June announcement that he would hand most of his $40 billion fortune to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, philanthropy is increasingly attracting cash infusions from hedge fund managers, real estate moguls and technology entrepreneurs, Bloomberg News reports. And this year, Wall Street bankers and traders sharing more than $36 billion in bonuses may help drive the donations up even more.

abstract: Real life may have taken a cue from “Mission: Impossible,” albeit a little too late for those like one-time investment banking star Frank Quattrone who found themselves in hot water over undeleted e-mails. The New York Post writes of new e-mail that self-destructs in just seconds, with no traces left. The vanishing text and video are the brainchild of a small e-mail provider, BigString of Redbank, N.J., founded a year ago by a former Wall Street dot-com trader and several dot-com survivors from the late 1990’s. Data can be timed to vanish after just three readings, for example, or in just 30 seconds or as long as several weeks or more.

abstract: Zebra Technologies said Thursday it had agreed to buy WhereNet, bolstering its position in an up-and-coming technology known as radio frequency identification. Zebra, which primarily makes printers that spit out bar code labels, will pay $126 million in cash for the privately-held WhereNet, based in Santa Clara, Calif. Analysts believe that radio frequency identification — RFID for the cognoscente — will one day supplant bar code technology in supply chain tracking.

abstract: An unidentified institutional shareholder last night sold 1.02 billion Hong Kong dollars ($131 million) worth of shares in Esprit Holdings, the second placement in the fashion retailer in less than four months. The sale came on a day when Esprit’s share price turned higher again after six days of mainly declines and could suggest that more shareholders are getting nervous about the current weakness in the market and are taking the opportunity to secure some profit on days of strength.

abstract: The former chairman of Tyco International, Dennis Kozlowski, returned to prison Thursday after being hospitalized, according to a prison spokeswoman. Mr. Kozlowski is currently being housed in the Mid-State Correctional Facility’s infirmary in New York, after being treated for an undisclosed ailment. Mr. Kozlowksi is serving a sentence of 8-1/3 to 25 years after being found guilty in June 2005 of looting the company.

abstract: In an unexpected shake-up, the British music giant EMI Group has fired its chief of recorded music, Alain Levy, ahead of a broad reorganization aimed at reviving the flagging company. The sudden move, announced Friday, follows a series of setbacks at EMI, including a string of failed merger negotiations with a rival, the Warner Music Group, and the poor sales performance of the pop star Janet Jackson.

McCormack, and is running it like a profit-driven, even obsessed, property.

abstract: Marsh & McLennan‘s chief executive, Michael Cherkasky, will look to acquisitions to help the financial-services company grow in 2007 as it tries to recover from an aggressive investigation by the former New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer. The company is looking to go to market after completing a possible $3.9 billion sale of its Putnam Investments unit to the Power Corporation of Canada, The Telegraph reported. “Our first priority is growth as opposed to a share buy-back,” Mr Cherkasky told the paper.

abstract: The German drugmaker Merck KGaA has attracted interest in its generic drugs unit from Cinven, Permira and the Texas Pacific Group, people familiar with the matter told Reuters. Merck — no relation to the United States company of the same name — said last week it was considering selling the business, valued at more than 4 billion euros ($5.2 billion), as it retrains its focus on higher-revenue branded products. Merck declined to comment, as did Permira and Cinven, while Texas Pacific was not available to comment, Reuters said.

abstract: Cablevision Systems‘s controlling family, the Dolans, said Friday that they had raised their offer to buy out the public shareholders of their cable television empire to $30 per share in cash, up from the $27-per-share cash offer they presented in October. In a press release, the family said their latest proposal valued Cablevision’s equity at $8.9 billion and implied a total entreprise value of $20.1 billion. The Dolans said the bid was their “best and final offer” and would expire on Jan. 17.

abstract: The Investment bank Evercore Partners said Friday it had hired James Matthews as a senior managing director to co-lead its private equity business, which makes investments in midsize companies. He will oversee the group alongside the senior managing director Neeraj Mital. Mr. Matthews, previously a general partner at the private equity firm Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe, will bring expertise in the business-services and “mature technology” sectors, Evercore’s co-chief executive, Austin Beutner, said in a news release.

abstract: At least one of the Blackstone Group‘s headaches seems to have gone away. Late Thursday, dissident bondholders of Equity Office Properties Trust relented and said they would accept the company’s debt buyback, part of Blackstone’s $36 billion buyout of the trust. The bondholders, including the insurance giant American International Group, said that they would accept a revised offer by the Jan. 18 deadline, even though it fell short of their initial demands.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 — Johnnie M. Burton, who runs the Interior Department’s troubled program to collect royalties on oil and gas pumped on public lands, is under attack and out of sight.

abstract: Flexible electronic circuits could make it routine to modify the circuitry in consumer products even after they have been sold.
snippet: Flexible electronic circuits could make it routine to modify the circuitry in consumer products even after they have been sold.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 — Hewlett-Packard researchers have developed a novel way to create flexible electronic circuits that could make it routine by the end of the decade to modify and upgrade the circuitry in computer-based consumer products even after they have been sold.

abstract: The first extension of the Registered Traveler program beyond Orlando, Fla., is scheduled to start today at Terminal 7 at Kennedy International Airport as the expedited security program begins nationally.
snippet: The first extension of the Registered Traveler program beyond Orlando, Fla., is scheduled to start today at Terminal 7 at Kennedy International Airport as the expedited security program begins nationally.
lead_paragraph: REGISTERED TRAVEL AT KENNEDY  The first extension of the Registered Traveler program beyond Orlando, Fla., is scheduled to start today at Terminal 7 at Kennedy International Airport as the expedited security program begins nationally. The program at Kennedy is being operated by Verified Identity Pass under the brand name Clear, in a marketing partnership with British Airways. A Clear program has been in operation at Orlando International Airport since July 2005. Clear is also taking enrollments for airports in Indianapolis, Cincinnati and San Jose, Calif. The program costs $99.95 a year (including a $30 federal fee) and requires a federal background check. Competitors, among them Unisys, are expected to begin operating their own programs later this year.

headline.main: Memo Pad

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Jan. 15 — When BP announced a landmark investment of $6.15 billion in Russia in 2003, the event was celebrated with a healthy dose of British pomp and circumstance.

abstract: You can’t eat on the Web, but you can follow the clues online to find directions to a good dinner away from home.
snippet: You can’t eat on the Web, but you can follow the clues online to find directions to a good dinner away from home.
lead_paragraph: Provide a slight prompt for Clark Troy, and he will reminisce about the best diver scallops he has ever had. Succulent, smooth, tender and luscious are words he uses, and his voice holds a certain tone of awe. He can manage similar enthusiasm for a fine steak he once ate.

abstract: When BP, the oil and gas giant, announced a landmark investment of $6.15 billion in Russia in 2003, the event was celebrated with a healthy dose of British pomp and circumstance. But TNK-BP, as the venture is known, has already suffered many setbacks, and now BP may be forced to cede some control over the venture, as the Russian government steps up control of its natural resources.

abstract: General Electric said Monday that it would pay $4.8 billion for Smiths Aerospace, the cockpit electronics arm of the London conglomerate Smiths Group. The two companies said they would pool their technologies for detecting bombs, chemicals and other dangerous items into a joint venture, Smiths GE Detection.

abstract: AOL said Monday that it had agreed to buy TradeDoubler, a Swedish company that matches Internet advertisers with online media owners and e-commerce sites, as AOL tries to grab a bigger share of the booming global market in Internet advertising. The deal, at 6.3 billion Swedish kronor, or $900 million, would be AOL’s first major acquisition since Randy Falco was named chief executive in November, after the company’s shift to a free, advertiser-supported portal from a subscriber-based service.

abstract: The Liverpool soccer club is close to accepting an $882 million takeover offer from a consortium led by the ruler of Dubai, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum. Sheik Mohammed owns Dubai International Capital, which has been examining the club’s finances for the last month. “A huge amount of work has been going on from both parts. I imagine we’ll have something concrete to say relatively soon on that,” the soccer club’s chief executive, Rick Parry, told BBC radio on Sunday.

I imagine we’ll have something concrete to say relatively soon on that,” the soccer club’s chief executive, Rick Parry, told BBC radio on Sunday.

headline.main: Liverpool Team Close to Deal With a Sheik

abstract: By relying on money from Goldman Sachs to do a deal, the chief executive of the media giant Canwest is directly challenging Canadian laws banning the foreign control of broadcasters.
snippet: By relying on money from Goldman Sachs to do a deal, the chief executive of the media giant Canwest is directly challenging Canadian laws banning the foreign control of broadcasters.
lead_paragraph: Leonard J. Asper is part of the best-known family in the Canadian media and one of its most aggressive. The chief executive of CanWest Global Communications, a leading broadcaster and newspaper publisher, Mr. Asper has just concluded the acquisition of Alliance Atlantis Communications, best known in the United States as the creator of “CSI: Crime Scene Investigation” and in Canada for its lucrative specialty cable channels, for 2.3 billion Canadian dollars. But, The New York Times wonders, have the Aspers picked one fight too many?

headline.main: With a U.S. Partner, First Family of Canadian Media Tests Ownership Rules

abstract: Bertelsmann, the privately owned media company, is expected to name its new chief executive in the next few days, and Hartmut Ostrowski, the sober son of a North Westphalian plumber whose favorite corporate dictums run the range from “Just do it!” and “Keep it simple!” to “Put your fish on the table,” is thought to be front-runner for the post.

headline.main: Bertelsmann Is Days Away from Naming a New Chief

abstract: John Browne, chief executive of BP, will become chairman of the advisory board of the private equity firm Apax Partners when he leaves the oil company in July. Mr. Browne told BP executives on Friday of his plans, which would make him one of the biggest names in a new trend of globalism sweeping the private equity industry. His years presiding over an international company are likely to help Apax’s expansion plans.

His years presiding over an international company are likely to help Apax’s expansion plans.

abstract: Being a chief executive has many perks, but job security is not one of them, especially now. A record total of 1,478 chief executive departures were announced last year at United States-based companies, 12 percent more than in 2005. Health care companies had the highest turnover of chiefs, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm. Computer companies were second, and financial firms, affected by heavy merger activity last year, were third.

Computer companies were second, and financial firms, affected by heavy merger activity last year, were third.

headline.main: For Top Executives, a Need to Be Aware of the Nearest Exit

abstract: In a Q&A in The New York Times, William J. Holstein, editor in chief of Directorship magazine, discusses current trends in private equity buyouts with Justin B. Wender, president of Castle Harlan, a private equity firm in New York that specializes in retailing and restaurants. Among the points covered, Mr. Wender addresses the complaint that big take-private deals make money for the private equity owners and fleece the average shareholder. He rejects the notion, calling it “apples-to-oranges analysis.”

headline.main: Defending the Big Buyout

abstract: Federal prosecutors scored their first victory in the investigation of boardroom spying at Hewlett-Packard on Friday, when a private investigator pleaded guilty to identity theft and conspiracy charges. The investigator, Bryan Wagner, 29, of Littleton, Colo., pleaded guilty to the two felony counts during his initial appearance in United States District Court in San Jose.

abstract: A Philadelphia private equity firm, Chrysalis Capital Partners, said it made an offer to buy and operate Malden Mills Industries, a textile maker, on terms “similar” to the $44 million sale the company said last week it had arranged with Gordon Brothers Group of Boston. Malden Mills, which is based in Lawrence, Mass., and makes Polartec cold-weather fabrics, filed for bankruptcy protection on last week and said it would be sold to Gordon Brothers for $44 million.

abstract: In the latest example of hedge fund activism, the largest shareholder in the struggling chip equipment maker Ultratech has called for management to bolster sales or consider selling the company. In a letter filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, a New York-based hedge fund, Thales Fund Management, called Ultratech undervalued and suggested management put the company up for sale if it cannot increase its share price this year.

abstract: A French court on Monday approved a multibillion-dollar restructuring plan for Eurotunnel, making way for the debt-burdened operator of the undersea rail link to emerge from bankruptcy-law protection. “This opens a new episode for the company,” said Judge Perrette Rey, president of the Paris Commercial Court, who gave management three years to implement a plan that aims to slash Eurotunnel’s 6.2 billion pounds, or $12.1 billion, of arrears by more than half.
lead_paragraph: A French court on Monday approved a multibillion-dollar restructuring plan for Eurotunnel, making way for the debt-burdened operator of the undersea rail link to emerge from bankruptcy-law protection. “This opens a new episode for the company,” said Judge Perrette Rey, president of the Paris Commercial Court, who gave management three years to implement a plan that aims to slash Eurotunnel’s 6.2 billion pounds, or $12.1 billion, of arrears by more than half.

headline.main: French Court Approves Eurotunnel Restructuring Plan

abstract: In a blow to the hedge fund Highland Capital Management, a federal bankruptcy judge approved a complex equity plan for Delphi that will inject up to $3.4 billion into the auto-parts supplier. The Judge, Robert Drain, called it a “watershed event” on Friday as he approved a framework for approaching the remaining issues in the company’s reorganization.

headline.main: Judge Approves Delphi Equity Deal

abstract: Indian state-owned Power Finance has confirmed its intention to raise up to $225 million from the first sizable initial public offering in the Indian market this year. The announcement came as the Mumbai benchmark index closed at a record high after it finished above 14,000 points for the first time on Friday. Power Finance, which provides financing for Indian power and infrastructure projects within both the public and private sectors, will sell 117.3 million new shares at a price between 73 rupees and 85 rupees apiece.

Power Finance, which provides financing for Indian power and infrastructure projects within both the public and private sectors, will sell 117.3 million new shares at a price between 73 rupees and 85 rupees apiece.

headline.main: India’s Power Finance Plans I.P.O.

abstract: Blackstone Ventures is buying Xstrata Nickel‘s interest in three Norway exploration projects for $15.5 million. The deal will give Blackstone all the outstanding shares of a joint venture partner and Xstrata subsidiary, Sulfidmalm, as well as full control of the Norwegian projects.
lead_paragraph: Blackstone Ventures is buying Xstrata Nickel‘s interest in three Norway exploration projects for $15.5 million. The deal will give Blackstone all the outstanding shares of a joint venture partner and Xstrata subsidiary, Sulfidmalm, as well as full control of the Norwegian projects.

headline.main: Blackstone Buys Xstrata Stake in Exploration Projects

abstract: The London Stock Exchange is in talks about its future with its second-largest shareholder, the investor Samuel Heyman, according to The Observer. An exchange spokesman confirmed for the first time that the exchange was in “ongoing discussions” with Mr. Heyman, who owns 10.07 percent of the shares, the report said. The newspaper said that Mr. Heyman may be trying to broker a deal to sell the exchange to Nasdaq, which holds a stake of more than 28 percent and began a 2.7 billion pound ($5.2 billion) hostile bid for the the London exchange in December.

headline.main: U.S. Investor May Be Brokering L.S.E. Deal, Report Says

abstract: The Italian fashion house Prada confirmed on Monday it could consider an initial public offering of its shares next year and said sales in 2006 probably rose 10 percent. “At this point, based on where we are it would make sense to go for an I.P.O. at some point, maybe next year,” a spokesman, Tomaso Galli, told Reuters after the company’s menswear fashion show. “We are reaching all our targets. So obviously we can now look at a potential I.P.O.,” he said. The chief executive, Patrizio Bertelli, said in November that the company could look again at a listing in 2008 but not in 2007.

So obviously we can now look at a potential I.P.O.,” he said. The chief executive, Patrizio Bertelli, said in November that the company could look again at a listing in 2008 but not in 2007.

headline.main: Prada Thinks an I.P.O. May Be in Fashion

abstract: Canadian regulators will require fund managers to be registered with provincial securities commissions as part of a multi-pronged project to improve oversight of the hedge fund sector. The Canadian Securities Administrators, an umbrella group for provincial securities commissions, said Thursday that it would introduce new registration requirements for fund managers in an effort to ensure they have appropriate capital and insurance, and have sufficient experience and proficiency to carry out their duties.
lead_paragraph: Canadian regulators will require fund managers to be registered with provincial securities commissions as part of a multi-pronged project to improve oversight of the hedge fund sector. The Canadian Securities Administrators, an umbrella group for provincial securities commissions, said Thursday that it would introduce new registration requirements for fund managers in an effort to ensure they have appropriate capital and insurance, and have sufficient experience and proficiency to carry out their duties.

headline.main: Canadian Hedge Fund Managers Will Be Required to Register

abstract: The founders of Skype and Kazaa, Janus Friis and Niklas Zennstrom, have chosen a name for their new online-video start-up: Joost. The start-up had been dubbed “The Venice Project” by company executives before the the duo came up with the name, which they apparently chose because they liked the ring of it. Joost plans to offer studios, cable stations and anyone else who wants to distribute high-quality video over the Internet, a fast, efficient and cheap distribution method. The site will rely on the peer-to-peer technology that helped Mr. Friis and Mr. Zennstrom build Skype and Kazaa, in an effort to compete in the increasingly crowded online video market.

headline.main: Skype Founders Start a YouTube Rival

abstract: Hong Kong and Shanghai are locked in an increasingly public struggle to become China’s main financial center as a top-level committee in the capital, Beijing, prepares to meet later this month to map out a national financial regulatory strategy. On Monday, Hong Kong’s highest government leaders and best-known business tycoons made the city’s case at a series of televised conferences and briefings. They called for China to continue letting the biggest state-owned companies make their initial public offerings in the former British colony, allow the Chinese currency, the yuan, to circulate more widely here and dismantle many remaining financial barriers between the mainland and Hong Kong.

abstract: Citigroup, the global banking giant, is shrinking – but only its name. Executives are prepared to rebrand the company “Citi” and to fold up its familiar red umbrella and instead use a logo with a stylized arc above the name. The new name and look will be presented to the Citigroup board this week following a 14-month review of the bank’s brand, according to The New York Times.

headline.main: Just ‘Citi’ as the Brand, and a Folded Umbrella

abstract: Bank of America has begun a push to raise a regulatory cap that bars any bank in the United States from an acquisition that would give it more than 10 percent of the nation’s total bank deposits, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. The company has argued that United States banks are artificially small and vulnerable to foreign acquirers, the Journal said. It said the bank last year won support for changing the policy in votes before the North Carolina Bankers Association and the New Hampshire Bankers Association. Bank of America has also approached bankers in Massachusetts and other states to support potential legislation this spring in Congress, the Journal reported.

It said the bank last year won support for changing the policy in votes before the North Carolina Bankers Association and the New Hampshire Bankers Association. Bank of America has also approached bankers in Massachusetts and other states to support potential legislation this spring in Congress, the Journal reported.

headline.main: BofA Seeks a Lift on Deposit Caps

abstract: When hostile takeover bids rear their heads, some chief executives declare fiercely that they’re not interested. From Gerald Grinstein of Delta Air Lines to Edwin Crawford of Caremark Rx, these chief executives insist that their suitors take a hike. But the problem, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin in his Sunday DealBook column, is that they may not be telling the truth — and that they’re simply looking to up the ante. Read on to find out more.
lead_paragraph: When hostile takeover bids rear their heads, some chief executives declare fiercely that they’re not interested. But the problem, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin in his Sunday DealBook column, is that they may not be telling the truth — and that they’re simply looking to up the ante. Read on to find out more.

headline.main: Commentary: In Takeovers, Truth Can Be the First Casualty

abstract: The ouster of EMI Music‘s chairman and chief executive, Alain Levy, is seen by many analysts as a precursor to a radical reorganization of the British music company and a new drive to explore a sale or merger. The label, which counts Norah Jones and Coldplay (left) among its ranks, announced on Friday the dismissal of the music unit’s top two executives, Mr. Levy and David Munns, vice chairman. Their responsibilities will be taken on by Eric L. Nicoli, the chief executive of the EMI Group.
lead_paragraph: The ouster of EMI Music‘s chairman and chief executive, Alain Levy, is seen by many analysts as a precursor to a radical reorganization of the British music company and a new drive to explore a sale or merger. Their responsibilities will be taken on by Eric L. Nicoli, the chief executive of the EMI Group.

headline.main: With Ousters, EMI Group Is Said to Be Packaging Itself for Sale

abstract: Mirant will sell six natural gas-fired power plants to LS Power Equity Partners, an asset management company, for $1.4 billion, the energy said Tuesday. After accounting for project-level debt, Mirant will reap about $1.3 billion, money that it said it would reinvest in other projects or return to shareholders. Mirant was advised by J.P. Morgan Securities and King & Spalding, while LS Power Equity was advised by Barclays Capital and Latham & Watkins.

Morgan Securities and King & Spalding, while LS Power Equity was advised by Barclays Capital and Latham & Watkins.

headline.main: Mirant to Sell Six Natural Gas Plants for $1.4 Billion

abstract: The board of Cablevision rejected an $8.9 billion offer to sell the company to the Dolans, its founding family.

abstract: Express Scripts began a $24.8 billion offer for all outstanding shares of Caremark Rx on Tuesday. The move is the latest step in a high-stakes takeover battle after Caremark said last week that it preferred a lower $23.3 billion deal with the drugstore chain CVS. Express Scripts is offering Caremark shareholders $29.25 in cash and 0.426 shares of Express Scripts stock for each Caremark share.
lead_paragraph: Express Scripts began a $24.8 billion offer for all outstanding shares of Caremark Rx on Tuesday. Express Scripts is offering Caremark shareholders $29.25 in cash and 0.426 shares of Express Scripts stock for each Caremark share.

headline.main: Express Scripts Begins $24.8 Billion Offer for Caremark Shares

abstract: In an effort to focus on higher-growth wireless and Internet offerings, Verizon Communications will spin off $2.72 billion in landline businesses in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont, merging them with FairPoint Communications. Verizon shareholders will own 60 percent of the new company, which will have 1.6 million local lines, 234,000 high-speed Internet subscribers and 600,000 customers. Verizon will also shed $1.7 billion in debt in the spinoff.

abstract: In its quest to acquire the Swedish Internet ad broker TradeDoubler for $900 million, Time Warner‘s AOL may have run into a formidable hurdle. Shortly after the deal was announced Monday, a large TradeDoubler shareholder balked, criticizing the board-approved takeover as too low. Alecta, a Swedish pension group, says it holds a 10.1 percent stake in the company, a position that both AOL and TradeDoubler admitted amounted to a blocking stake under the deal’s provisions.
lead_paragraph: In its quest to acquire the Swedish Internet ad broker TradeDoubler for $900 million, Time Warner‘s AOL may have run into a formidable hurdle. Alecta, a Swedish pension group, says it holds a 10.1 percent stake in the company, a position that both AOL and TradeDoubler admitted amounted to a blocking stake under the deal’s provisions.

headline.main: Pension Group May Throw Wrench into AOL’s Swedish Deal

abstract: Is Kenneth Langone “Patient Zero” — the primary carrier of a malady that makes corporate boards feverishly inflate executive pay? At the least, he is what The New Yorker’s James Surowiecki dubs a “supercarrier,” given his track record, which includes that of the recently ousted Home Depot head, Robert L. Nardelli. And abetting Mr. Langone is the clubby world of corporate boards, an increasingly interconnected social network where directors and executives tend to scratch each other’s back.
lead_paragraph: Is Kenneth Langone “Patient Zero” — the primary carrier of a malady that makes corporate boards feverishly inflate executive pay? And abetting Mr. Langone is the clubby world of corporate boards, an increasingly interconnected social network where directors and executives tend to scratch each other’s back.

headline.main: How Rising C.E.O. Pay Spreads

abstract: Genesis HealthCare, a nursing home operator, said Tuesday it would be acquired by a consortium of private equity firms for about $1.25 billion. The joint venture, which includes affiliates from Formation Capital and JER Partners, will pay $63 a share (a premium of about 31 percent over Genesis shares’ average closing price over the past 30 trading days) and assume $450 million in debt.

abstract: One could almost imagine the story of Roger C. Altman set to the soundtrack of “Rudy” or “Field of Dreams.” As written by Investment Dealers’ Digest, his is a tale of setbacks — a heart transplant and a tenure in the Clinton administration cut short by Whitewater — overcome by courage and savvy. Now Mr. Altman is known as the chief of the boutique investment bank Evercore Partners, a man smart enough to have advised on AT&T‘s $90 billion acquisition of BellSouth, humble enough to have refused naming his firm after himself. (He makes sure to point the latter out.)

(He makes sure to point the latter out.)

headline.main: Evercore’s Secret to Getting Big? Staying Small

abstract: Another day, another near-record private equity fund. This time, it is Washington’s Carlyle Group, which said Tuesday that it has raised 2.4 billion euros ($3.1 billion) for its latest European buyout pool. If it maintains that pace — the private equity firm said in a regulatory filing earlier this month that it aims to raise $5.9 billion for Carlyle European Partners III — it could beat Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘ 4.5 billion euro fund from last year. As Bloomberg News reported, European buyouts rose to a record $200 billion last year, versus $120 billion in 2005.
lead_paragraph: Another day, another near-record private equity fund. This time, it is Washington’s Carlyle Group, which said Tuesday that it has raised 2.4 billion euros ($3.1 billion) for its latest European buyout pool. If it maintains that pace — the private equity firm said in a regulatory filing earlier this month that it aims to raise $5.9 billion for Carlyle European Partners III — it could beat Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘ 4.5 billion euro fund from last year. As Bloomberg News reported, European buyouts rose to a record $200 billion last year, versus $120 billion in 2005.

headline.main: Carlyle Raises $3.1 Billion for European Fund

abstract: Fighting back against a higher $24.8 billion offer from Express Scripts, CVS said Tuesday afternoon that it would pay Caremark Rx holders a special $2 a share dividend. The one-time move is an effort by the drugstore chain to shore up its $23.3 billion offer for the prescription benefits manager, as Express Scripts launched its tender offer for Caremark shares. Caremark’s board has said it favors the CVS offer despite its lower valuation, citing antitrust concerns in a merger with Express Scripts.
lead_paragraph: Fighting back against a higher $24.8 billion offer from Express Scripts, CVS said Tuesday afternoon that it would pay Caremark Rx holders a special $2 a share dividend. The one-time move is an effort by the drugstore chain to shore up its $23.3 billion offer for the prescription benefits manager, as Express Scripts launched its tender offer for Caremark shares. Caremark’s board has said it favors the CVS offer despite its lower valuation, citing antitrust concerns in a merger with Express Scripts.

headline.main: CVS Sweetens Caremark Deal with $2 a Share Dividend

But a few months later, city planners proposed rezoning the site, which is known as the Bay Parkade. lead_paragraph: The human mind isn’t very well equipped to make sense of a figure like $1.2 trillion. We don’t deal with a trillion of anything in our daily lives, and so when we come across such a big number, it is hard to distinguish it from any other big number. Millions, billions, a trillion — they all start to sound the same.

abstract: The EMI Group, which lost a copyright infringement lawsuit against Baidu.com, a Chinese Internet search site, will drop its appeal of the case and work with the company to win advertising by offering free online samples of its music. Baidu, based in Beijing, will sell online ads for a section of its Web site featuring streaming samples of EMI’s Chinese-language music, the company said. EMI and Baidu will share the ad revenue, they said, without providing details. EMI is planning to drop out of an infringement lawsuit brought against Baidu by record companies on claims the Web site violated copyright by offering links to illegally copied music on nonaffiliated sites.

abstract: German investor confidence rose more than forecast, reaching a six-month high in January, despite a higher sales tax and a slowdown in export markets. The index of investor and analyst expectations for economic growth in six months, compiled by the ZEW Center for European Economic Research, rose to minus 3.6 from minus 19 in December. The report adds to signs that cooling growth in the German economy may be limited even after the country raised the value-added tax, a sales tax, to 19 percent from 16 percent. The confidence indicator has shown a negative reading, with pessimists outnumbering optimists, in every month since August.

abstract: Commerce Bancorp, which calls itself “America’s most convenient bank,” rattled investors Tuesday after it disclosed that federal regulators were investigating the bank’s real estate deals with executives. Shares of Commerce fell 8.3 percent, or $2.89, to $31.83, after the bank said the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve were conducting an inquiry. Commerce has become one of the fastest-growing banks in the nation, thanks in part to its extended branch hours, and has made an aggressive and successful push into New York’s crowded banking market. Commerce, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., said, “The scope of the investigation will include but not be limited to transactions with its officers, directors and related parties, including transactions involving bank premises.”
lead_paragraph: Commerce Bancorp, which calls itself “America’s most convenient bank,” rattled investors Tuesday after it disclosed that federal regulators were investigating the bank’s real estate deals with executives. Shares of Commerce fell 8.3 percent, or $2.89, to $31.83, after the bank said the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve were conducting an inquiry. Commerce has become one of the fastest-growing banks in the nation, thanks in part to its extended branch hours, and has made an aggressive and successful push into New York’s crowded banking market. Commerce, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., said, “The scope of the investigation will include but not be limited to transactions with its officers, directors and related parties, including transactions involving bank premises.”

headline.main: Regulators Are Examining Commerce Bank

abstract: Carl C. Icahn is at it again. The billionaire investor has set his activist sights on two new targets, building stakes in the companies because he believes the shares are undervalued. Mr. Icahn now has a 14.57 percent stake in WCI Communities, a developer of housing in Florida, and has increased his holdings in Telik, an unprofitable developer of cancer and diabetes drugs, to 9.92 percent.

abstract: A former owner of Refco, the commodities brokerage firm, was charged Tuesday in a fraud that cost investors more than $1 billion in losses, prosecutors said as they also added charges against the former chief executive and chief financial officers of the firm. Tone N. Grant, 62, of Chicago, a former owner of Refco, was charged with bank fraud and money laundering along with the former chief executive, Phillip R. Bennett, 58, of Gladstone, N.J., and the former finance chief, Robert C. Trosten, 37, of Sarasota, Fla.

abstract: The buyout unit of Goldman Sachs has agreed to acquire the insurance brokerage firm USI Holdings for about $1.4 billion including debt. The Goldman unit, GS Capital Partners, will pay $17 a share, USI said Tuesday. The offer represents a 21 percent premium over the average closing share price in the 30 days before Oct. 24, the day USI announced that it had formed a committee to review a possible takeover. USI is based in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

abstract: The former general counsel at Computer Associates, Steven Woghin, was sentenced on Tuesday to two years in prison for his role in a scheme to increase the software maker’s quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts, prosecutors said. At a hearing in Brooklyn, Judge I. Leo Glasser of Federal District Court also sentenced Mr. Woghin to three years of supervised release. Several former executives at the company, now known as CA, including the former chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, have pleaded guilty to criminal charges.

abstract: A former Millennium Partners mutual fund trader who pleaded guilty to improper trading in 2003 avoided a prison term after cooperating with a New York State investigation of the mutual fund industry. The former trader, Steven Markovitz, 44, was sentenced to five years’ probation Tuesday after pleading guilty to violating New York’s General Business Law, a felony, by trading in mutual funds from late 2001 to July 2003 after markets had closed.

abstract: Two founders of a company that processes Internet gambling transactions were arrested and charged with laundering billions of dollars in gambling proceeds, federal prosecutors announced Tuesday. The charges were filed against John David Lefebvre, 55, and Stephen Eric Lawrence, 46, who founded the company, Neteller, in 1999, in two criminal complaints unsealed in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Monday, Michael J. Garcia, a United States attorney, said in a statement.

abstract: General Motors has been in talks with Proton Holdings, the Malaysian carmaker that is looking to sell a stake, G.M.’s chief executive, Rick Wagoner, said Tuesday night. “There have been conversations, not extensive,” Wagoner told reporters after a speech in Dearborn, Mich., last night. “It’s very early to handicap the potential outcome.” G.M. is interested in Proton because it is underrepresented in Malaysia, Southeast Asia’s largest auto market. G.M., the world’s largest automaker, is focusing growth on 11 emerging markets, including Malaysia, India and China, as its domestic sales shrink, Mr. Wagoner said.

abstract: Landry’s Restaurants said Tuesday that it had made a $64.4 million offer to buy the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, whose original steakhouse is a New York City institution and a favorite of the likes of Warren Buffett. Smith & Wollensky, whose shares soared 45 percent, to $7.29, said it had formed a special committee to review the $7.50 per share offer. Shares of Landry’s, which operates the Landry’s Seafood House, Chart House and Rainforest Cafe restaurants, also got a boost, rising more than 2.5 percent to $31. The Smith & Wollensky Group operates its namesake steakhouses as well as Maloney & Porcelli, Post House, Park Avenue Cafe and Quality Meats.

abstract: Norwest Venture Partners has invested $20 million in India-focused Adventity, which provides high-end research and analytics to the investment banking, mortgage and financial services industries. The investment closes the second round of financing for Adventity and marks the first funding received from an institutional source. Based in New York, most of Adventity’s operations are in India. With more than 2,000 employees, Adventity serves several global investment banks, management consulting firms and some of the largest hedge funds. The funding is one of several investments by Norwest in second-generation services, or business processes that are not traditionally outsourced.

abstract: Going head-to-head with Microsoft is a risky business strategy, but investors in a mail server technology developer, PostPath are confident enough to give the company an additional $15 million. The Series C financing for PostPath closed in late December and was led by a new investor, Jafco Ventures. Two previous investors Matrix Partners and Worldview Technology Partners also participated in the financing, which brings the company’s total funding to $30 million. PostPath has developed a Linux-based exchange server that integrates fully with Microsoft’s own Exchange server.

abstract: The Chinese search engine Baidu.com and EMI Music are teaming up in an Internet venture that will let users listen to streaming music free, adding to Baidu’s growing entertainment business. Under the terms of the the venture, announced Tuesday, EMI will make its Chinese pop music available on Baidu’s Web site. Baidu, which has more than 60 percent of China’s online search market, has been expanding entertainment offerings in an effort to compete with Web sites that combine search with entertainment and games, financial analysts say.

abstract: The Memphis Grizzlies are back on the block after a deadline passed for a group led by a former Duke University player, Brian Davis, to assemble a $252 million deal. The window for the Grizzlies Acquisition Holdings, Mr. Davis’s acquisition vehicle, to negotiate exclusively for the 70 percent stake owned by a Chicago billionaire, Michael Heisley, expired on Monday. Mr. Heisley, a turnaround specialist , told the Memphis Commercial Appeal that the team is still for sale — to Davis, to the team’s local minority-share investors or to someone else making an “acceptable” offer for the team, which has the NBA’S worst record. ‘He wasn’t able to get all of his financing together,’ Mr. Heisley told The Deal. ‘He was able to get some of it. If Mr. Davis comes up with the money, we’ll sell him the team.’

If Mr. Davis comes up with the money, we’ll sell him the team.’

headline.main: Time Runs Out on Bid for N.B.A.’s Grizzlies

abstract: A Spanish court lifted the final injunction Tuesday to an offer by the German utility E.ON for Endesa of Spain, a potentially groundbreaking merger that has become one of Europe’s longest-running takeover battles. The court’s decision allows E.ON to move forward with its 36.5 billion euro, or $47.1 billion, bid for Endesa, which is also being pursued by Gas Natural, another Spanish energy concern. That combination is backed by the Spanish government, which would like to see the creation of a national energy champion. Meanwhile, a Spanish building conglomerate, Acciona, has also steadily built up a 21 percent stake in Endesa, but it has not moved to secure full control.
lead_paragraph: A Spanish court lifted the final injunction Tuesday to an offer by the German utility E.ON for Endesa of Spain, a potentially groundbreaking merger that has become one of Europe’s longest-running takeover battles. That combination is backed by the Spanish government, which would like to see the creation of a national energy champion. Meanwhile, a Spanish building conglomerate, Acciona, has also steadily built up a 21 percent stake in Endesa, but it has not moved to secure full control.

headline.main: Court Lifts Hurdle to E.ON’s Bid for Endesa

abstract: Gazprom’s banking unit has set up an emissions trading venture with Dresdner Bank to take advantage of the growing market for securities linked to greenhouse-gas quotas under the Kyoto Protocol, the companies said Tuesday. The company, Carbon Trade & Finance Sicar, will invest in projects that earn emissions credits by reducing pollution, and will trade the credits and securities linked to the credits.

The funding comes from Bessemer Venture Partner, an investor in companies such as Blue Nile, Skype and VeriSign; Columbia Capital, an investor in Mobi, Nextel and XM Satellite Radio; and Acta Wireless.

abstract: Two major shareholders of Mills each offered a plan to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in the troubled shopping-mall developer to help it pay off heavy debt and stave off potential bankruptcy. The hedge fund Farallon Capital Partners proposed a $499 million recapitalization plan for Mills, while the Israeli real estate firm Gazit-Globe offered a new, $1.8 billion version of an offer it made last year.

abstract: As Merrill Lynch prepares to announce Thursday what analysts expect will be its most profitable year ever, its chief executive will continue to spend those record-breaking profits to make acquisitions to stay competitive, Bloomberg News said. The chief, E. Stanley O’Neal, is expected to eye investments in commodities and mortgage-bond trading in efforts to catch up with Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers, respectively.

headline.main: As Fast as Merill Can Make It, O’Neal Is Is Spending It

abstract: An associate at one of the country’s most prestigious law firms, Sullivan & Cromwell, filed a state lawsuit in Manhattan yesterday accusing the firm of a systematic campaign of discrimination and retaliation against him because of his sexual orientation. The associate, Aaron B. Charney, 28, asserts in the lawsuit, filed in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan, that several partners in Sullivan & Cromwell’s highly regarded mergers and acquisitions practice subjected him to “lewd and illegal conduct,” beginning in the fall of 2005. He is seeking a jury trial and unspecified compensatory and punitive damages.

abstract: The board of Cablevision Systems rejected an $8.9 billion offer Tuesday to sell the company to the Dolans, its founding family. The rebuff was a rare example of a board standing up to and denying a request by a controlling shareholder. The rejection by the board, which set up a special committee to review the Dolans’ proposal, is the second time it has refused to sell the company to the family.

abstract: The regulatory arm of the New York Stock Exchange said Tuesday that it had fined seven specialist firms a combined $2.8 million for trading violations. NYSE Regulation said that the specialists violated the so-called “firm quote” rule. The rule requires specialist firms execute buy or sell orders that are presented to them at prices that are at least as favorable as the N.Y.S.E.’s published bid or offer at the time the orders enter the N.Y.S.E.’s electronic-display book. The specialists also were censured.

abstract: The final chapter in one of the longest-running sagas of corporate crime is scheduled to conclude Wednesday in a Connecticut courtroom. Walter Forbes, the blue-blooded former chairman of Cendant, is set to be sentenced for his role in a $252 million accounting fraud that was exposed nearly a decade ago. At the time, the Cendant fraud was the largest on record, and its exposure in April 1998 wiped out $14 billion of the company’s market capitalization, nearly half its total, in a single day.

headline.main: Day of Reckoning for Former Cendant Chief

abstract: The oil and gas producer Encore Acquisition said on Wednesday that it would pay $400 million in cash to buy oil and natural gas properties in Wyoming from Anadarko Petroleum. The properties include the Elk Basin Unit and the Gooseberry Unit in Park County, Wyo., and Encore expects them to generate about $50 million in cash flow a year in 2007 and 2008. The transaction is expected to close in March, Encore said.

abstract: Tribune, the owner of the Chicago Cubs, the Los Angeles Times and Newsday, appears to have thrown a takeover party where no one showed up. With the deadline for final bids today, the private-equity firms that have been meeting with Tribune’s management and looking over its financial records for the past several months do not plan to submit final offers, according to The New York Post.

abstract: The European aerospace giant EADS, the parent company of Airbus, said on Tuesday it might ask shareholders for permission to go to the financial markets to raise funds. “The question is whether it is possible that we will ask the AGM for authorization to go to the market,” EADS’ finance chief, Hans Peter Ring, said at a press conference. “The answer is ‘yes’, it is possible.”

abstract: Helped by gains from investment banking and trading, J.P. Morgan Chase posted a profit of $3.91 billion, or $1.09 a share, for its fourth quarter of 2006, capping its most profitable year ever. The numbers were up from $2.64 billion a year earlier, exceeding the $2.64 billion from a year ago and beating analysts’ expectations of 94 cents a share. J.P. Morgan’s windfall arrives as other Wall Street rivals like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley boasted of similarly outsized returns.

abstract: Cerberus Capital Management dropped out of a consortium considering a rival offer for the Equity Office Properties Group, according to news reports. The group, which still includes Vornado Realty Trust, Barry Sternlicht’s Starwood Capital and Leon Bluhm’s Walton Street Capital, has been scrambling to put together an offer for Equity Office that would top its agreement last year to be sold for $36 billion to the Blackstone Group. Without Cerberus, it is unclear whether the consortium will be able to mount an offer.

abstract: Bonus-flush investment bankers may be preparing to spend on pricey new real estate, and now it appears at least one of their companies will, too. Bear Stearns is close to signing a deal to drastically expand its midtown Manhattan location, The New York Observer reported Wednesday. After acquiring 240,000 square feet in two leases signed last year, the investment bank is looking to buy an additional 104,000 square feet at its 237 Park Ave. offices, the Observer said, citing three sources close to the deal. If completed, it would be the largest New York City lease of 2007 thus far.

headline.main: Bear Stearns Seeks to Expand — Literally

abstract: Investment banks have long been known as the preserve of hundred-hour weeks, where leaving the office only to change clothes is considered a badge of honor. But according to Fortune, Wall Street is discovering that some of its best people don’t believe that being chained to the office is a mark of greatness — and are leaving for saner pastures. Now, Lehman Brothers and its rivals are turning to “return to work” recruitment programs to lure those employees back. The draw: lighter schedules and less travel.

Now, Lehman Brothers and its rivals are turning to “return to work” recruitment programs to lure those employees back. The draw: lighter schedules and less travel.

headline.main: The Latest Investment-Banking Bonus: A Life

abstract: Teetering on the brink of bankruptcy, it appears Mills has found its white knight. The developer of 38 malls throughout the United States said Wednesday morning that it had agreed to a $1.35 billion buyout by Brookfield Asset Management. Mills has struggled to repay loans that it took out as its business has shriveled and it bled cash. Last week, it said that it could be forced into bankruptcy over a loan from Goldman Sachs Mortgage that would come due at the end of March.

He was found not guilty of a fourth count, securities fraud.

abstract: ASML Holding, maker of the most expensive machines in chip fabrication, said fourth-quarter profit quadrupled on demand for semiconductors used in iPod music devices and mobile phones. Net income jumped to a record 205.5 million euros ($265.7 million), or 0.42 euro a share, from 51.6 million euros, or 0.11 euro a share, a year earlier, ASML said. Sales surged 95 percent, to a record 1.07 billion euros. The company said orders would be “healthy” in the first quarter and revenue would gain this year. Demand for Apple iPods and Motorola phones has spurred shipments of ASML’s $18 million machines to clients like Samsung Electronics, Intel and Texas Instruments. ASML is based in Veldhoven, the Netherlands.

abstract: Exxon Mobil said output from its $17 billion Sakhalin Island development in the Pacific off Russia jumped 40 percent in the last month. Oil and natural gas production from the Sakhalin-1 development has risen to the equivalent of more than 200,000 barrels of crude a day, according to Stuart McGill, senior vice president. Exxon, which operates and owns a 30 percent stake in the project, expects output eventually to reach the equivalent of 317,000 barrels a day. Production at Sakhalin-1 was about 160,000 barrels a day in early December, a Bear Stearns analyst, Nicole Decker, said in a Dec. 13 note to clients after an analysts’ lunch with Exxon’s chief executive, Rex W. Tillerson. Exxon began producing crude from the Chayvo field off Sakhalin Island’s ice-choked coastline in October 2005. Exxon’s partners in Sakhalin-1 are a Japanese group known as Sodeco, the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation of India and the state-run Russian oil company Rosneft.

abstract: The board that establishes accounting rules decided unanimously yesterday not to postpone a rule that requires companies to take a new, more stringent approach to reporting uncertain tax positions on their financial statements. The Financial Accounting Standards Board denied a request from Tax Executives International, which represents corporate tax officers, to delay the new rule, which takes effect this year. The rule, known as Fin 48, requires companies to examine and document their tax positions, evaluating whether those positions are likely to withstand a challenge by the Internal Revenue Service.
lead_paragraph: The board that establishes accounting rules decided unanimously yesterday not to postpone a rule that requires companies to take a new, more stringent approach to reporting uncertain tax positions on their financial statements. The Financial Accounting Standards Board denied a request from Tax Executives International, which represents corporate tax officers, to delay the new rule, which takes effect this year. The rule, known as Fin 48, requires companies to examine and document their tax positions, evaluating whether those positions are likely to withstand a challenge by the Internal Revenue Service.

headline.main: Delay Denied on Tax Accounting Rule

abstract: Fannie Mae’s former chief executive, Franklin D. Raines, asked a federal appeals court Wednesday to bar the company’s regulator from ruling on a lawsuit seeking more than $84 million in penalties against him. James B. Lockhart, director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, “has prejudged the charges” against him “and cannot serve as the impartial decision maker that due process requires,” Mr. Raines said in a filing with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. On Dec. 18, the agency sued Mr. Raines; a former chief financial officer, J. Timothy Howard; and Fannie Mae’s former controller, Leanne G. Spencer, for more than $215 million, citing their roles in profit overstatements of $6.3 billion from 2001 until mid-2004.

Spencer, for more than $215 million, citing their roles in profit overstatements of $6.3 billion from 2001 until mid-2004.

abstract: It looks $400 million is the going rate these days to buy naming rights for the play grounds of professional sports teams, at least when investment banks are anteing up. Setting a record price for the naming rights to an American indoor sports arena, the British bank Barclays has agreed to pay nearly $400 million over 20 years to put its name on the New Jersey Nets’ planned future home in Brooklyn, according to press reports. The deal follows Citigroup‘s November agreement to shell out $20 million a year over 20 years to have its name attached to the structure replacing Shea Stadium, the most expensive stadium rights deal in the United States.

abstract: Less than three weeks after selling Boston’s John Hancock Tower and other office buildings for about $3.2 billion, Beacon Capital Partners is moving to capitalize on the still-hot commercial real estate market by putting an even larger portfolio of properties in the city on the block, according to The Boston Globe.

abstract: Volkswagen‘s former personnel chief may get a suspended sentence and a fine in exchange for a confession on breach of trust charges, the judge at his trial over a corruption scandal at the automaker said Wednesday. The former executive, Peter Hartz, is charged with 44 counts of breach of trust in the case, which has shone an unsavory light on the cozy relationship between the company’s management and labor representatives.

abstract: Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, released additional preliminary financial results, but gave investors no better sense of the size of the earnings restatement the company would make after a review of its stock option grants to employees. In filings with Canadian and American securities regulators, Research in Motion repeated its earlier warning Tuesday that it could restate more than $45 million in earnings dating back to 1997, and again did not indicate an upper limit.

abstract: Apparently, nothing effaces the stigma of a scandal like a billion-dollar profit, as BusinessWeek, looking at Apple‘s recent sales figures, points out. Buoyed by record sales of 21 million of its signature iPod digital media players, Apple reaped that billion-dollar bottom line on revenues of $7.1 billion in its fiscal first quarter. Net income surged 78 percent in the period that includes the year-end holiday season, yielding per-share profit of $1.14, Apple said Wednesday.

abstract: Lionsgate is putting the finishing touches on a $210 million financing pact led by Goldman Sachs, according to Variety, in a sign that private equity and hedge fund money continues to pour into Hollywood, despite mixed results on those investments in 2006. The deal apparently provides backing for 23 films, excluding, among other projects, the “Saw” movie franchise. Variety said that Lionsgate will receive a distribution fee of 15 percent — on the high side for deals that cover slates of films — showing just how the mini-studio has impressed Wall Street with its track record and its model of modestly priced films.

abstract: Viacom‘s MTV Networks announced Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire RateMyProfessors.com. The site, which allows college students to share information on the performance of college professors, has more than 6.6 million ratings on more than 900,000 college professors and is visited by more than 10 million college students, according to MTV Networks. RateMyProssors.com will become a part of MTV Network’s mvtU.com, a 24-hour online college channel that covers campus news, music and videos for college students, as well as a campus television production company.

abstract: Has the fat lady sung for a possible merger between Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio Holdings? The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Kevin Martin, said Wednesday that the two satellite radio companies would not win approval of a merger under current rules. Speculation has ramped up in the last few weeks over the possibility of such a deal, which has long been championed by a slew of market watchers, as well as Sirius executives. And last week XM officials were apparently showing signs of enthusiasm themselves at a Citigroup entertainment and media conference.

And last week XM officials were apparently showing signs of enthusiasm themselves at a Citigroup entertainment and media conference.

abstract: Universal Pictures has raided 20th Century Fox and hired away the animation executive who oversaw the hit “Ice Age” movies, a move intended to fill a void left when Paramount acquired DreamWorks and replaced Universal as distributor of animated films like “Over the Hedge.” Universal has lured Christopher Meledandri, the president of 20th Century Fox Animation, with a deal to initially finance a new company run by Mr. Meledandri, whose animated and live action films would be exclusive to Universal, according to press reports. The plan calls for the firm to ultimately be financed by outside investors.

The plan calls for the firm to ultimately be financed by outside investors.

The net proceeds of the bought deal, underwritten by a syndicate including Scotia Capital, GMP Securities, BMO Nesbitt Burns and CIBC World Markets, are to be used to repay debt and for general corporate purposes.

abstract: The London Stock Exchange stepped up its defense against the 2.7 billion pound ($5.3 billion) bid from it rival, Nasdaq, with the promise that it will give up to 250 million pounds back to shareholders. This is more than double the amount that had been expected in the City of London, and the L.S.E. is hoping it will be enough to persuade its investors to remain loyal and reject the offer, The Guardian reported.

Nicholas III and Henry Samueli, the billionaire founders of the company, legal experts told The Los Angeles Times. Broadcom disclosed last month that the Securities and Exchange Commission had elevated its inquiry to a formal investigation, an action that gives the agency the power to subpoena documents and testimony.

abstract: The German insurer Allianz said it is offering 10.5 billion euros ($13.5 billion) to buy out the stakes it does not already own in France’s AGF and Germany’s Allianz Leben as it tries to get a better grip on its wide array of European operations. Allianz said the deals would strengthen its position in Europe and in growth markets, simplify its ownership structure and lift earnings per share in 2008.

abstract: Merrill Lynch plans to invest up to $4.15 billion in a property development partnership with the Japanese venture capital firm SBI Holdings, Reuters reported. Merrill Lynch’s Japan arm and SBI have agreed to create a special-purpose company to buy land and build condominiums and commercial properties, intending to sell the developments on to real estate funds and other investors, the report said.

Citigroup would pay $30 million for a 14 percent stake, which will be made up of new shares and 284,000 convertible warrants. Goldman would buy $22 million of foreign currency convertible bonds.

abstract: With the unprecedented amount of cash sloshing around in private equity’s pockets, it may have been inevitable, but the gloves have come off in buyouts. Late Wednesday, a group of investors offered $38 billion for the nation’s largest office landlord, setting off the biggest buyout battle since the landmark fight for RJR Nabisco nearly two decades ago. The upstart bid for Equity Office Properties, the real estate investment trust that was founded by Samuel Zell, tops a $36 billion deal that Equity Office had reached with the Blackstone Group in November. Either bid would win the crown as the largest buyout ever, surpassing last summer’s $33 billion deal for HCA.

The upstart bid for Equity Office Properties, the real estate investment trust that was founded by Samuel Zell, tops a $36 billion deal that Equity Office had reached with the Blackstone Group in November. Either bid would win the crown as the largest buyout ever, surpassing last summer’s $33 billion deal for HCA.

headline.main: Equity Office: Sharper Elbows in Buyout Battles

abstract: Knight Capital Group, the second-largest trader of Nasdaq-listed stocks, said fourth-quarter profit increased 13 percent as it handled more shares and fees rose from its Deephaven hedge funds. Net income rose to $47.4 million from $41.9 million a year earlier, while revenue increased 29 percent, to $260.1 million. Deephaven Capital Management produced $27.4 million in pretax profit from asset-management fees, compared with $6.6 million a year earlier. The hedge funds had $4.2 billion under management as of Dec. 31, up from $2.9 billion a year earlier.

abstract: Helped by gains from trading and buyouts, Merrill Lynch said its fourth-quarter profit surged 68 percent to $2.35 billion, or $2.41 a share, from $1.39 billion a year earlier. The results, which exceeded analysts’ estimates, fall in line with the record profits other Wall Street firms have shown over the past year, as mergers and acquisitions activity has risen to new heights.

abstract: Shortly after the rejection of their $8.9 billion second offer for Cablevision, the cable company’s ruling Dolan family might be looking to John Malone for some solace, The New York Post reports. Unnamed sources said that the failed bid poses an opportunity for the two sides to talk about selling part or all of the network’s Rainbow Media, home to the AMC and IFC channels, to Mr. Malone’s Liberty Media. As it previously reported, the Post said that the Dolans could use cash from the transaction to make a third run at Cablevision.

abstract: The California attorney general’s office has offered plea bargains to Patricia Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, and four other defendants, offering them the chance to accept a misdemeanor charge each for their role in a spying scandal at the company, The San Jose Mercury News reported Thursday. But federal prosecutors will continue with their own case, which the Mercury News said could endanger those deals through “double jeopardy” provisions in California’s penal code. (State attorneys are discouraged from pursuing cases in which defendants have been acquitted or convicted in federal court.)

abstract: A lawsuit filed by former New York Stock Exchange seatholders against the exchange has gotten some backing, The New York Post reported Thursday. The Weys then sold their seat for $1.54 million the next month. (The N.Y.S.E. eventually merged with the Archipelago electronic exchange, creating one of the world’s largest exchanges with a current market capitalization of $16 billion.)

abstract: Is it possible that hedge funds, the media stars du jour, may have lost a little of their shine lately? Data from two reports suggests that may be the case — at least, temporarily. Bloomberg News writes of a new study by Hedge Fund Research showing that hedge fund inflows dropped 64 percent in the fourth quarter of 2006. And a separate report by Spectrem found that among the wealthiest investors, investment in that $1.3 trillion asset class dropped by more than 10 percent.

abstract: Deutsche Bank and its former chief executive, Rolf E. Breuer, are facing damage claims of 1.4 billion euros ($1.8 billion) from the media mogul Leo Kirch for comments made in 2002 about the creditworthiness of Mr. Kirch’s media group. “The claims have no substance, and we’ll vigorously counter any legal action,” a Deutsche Bank spokesman, Ronald Weichert, said. The bank received a letter from Mr. Kirch’s lawyers demanding it pay the money by Jan. 30 or face a lawsuit, Mr. Weichert said. The dispute stems from a 2002 Bloomberg television interview in which Mr. Breuer said the financial sector was not prepared to provide new loans for Mr. Kirch’s company. The company collapsed a few months later.

abstract: The BBC said it might have to cut back on the creation of television shows and other programming after the government awarded it less public financing over the next six years than it had requested. The BBC’s license fee, which every British household with a television is required to pay, will rise to £148 ($290) in 2012, from £131.50 last year. The fee will generate more than £20 billion ($39.4 billion) for the BBC over the six years, about £2 billion less than the BBC had requested, the broadcaster said. “We now face not just a tight settlement but daunting investment challenges in distribution, infrastructure and technology that risk diverting money away from content creation,” said Mark Thompson, above, the director general of the BBC.

abstract: Intel is considering building its first semiconductor factory in Asia in the northeastern Chinese city of Dalian. The company won approval to build a factory in the Dalian Economic and Technological Development Zone, Mr. Gao said. Intel has assembly and testing plants in Shanghai and Chengdu.

abstract: When members of Tribune board assemble this weekend to review bids for the company, they will have a lot to consider but not much to be happy about. The company received at least two firm bids by Wednesday’s deadline, one from the Los Angeles team of Eli Broad and Ronald W. Burkle, and another from the Chandler family, the company’s largest shareholder. A third potential bidder, the Carlyle Group, has expressed interest but only in Tribune’s television group. The company also owns 11 papers, including The Los Angeles Times.

abstract: A special committee of the New York State Bar Association is calling on law firms to end the practice of mandatory retirement for partners. In a strongly worded report that is to be released Friday, the committee concluded that “mandatory retirement – requiring a partner to leave the firm upon reaching an arbitrary age – is not an acceptable practice.”

abstract: The Bank of New York Company, one of the nation’s largest trust banks, reported an increase in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday on strength in its corporate trust business, depositary receipts and global custody services. The New York-based bank said net income totaled $1.79 billion, or $2.36 a share, in the October-December period, up from $405 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier.

abstract: The bidding for the roofing products maker ElkCorp heated up Thursday, with the Building Materials Corporation of America raising its bid to $865.2 million, topping a $834 million offer by a private equity firm, the Carlyle Group. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Building Materials said it had raised its offer for ElkCorp to $42 a share in cash, from an earlier $40. Earlier in the day, Carlyle said it had started a tender offer on its previously disclosed bid of $40.50 a share.
lead_paragraph: The bidding for the roofing products maker ElkCorp heated up Thursday, with the Building Materials Corporation of America raising its bid to $865.2 million, topping a $834 million offer by a private equity firm, the Carlyle Group. Earlier in the day, Carlyle said it had started a tender offer on its previously disclosed bid of $40.50 a share.

headline.main: Bidding for ElkCorp Heats Up

abstract: On the vanguard of venture capital, the buzzwords of late have been “alternative energy” and “China.” Are the two worlds about to collide? Seed investors are financing, or considering financing, start-ups in China that are developing equipment for wind and solar power, clean water and food alternatives and technology to promote energy efficiency. While this may seem to be an arbitrary combination of two of the hottest trends in venture capital – sort of like the first person who mixed peanut butter and chocolate – there is a growing number of investors who believe that the potential reward in China is worth the tremendous risk.
lead_paragraph: On the vanguard of venture capital, the buzzwords of late have been “alternative energy” and “China.” Are the two worlds about to collide? Seed investors are financing, or considering financing, start-ups in China that are developing equipment for wind and solar power, clean water and food alternatives and technology to promote energy efficiency. While this may seem to be an arbitrary combination of two of the hottest trends in venture capital – sort of like the first person who mixed peanut butter and chocolate – there is a growing number of investors who believe that the potential reward in China is worth the tremendous risk.

headline.main: How China Is Going Green

abstract: Royal Dutch Shell is dangling the prospect of a 15 percent-plus bump in its offer to buy oil patch subsidiary Shell Canada for C$7.7 billion ($6.6 billion), if minority shareholders agree to support its takeover bid, The Globe and Mail reported. Apparently frustrated in its attempts to drum up interest in a 40-Canadian-dollars -a-share offer made in October, and fearing a nasty takeover battle, Royal Dutch has been quietly meeting with the biggest shareholders in its Calgary-based offspring in recent weeks, the report said. Money managers in Toronto and Calgary told the newspaper that the parent company is holding out the promise of $46 to $48 a share if institutions agree to commit their shares.

headline.main: Shell Mulls Boosting Offer for Canadian Unit, Report Says

abstract: Mace Security International, which owns a chain of car washes and makes the namesake pepper spray, has received an unsolicited $45.8 million buyout bid from a California-based private equity firm. The offer of $3 a share by Kelly Capital Management was disclosed in a regulatory filing yesterday and Mace said its board was reviewing the offer. While shares of the company soared on the news, Mace’s two largest shareholders, Lawndale Capital Management and Ancora Capital, said the offer seemed too low.
lead_paragraph: Mace Security International, which owns a chain of car washes and makes the namesake pepper spray, has received an unsolicited $45.8 million buyout bid from a California-based private equity firm. While shares of the company soared on the news, Mace’s two largest shareholders, Lawndale Capital Management and Ancora Capital, said the offer seemed too low.

headline.main: Buyout Firm Reaches for Mace

abstract: Ten major companies, including industrial giants like General Electric, DuPont and Alcoa, have banded together with leading environmental groups to call for a firm nationwide limit on carbon dioxide emissions that would lead to reductions of 10 to 30 percent over the next 15 years. Besides adding pressure on Congress to act, one of the group’s major goals is the creation of a market in which allowances to emit carbon dioxide could be traded in a way that achieves the greatest reduction at the lowest cost.
lead_paragraph: Ten major companies, including industrial giants like General Electric, DuPont and Alcoa, have banded together with leading environmental groups to call for a firm nationwide limit on carbon dioxide emissions that would lead to reductions of 10 to 30 percent over the next 15 years. Besides adding pressure on Congress to act, one of the group’s major goals is the creation of a market in which allowances to emit carbon dioxide could be traded in a way that achieves the greatest reduction at the lowest cost.

headline.main: Firms Band Together for Emissions Market

abstract: Providence Equity Partners is gearing up to play with the big boys. The media buyout specialist is looking to triple its fund size, and, in doing so, has agreed to cut its carried interest, or percentage of the fund’s profits, to 20 percent from 25 percent, according to press reports. The firm promised at the outset to do so if the new fund exceeded its initial $8 billion soft target, The Deal.com reported. And now it is now raising up to $12 billion, after recently holding a first close at $8 billion. The move puts Providence among $10 billion-plus mega-funds raised by the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.
lead_paragraph: Providence Equity Partners is gearing up to play with the big boys. The firm promised at the outset to do so if the new fund exceeded its initial $8 billion soft target, The Deal.com reported. And now it is now raising up to $12 billion, after recently holding a first close at $8 billion. The move puts Providence among $10 billion-plus mega-funds raised by the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline.main: As Fund Grows, Providence Cuts Fees

abstract: After the announcements of the twin $400 million naming-rights deals inked by British bank Barclays, for the Nets new arena, and Citigroup, for the Mets new stadium, the Jets and the Giants must be salivating as they look over the next year to sell the naming rights to their $1.2 billion stadium in the Meadowlands. They professional football teams have hired the Wasserman Media Group to handle the transaction, and yesterday, Jeff Knapple, the president of WMG Marketing told The New York Times: “We’ve watched with a keen eye toward what the Mets and the Nets have done. It’s an indication of the power of the New York marketplace and its position in the nation and the world.”

abstract: The leap into hedge funds by Richard C. Breeden, the former top securities regulator, is making waves. As the court-appointed guardian and self-described fixer of some of America’s most wayward companies, Mr. Breeden, who also oversaw Securities and Exchange Commission from 1989 to 1993, is considered a pillar of corporate ethics and governance. Now he trying to become another paragon – that of savvy investor in troubled companies. And in the coming months he will face his first major test: taking on the Applebee’s International restaurant chain in a proxy fight.

And in the coming months he will face his first major test: taking on the Applebee’s International restaurant chain in a proxy fight.

Robinson, said Thursday that the company remains committed to the New England market and The Globe, despite the financial difficulties roiling the newspaper and traditional media in general.
