abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

abstract: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act might be meant to guard against massive white-collar scandals, but the resignation of a high-profile tech veteran suggests the law may also be restricting efficiency atop Silicon Valley’s corporate ladder, CNet News.com suggests. Earlier this month, venture capitalist and Netscape founder Jim Clark announced his departure from the board of directors at photo-printing site Shutterfly, where he served as chairman. In his resignation letter, he cited “the constraints imposed by Sarbanes-Oxley” as one of the primary reasons for departure.
lead_paragraph: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act might be meant to guard against massive white-collar scandals, but the resignation of a high-profile tech veteran suggests the law may also be restricting efficiency atop Silicon Valley’s corporate ladder, CNet News.com suggests. In his resignation letter, he cited “the constraints imposed by Sarbanes-Oxley” as one of the primary reasons for departure.

headline.main: Silicon Valley’s Sarbanes-Oxley Problem

abstract: Morgan Stanley, the biggest real estate investor among Wall Street firms, agreed to buy CNL Hotels & Resorts Inc., adding eight luxury hotels and resorts throughout the U.S. in a transaction worth $6.6 billion. The move comes amid a hot market for hotel acquisitions, which booked a 38 percent jump in 2006 to reach $70 billion. Morgan Stanley Real Estate will pay $20.50 for each CNL share and assume CNL’s debt. CNL, based in Orlando, Florida, will also sell 51 properties to Ashford Hospitality Trust for about $2.4 billion as part of the takeover.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley, the biggest real estate investor among Wall Street firms, agreed to buy CNL Hotels & Resorts Inc., adding eight luxury hotels and resorts throughout the U.S. in a transaction worth $6.6 billion. The move comes amid a hot market for hotel acquisitions, which booked a 38 percent jump in 2006 to reach $70 billion. Morgan Stanley Real Estate will pay $20.50 for each CNL share and assume CNL’s debt. CNL, based in Orlando, Florida, will also sell 51 properties to Ashford Hospitality Trust for about $2.4 billion as part of the takeover.

headline.main: Morgan Stanley to Buy CNL Hotels in $6.6 Billion Deal

Smith; and broadcasting president, John E. Reardon, are among those eligible if they are dismissed within three years of a Chandler takeover.

abstract: Wall Street executives and office types may be enjoying record bonuses right now, but those who work the trading floor have increasingly little to celebrate. The New York Post reported Friday that Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs have laid off even more floor workers at the New York Stock Exchange, as the market increasingly moves to electronic trading via its so-called hybrid-trading system. Lehman laid off six and Goldman nine on Thursday, the paper said, adding that both laid off an unknown number of marketers who sell floor-trading screens and execution services.

abstract: DAVOS, ANYONE? The annual World Economic Forum will take place Wednesday through Sunday in Davos, Switzerland, drawing political and business leaders — plus a celebrity or two — to brainstorm solutions to world problems. Among the top issues on the agenda are climate change and the role of emerging markets. Klaus Schwab, right, the founder and executive chairman of the forum, said he hoped that this year’s conference would address a “schizophrenic world” in which there are both broad prosperity and tremendous risks from many directions.

abstract: The NYSE Group and NASD have won approval from brokerage firms to form a single regulator for the United States securities industry, overcoming opposition from a group of small firms. Sixty-four percent of members of NASD approved combining its regulatory operations with those of NYSE to create a single watchdog, NASD said in a statement Sunday. NASD, a private-sector provider of financial regulatory services with 5,058 brokerage firms, said almost 83 percent of eligible members voted during a 33-day election period.

abstract: The Industrial Bank of China, partly owned by a unit of HSBC Holdings, may raise up to 21.25 billion yuan ($2.74 billion) from a Shanghai share sale, making it the second-largest domestic initial public offering by a mainland Chinese bank. Industrial Bank plans to sell up to 1.33 billion class A shares at between 15 yuan and 15.98 yuan each to investors, the company said in a statement Sunday. The sale would top the Bank of China’s 20 billion yuan offer in June 2006 and would be second only to the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China’s sale of 46.6 billion yuan last year.

abstract: Directors of corporations often form a tight-knit community, serving at more than one company and creating what are known as interlocking boards of directors. As a result of this chumminess, corporate practices that otherwise might remain confined to just a few companies can spread quickly. That appears to have been the case with the backdating of stock options, according to a new statistical study of publicly traded American companies.

abstract: The chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, Mark V. Hurd, told Congressional lawmakers that his sale of company shares on Aug. 25 was “totally unrelated” to the fact that he was questioned the same day about an ill-fated internal investigation. The sale of 100,000 shares of Hewlett-Packard was made during a scheduled window for trading by executives, Mr. Hurd wrote in a letter dated Dec. 21 that he sent to the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat. On the same day the trade was completed, Mr. Hurd was interviewed by lawyers from the law firm of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati. The lawyers were looking into techniques used by Hewlett-Packard to identify the source of boardroom leaks.

abstract: Two former traders at the New York Stock Exchange were each sentenced Friday to six months in prison and fined $250,000 for improper stock trading. The two traders, Michael J. Hayward and Michael F. Stern, former managers at Van der Moolen Specialists USA, were each convicted of securities fraud at a trial in July, part of a crackdown on illegal trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: Two former traders at the New York Stock Exchange were each sentenced Friday to six months in prison and fined $250,000 for improper stock trading. The two traders, Michael J. Hayward and Michael F. Stern, former managers at Van der Moolen Specialists USA, were each convicted of securities fraud at a trial in July, part of a crackdown on illegal trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline.main: Two Former N.Y.S.E. Traders Sentenced for Fraud

abstract: Sears Holdings‘ chief financial officer resigned Friday after less than four months on the job, the latest in a string of high-level executive changes as billionaire Edward Lampert searches for ways to make money on one of his biggest, and most challenging, investments. The executive, Craig Monaghan, plans to leave at the end of January and return to Florida where his family lives, according to an announcement from the Hoffman Estates-based company. William Crowley, chief administrative officer and chief financial officer before Mr. Monaghan’s arrival, will assume the C.F.O. role while Sears looks for a replacement.
lead_paragraph: Sears Holdings‘ chief financial officer resigned Friday after less than four months on the job, the latest in a string of high-level executive changes as billionaire Edward Lampert searches for ways to make money on one of his biggest, and most challenging, investments. The executive, Craig Monaghan, plans to leave at the end of January and return to Florida where his family lives, according to an announcement from the Hoffman Estates-based company. William Crowley, chief administrative officer and chief financial officer before Mr. Monaghan’s arrival, will assume the C.F.O. role while Sears looks for a replacement.

headline.main: Sears C.F.O. Resigns

abstract: The Justice Department has issued subpoenas to at least four Wall Street investment banks as part of a widening investigation into the multibillion-dollar online gambling industry, The New York Times reported. The subpoenas were apparently issued to firms that had underwritten the initial public offerings of some of the most popular online gambling sites that operate abroad. The Times said that the banks involved in the inquiry include HSBC, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Kleinwort, these people said.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has issued subpoenas to at least four Wall Street investment banks as part of a widening investigation into the multibillion-dollar online gambling industry, The New York Times reported. The Times said that the banks involved in the inquiry include HSBC, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Kleinwort, these people said.

headline.main: Online Gambling Underwriters Face Subpoenas in U.S.

abstract: Another iconic Chicago tower changed hands Friday with the closing of the approximately $385 million sale of Chicago’s third-tallest skyscraper, the John Hancock Center. The buyer is a joint venture of hometown real estate firm Golub & Company and Whitehall Street Real Estate Fund, an affiliate of New York-based Goldman Sachs.

headline.main: Chicago’s Hancock Center Changes Hands

abstract: Actor Kevin Bacon has finally embraced the fact that he’s connected to most of the rest of the world by just six degrees, and he’s parlaying the concept to help humanity. SixDegrees.org, a play on the popular, tongue-in-cheek “Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon” game based on the performer’s career, hopes to be more than just a social-networking site, but rather a site that motivates the public to be more charitable.

headline.main: Bacon’s Six Degrees of Charitable Giving

abstract: China wants Canadian banks to abandon their timid approach to the Asian market of 1.3 billion consumers and instead step up investment there, the Canadian finance minister, Jim Flaherty, said Sunday, passing on advice that he underlined should be heeded. “One of the things I heard from officials in China is that our financial services sector – particularly our banks – have probably been too conservative, not aggressive enough, in the China market,” Mr. Flaherty said during a conference call with reporters at the end of a week-long trip to Beijing and Shanghai.
lead_paragraph: China wants Canadian banks to abandon their timid approach to the Asian market of 1.3 billion consumers and instead step up investment there, the Canadian finance minister, Jim Flaherty, said Sunday, passing on advice that he underlined should be heeded. “One of the things I heard from officials in China is that our financial services sector – particularly our banks – have probably been too conservative, not aggressive enough, in the China market,” Mr. Flaherty said during a conference call with reporters at the end of a week-long trip to Beijing and Shanghai.

headline.main: Canadian Banks Chided for Timid Approach to China

abstract: Providence Equity Partners said it would open offices in Hong Kong and New Delhi to support its growing investment activities in Asia. Andrew Rickards, chief executive of the investment bank N.M. Rothschild & Sons in Asia, will become a managing director at Providence in Hong Kong and will lead the firm’s Asian investments, Providence said.

abstract: It seems that the brouhaha surrounding the treatment of a Bollywood actress on the British version of “Big Brother” is not doing British business any favors. Richard Lambert, director-general of an employers’ organization, the CBI, has waded into the row over alleged racism on Channel 4’s “Celebrity Big Brother” by describing the program as “complete crap” and “unhelpful” to British firms trying to establish themselves in India. The Guardian reported.

abstract: Google is in talks to acquire Adscape Media in a move to expand beyond its traditional Internet search advertising business and into video games, according to The Wall street Journal. A deal for Adscape, a closely held San Francisco firm whose technology allows for the placement of ads over the Web in video games, could be reached as early as this week, the report said.

headline.main: Google in Talks to Buy Internet Ad Firm, Report Says

abstract: Salary.com, which provides on-demand compensation management products, set its planned initial public offering Friday at 5 million shares for an estimated price of $8 to $10 each. The company said in an amended Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the underwriters, Thomas Weisel Partners, William Blair & Company, Needham & Company, Wachovia Securities, and Pacific Crest Securities, have the option to buy an additional 750,000 shares to cover over-allotments.
lead_paragraph: Salary.com, which provides on-demand compensation management products, set its planned initial public offering Friday at 5 million shares for an estimated price of $8 to $10 each. abstract: The Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland’s second-largest bank, plans a record share buyback and will seek takeovers after selling its Winterthur insurance unit for 12.3 billion Swiss francs ($9.8 billion). The bank plans to buy back as much as 8 billion Swiss francs of stock over three years and has set aside 3.5 billion Swiss francs for “bolt-on acquisitions” in areas including wealth management, the bank said in a presentation to investors today. Credit Suisse last month completed the sale of Winterthur to France’s Axa.
lead_paragraph: The Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland’s second-largest bank, plans a record share buyback and will seek takeovers after selling its Winterthur insurance unit for 12.3 billion Swiss francs ($9.8 billion). Credit Suisse last month completed the sale of Winterthur to France’s Axa.

headline.main: Credit Suisse Eyes Big Buyback and and Other Deals

abstract: The Blackstone Group and Sweden’s billionaire Wallenberg family are the leading bidders for Moelnlycke Health Care, which may be sold for as much as 3 billion euros ($3.9 billion), according to Bloomberg News. The report said that Apax Partners, the buyout shop that acquired Moelnlycke, a maker of surgical products, two years ago, is considering whether to drop a planned initial public offering and pursue a sale after receiving offers that value Moelnlycke at 2.5 billion euros to 3 billion euros.

abstract: Stoke, a provider of networking hardware and software, said Monday it had raised $20 million in a Series C funding round led by led by DAG Ventures. Previous investors including Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers and Sequoia Capital also participated in the round, Stoke said.

abstract: Citigroup agreed to buy ABN Amro Holding‘s ABN Amro Mortgage Group for an undisclosed amount to strengthen its presence in mortgage origination and servicing in the United States. Citigroup will acquire about $9 billion in net assets and the mortgage group’s $224 billion mortgage-servicing portfolio, the bank said on Monday. The mortgage group is unit of ABN Amro’s LaSalle Bank.

abstract: Adding to a chorus of concern that the United States is losing its edge as the leading financial center, Senator Charles E. Schumer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will release a report Monday urging the country to take a series of steps to improve its legal and regulatory environment. If not, the report warns, it could lose 4 to 7 percent of the global financial services market over the next five years.

abstract: Blogging by a chief executive can be tricky business. Some executives, like Jonathan I. Schwartz of Sun Microsystems, pull it off with aplomb. Others, like Jason Goldberg of the online recruiting company Jobster, have had more difficulty. Last month, Mr. Goldberg took to his blog to knock down rumors that Jobster was in trouble. “Everybody’s all a speculating. A lot of falsehoods are being bandied about,” he wrote on Dec. 22. He said that revenue was up 30 percent, and he vowed to drive the company to profitability in 2007. Amid rumors of pending layoffs, he assured the staff that there would be no news until after the new year.

Amid rumors of pending layoffs, he assured the staff that there would be no news until after the new year.

headline.main: A Boss Takes to His Blog to Deny, Then Confirm

abstract: Sallie L. Krawcheck, the chief financial officer of Citigroup, will become head of the banking giant’s wealth-management division. The move, which Citigroup announced in a news release early Monday, comes several weeks after the bank announced a management shake-up that seemed to quiet speculation on Wall Street that Ms. Krawcheck was planning to resign from the firm.

abstract: Cushman & Wakefield has sold the former Banker’s Trust building at 14 Wall St., with its iconic pyramid top, as office space for $325 million, The New York Post reported. Citing unnamed sources, the Post said that the real estate firm approached John Zamir of Capstone Equities about buying the building, which was not then for sale. Its current owners bought the building, with 1 million square feet of space, for $215 million in 2005 with the intent of making it residential. Those plans have long since stalled.

abstract: “You would have thought,” one fund manager recently opined to Bloomberg News, “it would be a U.S. bank that’s nipping at Goldman’s heels.” But you would have thought wrong: It is Zurich-based UBS that appears to be doing the nipping. And if the bank keeps up its pursuit of the Chinese market, UBS may surpass Goldman Sachs as the top dog of global stock sellers, Bloomberg News reports.

abstract: Mark McGoldrick, the London-based co-head of Goldman Sachs’ Special Situations Group, will retire for personal reasons, Bloomberg News reported Monday. His New York-based partner, Stephen McGuinness, will assume control of the whole unit, a Goldman spokesman said. Mr. McGoldrick, 47, earned the investment bank $500 million last year after Goldman sold a stake in Accordia Golf, a company it formed to run a set of failed Japanese golf courses.

abstract: In an attempt to put the brouhaha over Caremark‘s proposed deal with CVS in context, TheStreet.com’s Melissa Davis offers a history lesson. Edwin M. Crawford, the chief of Caremark, was at the center of another health-care merger more than a decade ago that in many ways mirrors what’s happening now. Although he is considered a “turnaround king” who has steered Caremark to solid returns during his tenure, Ms. Davis writes, Mr. Crawford has at least one black spot in his past.

abstract: Thanks to its smallish size and its location on the West Coast, Alaska Air could make an attractive takeover candidate if airlines start merging, according to a Credit Suisse analyst, Daniel McKenzie. Mr. McKenzie initiated coverage of the airline with an “outperform” rating. Despite the dominance of larger carriers, he wrote, Alaska Air holds strong market positions in a number of routes and has a solid balance sheet that is second only to that of Southwest Airlines.

abstract: Why are so many billionaires speaking out lately about income inequality and the plight of the middle class? Trend-mongering is part of it, to be sure. But Slate’s Daniel Gross also sees something else at work: fear that the hoi-polloi are mad as hell, and soon won’t take it anymore. Should the middle class face continued hardship — while “economic royalists” like Stephen Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group keep growing richer — the free trade of goods, services and capital will lose political support. And who else does that hurt?

And who else does that hurt?

headline.main: The Mystery of the Private-Equity Populists

abstract: As well as a flurry of corporate bigwigs and policy makers, Davos can expect some snow later this week, if weather forecasts prove correct. Considering the unusually balmy winter the Alps is having this year, that is likely to be happy news for the conference’s many skiing aficionados and especially for one mogul in particular: publishing executive Hubert Burda, who for several years has organized an invitation-only ski race to coincide with the annual conference.

abstract: NOT A BAD YEAR FOR AIRLINES After $35 billion in net losses from 2001 to 2005, the domestic airline industry is expected to earn about $4 billion in 2007 and to report earnings of $2 billion to $3 billion for 2006, the Air Transport Association said. But the Champagne corks are not popping yet. John Heimlich, the trade association’s chief economist, noted that despite cost cutting, reduction in capacity and a decrease in the number of aircraft types flown, “debt levels remain high, leaving airlines vulnerable to fuel spikes” and other risks like a recession, natural disaster or another significant terrorist attack.

abstract: The Credit Suisse Group, the Swiss bank, will use proceeds from the sale of its Winterthur insurance unit to buy back a record amount of stock and make money-management acquisitions. The bank plans to repurchase as much as 8 billion francs ($6.4 billion) of shares over three years and has set aside 3.5 billion francs for possible takeovers in the United States, the Middle East and Asia. “We have the requisite resources to grow our business, while at the same time returning capital to our shareholders,” the chief executive, Oswald J. Grübel, told investors in Zurich. Credit Suisse completed the sale of Winterthur to Axa of France for 12.3 billion francs last month.

abstract: Small publishers left reeling by the bankruptcy filing of the book wholesaler Advanced Marketing Services last month received a rare bit of good news on Monday. The Perseus Books Group announced that it was offering to acquire the distribution contracts of about 150 book publishers who employ Publishers Group West, a subsidiary of Advanced Marketing Services, as their book distributor. Perseus promised to pay 70 cents for every dollar owed to the publishers, an amount that could total $20 million if all the publishers accepted the deal.

Perseus promised to pay 70 cents for every dollar owed to the publishers, an amount that could total $20 million if all the publishers accepted the deal.

headline.main: Partial Bailout Offered in Book Bankruptcy

abstract: The state of Illinois took the first steps in selling its state lottery system yesterday, hoping to attract as much as $10 billion from investors who, in return, would own a monopoly that could turn out to be the biggest jackpot yet. The sale, which may occur as early as the spring, would not be the first privatization of public property – both Chicago and Indiana have recently earned billions of dollars by signing long-term leases with private companies to run toll roads. But the proposed lottery sale is almost certain be one of the largest privatizations of a state-run program, and it raises concerns that states, some of them critically short of cash, are selling valuable assets that could otherwise provide consistent streams of revenue.

But the proposed lottery sale is almost certain be one of the largest privatizations of a state-run program, and it raises concerns that states, some of them critically short of cash, are selling valuable assets that could otherwise provide consistent streams of revenue.

headline.main: Illinois Is Putting Lottery on Block for Quick Payoff

abstract: Northwest Airlines will take control of Mesaba Airlines, the bankrupt regional carrier, in a step toward its own exit from bankruptcy. Mesaba will become a unit of Northwest under an agreement with Mesaba’s parent, Mair Holdings, the companies said Monday. Northwest, Mair’s largest shareholder, will sell its stake back to Mair for $35 million in exchange for Mesaba’s shares now held by Mair. Mesaba will get a claim of $145 million against Northwest that it will sell to pay off its creditors.

abstract: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn said on Monday that he planned to back three nominees by Metropolitan Capital Advisors to the board of Cyberonics, a medical device maker under investigation for its stock options dating practices. Mr. Icahn holds a 9.77 percent stake in Cyberonics, which is scheduled to have its annual stockholders meeting on Feb. 1, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Company management is trying to have shareholders re-elect three directors; Metropolitan Capital wants to replace all three.

abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software, maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, said Monday that it let its former chief executive, Ryan A. Brant, “control and dominate” improper options backdating that began when the company went public in 1997. The compensation committee abdicated its responsibilities for the grants and failed to maintain proper controls, the company said in a regulatory filing. Take-Two will restate results from 1997 to 2003 to reflect options costs.

abstract: Venture capital investments in high-tech and life sciences start-ups climbed 12 percent to $25.5 billion in 2006, from $22.7 billion the prior year, according to the MoneyTree survey released Monday. The increase marked the third consecutive year of higher outlays for the firms that supply financial fuel for the nation’s entrepreneurial economy. Last year’s venture capital investment level was the highest since 2001, the last big financing year before the dot-com bust.

Last year’s venture capital investment level was the highest since 2001, the last big financing year before the dot-com bust.

headline.main: Venture Capitalists Favored Tech Last Year

lead_paragraph: China Mobile, already the world’s largest mobile phone company, is making its first overseas acquisition by buying a majority stake in Paktel, a mobile phone company in Pakistan, for $284 million. China Mobile agreed to buy an 89 percent stake in the company, which is owned by Millicom International Cellular of Luxemberg.

headline.main: China Mobile Dials Up Deal for Paktel

abstract: Publicis, the advertising group, has denied market speculation that it is preparing a bid for the British media group Aegis. Publicis, which is finalizing a $1.3 billion deal to acquire the North American new media group Digitas, said that the rumors were “groundless.”
lead_paragraph: Publicis, the advertising group, has denied market speculation that it is preparing a bid for the British media group Aegis. Publicis, which is finalizing a $1.3 billion deal to acquire the North American new media group Digitas, said that the rumors were “groundless.”

headline.main: Publicis Denies Aegis Bid Rumors

abstract: A Georgia state judge on Monday refused to block the severance pay of Home Depot‘s former chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, but gave plaintiffs time to gather more information in the case. “On the injunction, I’m going to deny it with the proviso that I may consider it at a later date,” Judge Craig Schwall of Fulton County Superior Court said at a hearing. He said it would give lawyers for shareholders who sought to block the exit pay 60 days to depose company directors and compile more information.

Nardelli, but gave plaintiffs time to gather more information in the case. “On the injunction, I’m going to deny it with the proviso that I may consider it at a later date,” Judge Craig Schwall of Fulton County Superior Court said at a hearing. He said it would give lawyers for shareholders who sought to block the exit pay 60 days to depose company directors and compile more information.

headline.main: Judge Won’t Block Nardelli’s Pay

abstract: The recent shake-up in the United States Attorney’s office in San Francisco could lead to delays in the office’s wide-ranging backdating investigation, according to The San Jose Mercury News. The turnover, which includes the departure of a United States Attorney, Kevin Ryan, comes as the government’s scrutiny of options backdating at Apple appears to be heating up. Federal prosecutors and Securities and Exchange Commission officials interviewed Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, last week as part of that investigation, the newspaper said.
lead_paragraph: The recent shake-up in the United States Attorney’s office in San Francisco could lead to delays in the office’s wide-ranging backdating investigation, according to The San Jose Mercury News. Federal prosecutors and Securities and Exchange Commission officials interviewed Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, last week as part of that investigation, the newspaper said.

headline.main: Attorney General Shake-Up May Delay Options Inquiries

abstract: Cemex, the world’s third-largest cement maker, extended its $11.7 billion hostile takeover bid for Australia’s Rinker Group by two months while it waits for U.S. regulatory approval. Cemex’s $13-a-share offer for Australia’s biggest building materials company will now end March 30, the Monterrey, Mexico-based company said in a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Cemex, the world’s third-largest cement maker, extended its $11.7 billion hostile takeover bid for Australia’s Rinker Group by two months while it waits for U.S. regulatory approval. Cemex’s $13-a-share offer for Australia’s biggest building materials company will now end March 30, the Monterrey, Mexico-based company said in a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange Tuesday.

headline.main: Cemex Extends Rinker Bid

abstract: Royal Dutch Shell, Europe’s biggest oil company, raised a bid to buy out its Canadian unit by 13 percent to 8.7 billion Canadian dollars ($7.4 billion) to gain increased production from oil sands. Shell, which owns 78 percent of Shell Canada, raised its bid to 45 Canadian dollars a share, from an offer of 40 Canadian dollars a share made in October.

Shell, which owns 78 percent of Shell Canada, raised its bid to 45 Canadian dollars a share, from an offer of 40 Canadian dollars a share made in October.

headline.main: Shell Ups Bid for Canadian Unit

abstract: Carlyle Group‘s Asian arm is poised to realize a huge gain on an investment in China’s electronic advertising market. Carlyle is preparing to sell 10 million of the 22.5 million ordinary shares it owns in Shanghai-based Focus Media Holdings, China’s biggest purveyor of advertising on flat-panel television screens in upscale office buildings, hotels, airports and similar settings, according to a recent Securities and Exchange Commission filing.
lead_paragraph: Carlyle Group‘s Asian arm is poised to realize a huge gain on an investment in China’s electronic advertising market. Carlyle is preparing to sell 10 million of the 22.5 million ordinary shares it owns in Shanghai-based Focus Media Holdings, China’s biggest purveyor of advertising on flat-panel television screens in upscale office buildings, hotels, airports and similar settings, according to a recent Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline.main: Carlyle Plans Focus Share Sale

abstract: A British buyout firm, Candover, beat two rivals Apax Partners and CVC Capital Partners in the the auction for a Spanish theme park operator, Parques Reunidos, with a pitch The Deal.com said was worth more than 900 million euros ($1.2 billion). Candover bid in a consortium with a British operator of trailer parks and family holidays, Bourne Leisure, which is taking a substantial minority stake in the business.

headline.main: Candover Wins Race for Spanish Theme Park

abstract: Bank of America and Wachovia, two of the nation’s largest banks, said Tuesday that their profits rose sharply in the fourth quarter compared with the same period a year earlier. Results at both banks were helped by major acquisitions in 2006. Bank of America, which bought the credit-card giant MBNA last year, said its net income rose 47 percent, to $5.26 billion, in the fourth quarter. Wachovia, which picked up Golden West Financial, said its fourth-quarter profit increased 35 percent, to $2.3 billion.

Wachovia, which picked up Golden West Financial, said its fourth-quarter profit increased 35 percent, to $2.3 billion.

headline.main: Profit Jumps at BofA, Wachovia

abstract: The management shuffle at Citigroup, the second shake-up in a little more than a month, raises questions about the bank’s ability to turn itself around, The New York Times says. The ouster of Todd S. Thomson, as head of global wealth management, and the shift of Sallie L. Krawcheck from the post of chief financial officer to that of Mr. Thomson, comes amid years of lackluster operating results and a languishing stock price under its chief executive, Charles O. Prince III. And it now leaves Citigroup looking to fill two significant executive posts.

Prince III. And it now leaves Citigroup looking to fill two significant executive posts.

headline.main: New Shuffle Roils Waters at Citigroup

abstract: Equity Office Properties, which agreed in November to be bought by a private equity company, the Blackstone Group, for $36 billion, including debt, said Monday that it would begin discussions with a rival group that has offered to top that price. Equity Office, the nation’s largest office landlord, with 585 buildings in 24 metropolitan areas, also said it would open its books to the challengers, a consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust.
lead_paragraph: Equity Office Properties, which agreed in November to be bought by a private equity company, the Blackstone Group, for $36 billion, including debt, said Monday that it would begin discussions with a rival group that has offered to top that price. Equity Office, the nation’s largest office landlord, with 585 buildings in 24 metropolitan areas, also said it would open its books to the challengers, a consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust.

headline.main: Equity Office to Consider Another Takeover Bid

abstract: Congressional lawmakers fear a merger between US Airways and Delta Air Lines would trigger wider consolidation and leave consumers with less service and higher fares. But interviews with key members, their staff, lobbyists, and consultants ahead of Wednesday’s Senate Commerce Committee hearing on the hostile proposal found no consensus in Congress that lawmakers should oppose the $10.5 billion deal.
lead_paragraph: Congressional lawmakers fear a merger between US Airways and Delta Air Lines would trigger wider consolidation and leave consumers with less service and higher fares. But interviews with key members, their staff, lobbyists, and consultants ahead of Wednesday’s Senate Commerce Committee hearing on the hostile proposal found no consensus in Congress that lawmakers should oppose the $10.5 billion deal.

headline.main: Congress Remains Wary of Airline Mergers

abstract: Steve Case, the co-founder of America Online, launched a Web service on Monday to provide medical information and help with insurance to customers. The site, RevolutionHealth.com, will provide ratings for doctors, hospitals and different treatment options. Co-founders of the site include the former Secretary of State Colin Powell, Hewlett-Packard‘s former chief executive Carly Fiorina, Fannie Mae‘s former chairman Franklin Raines and a venture capitalist, Jim Barksdale, Mr. Case said.

headline.main: AOL Co-Founder Starts Up Medical Site

abstract: American Express, the financial and travel services company, reported Monday that stronger holiday shopping and a reduction in bankruptcy write-offs helped lift fourth-quarter profit by 24 percent. The company reported a profit of $922 million, or 75 cents a share, for the quarter, compared with $745 million, or 59 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue increased 13 percent, to $7.21 billion from $6.38 billion.

Revenue increased 13 percent, to $7.21 billion from $6.38 billion.

headline.main: New Bankruptcy Law Aids American Express

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission declined to take a stand on Monday on a request from Hewlett-Packard to exclude from its proxy ballot a proposal from some shareholders that would give them more power to nominate directors.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission declined to take a stand on Monday on a request from Hewlett-Packard to exclude from its proxy ballot a proposal from some shareholders that would give them more power to nominate directors.

headline.main: S.E.C. Is Silent on H.P. Proxy Fight

abstract: Gap‘s decision to push out its chief executive, Paul S. Pressler, clears the way for potential buyers to install their own C.E.O. at the struggling retail chain, The New York Times reports. Mr. Pressler stepped down Monday after Gap’s third dismal holiday shopping season in what the company described as a “mutual” decision. Several private equity groups have approached Millard S. Drexler, the former chief executive who was ousted to make way for Mr. Pressler, about running the company after a sale, a person briefed on the matter told The Times. But Mr. Drexler, whose runaway success at J. Crew has haunted Gap’s board, has told the investment firms that he has no interest in returning to Gap, this person said.

But Mr. Drexler, whose runaway success at J. Crew has haunted Gap’s board, has told the investment firms that he has no interest in returning to Gap, this person said.

headline.main: As Gap’s C.E.O. Leaves, Buyout Firms Circle

abstract: As the deadline to submit second-round bids for 18 Time Inc. titles expired Monday, up to six companies have emerged as competitors, The New York Post reported. Among the likely bidders are Sweden’s Bonnier Publications; the Quadrangle Group backing a former Wenner Media executive; Boston Ventures, supporting a former Time Inc. executive vice president; Intermedia Advisors; and Active Media in conjunction with Windpoint Partners. Also in the hunt for at least some of the titles is Elevation Partners, the private-equity firm founded by Roger McNamee and the U2 frontman Bono.
lead_paragraph: As the deadline to submit second-round bids for 18 Time Inc. titles expired Monday, up to six companies have emerged as competitors, The New York Post reported. Also in the hunt for at least some of the titles is Elevation Partners, the private-equity firm founded by Roger McNamee and the U2 frontman Bono.

headline.main: Time Inc. Magazines Auction Lures More Bidders

abstract: As New York’s attorney general, he was one of the most ardent defenders of heightened securities regulation. As the state’s new governor, however, Eliot Spitzer may be backtracking, or at least that is the suggestion of Tuesday’s article in The New York Post. Joining Sen. Chuck Schumer and New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday as they presented a new plan to streamline regulations, Mr. Spitzer said that he will do what it takes to keep Wall Street at the top of global finance.

abstract: The World Economic Forum theme seems especially apt this year. As the conference begins discussing “the shifting power equation” on Wednesday, some of the brightest lights from previous years won’t be on hand to contribute their views. Who’s out? Former President Bill Clinton, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Angelina Jolie, for starters. Who’s in? Nguyen Tan Dung, the prime minster of Vietnam.

lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — The first thing I noticed as the bus approached Davos for this year’s World Economic Forum was how green and beautiful the hillsides are. There are patches of snow, but it looked like a magnificent spring.

abstract: As part of our effort to open up the World Economic Forum and move the discussion beyond the confines of Davos, we are asking readers to weigh in on some of the big questions being addressed at this week’s conference. We encourage you to share your views in what we are calling Davos Dialogue.

abstract: In a quick turnaround, the Building Materials Corporation of America raised its offer for ElkCorp, a roofing products maker, to $43.50 a share, ElkCorp said in a regulatory filing. The increased offer extends a months-long battle with the Carlyle Group, which raised its offer to $42 on Monday, matching Building Materials’ previous bid. ElkCorp had previously recommended that shareholders accept the Carlyle offer.

ElkCorp had previously recommended that shareholders accept the Carlyle offer.

headline.main: Building Materials Re-Raises ElkCorp Bid

abstract: The VF Corporation said Tuesday that it would sell its intimate apparel business to Berkshire Hathaway‘s Fruit of the Loom for $350 million in cash as it focuses on more profitable businesses like outdoor clothing. VF, which owns Wrangler jeans and North Face outerwear, said the unit booked more than $800 million in revenue in 2006. It expects the deal to close in the first quarter of 2007, and that it would take a loss of $45 million from the loss of the unit. VF plans to use the proceeds to fund a share buyback this year.
lead_paragraph: The VF Corporation said Tuesday that it would sell its intimate apparel business to Berkshire Hathaway‘s Fruit of the Loom for $350 million in cash as it focuses on more profitable businesses like outdoor clothing. VF, which owns Wrangler jeans and North Face outerwear, said the unit booked more than $800 million in revenue in 2006. It expects the deal to close in the first quarter of 2007, and that it would take a loss of $45 million from the loss of the unit. VF plans to use the proceeds to fund a share buyback this year.

headline.main: VF Sheds Intimate Apparel Business

abstract: Scoring an invitation to the World Economic Forum is a coup in itself. Even tougher, though, is getting on the list for the dozens of exclusive soirees that participants host themselves here at Davos. Perhaps the hottest ticket this year is a private breakfast Saturday morning hosted by Bill and Melinda Gates. Mr. Gates, Microsoft‘s founder, and his wife will have a fireside chat about philanthropy with Tom Friedman of The New York Times acting as moderator.

abstract: Where are the snows of yesteryear? That is a question that many attendees of this year’s conference are pondering as they arrive in Davos and notice that the scenery looks a lot less wintery than in previous years. Coincidentally or not, the strange weather comes as Davos has put the issue of climate change high on its agenda, scheduling 17 sessions to discuss it.

abstract: Regulators should hold off on ruling how the New York Stock Exchange charges for its market data until questions about its new status as a for-profit group are resolved, the Securities Industry and Financial Markets association, a Wall Street lobbying group, has asked. The NYSE Group, which owns the exchange, is preparing to charge fees for access to ArcaBook, the real-time market data system the exchange picked up when it merged with Archipelago Holdings last year. Among the offerings the market is planning is real-time share-price data to Web sites like Google and CNBC, in return for a flat fee.

abstract: Consider what happens when a hedge fund buys stock in a company — giving it voting rights in various matters of importance to all shareholders — but then uses other investments to reduce or cancel out the economic risk associated with the holding. Paul Atkins, a commissioner at the Securities and Exchange Commission, said this common situation could raise concerns as some corporate-governance groups seek to give shareholders greater influence in a proxy vote. He told The Financial Times that hedge funds “have used financial derivatives to influence the voting for acquisitions but where they don’t have the economic interest.”

abstract: Those who thought that American investment bankers were clothes horses — recall those who dress like Patrick Bateman of “American Psycho” — may be in for a surprise, according to Reuters. British financiers are even more concerned about their appearance. Bankers in the City of London are every bit the peacock, according to one of their female colleagues. In fact, she told the news service, “they may care more than women.”

abstract: After an earlier offer received a cool reception from minority shareholders, Royal Dutch Shell increased its bid for the portion of Shell Canada it does not own to 45 Canadian dollars ($38.10) a share from 40 Canadian dollars. The new offer values the 22 percent of Shell Canada not held by the parent company at 8.7 billion Canadian dollars ($7.4 billion). About 150,000 barrels of Shell Canada’s daily production of 230,000 barrels comes from oil sands projects in Alberta rather than conventional sources. When it made its opening bid in October, Royal Dutch Shell said that full control of Shell Canada would allow it to increase its reported reserves. An accounting problem forced the parent company to lower its reserve levels in 2004. The higher bid still may face difficulty since some Canadian fund managers have said recently that they are looking for a price near 50 Canadian dollars a share.

Cemex wants to buy Rinker because of its business in the United States, which is focused on Florida, Arizona and Nevada. The deal would make Cemex, which is based in Mexico, the world’s biggest concrete maker.

headline.main: Mexico: Cemex Extends Bid for Australian Company

abstract: Man dropped its 10.3 billion euro ($13.4 billion) hostile bid for the Swedish truck maker Scania after opposition emerged from Volkswagen, Scania’s largest shareholder, and will seek a friendly merger instead. Man, Volkswagen and Scania “see the industrial logic behind a combination” of the three businesses, but such a combination is not possible under the existing offer, Man said. A combined Man and Scania, the Swedish truck maker, would surpass DaimlerChrysler and Volvo as Europe’s No. 1 maker of heavy vehicles. Volkswagen, based in Wolfsburg, Germany, said it wanted to wrap its Brazilian truck unit into a Scania-MAN combination to compete with DaimlerChrysler and Volvo. Man is based in Germany.

abstract: With New York’s dominance as the world’s financial center being threatened by the likes of London and Hong Kong, some are beginning to wonder if Silicon Valley is next on the hit-list of American corporate mainstays. A technology and media conference being held in Munich this week provided ample evidence that Silicon Valley’s dominance of Internet-style technology innovation is waning, according to The New York Times. The gathering, Digital Life Design, has become a showcase for a range of European entrepreneurs who have taken the start-up culture pioneered in Silicon Valley as a template and are successfully transplanting it across the Atlantic.

abstract: A federal jury in Denver agreed Tuesday with a former top auditor for the Interior Department that Kerr-McGee had cheated the government out of millions of dollars in royalties on oil it produced in publicly owned coastal waters. The decision, reached by the jury after deliberations of about four hours, is a vindication for the auditor, Bobby L. Maxwell. He became a whistle-blower and sued Kerr-McGee as a private citizen after top officials at the Interior Department ordered him to drop his audit findings.

headline.main: Kerr-McGee Is Found Liable in Lawsuit Over Oil Royalties

abstract: The battle over Equity Office Properties is sweet vindication for its founder, Samuel Zell, who has long argued that Wall Street has not given his company the respect it deserved. Many analysts have been scornful, or at best skeptical, of the Chicago real estate magnate’s strategy of creating a national brand of office buildings scattered among 37 metropolitan areas. But the bidding war by Vornado Realty Trust and the acquisition-hungry private equity firm Blackstone Group seems to be showing them up.

abstract: The Warner Music Group and Sony BMG have signed a deal to develop technology for distributing music downloads and multimedia entertainment to wireless customers throughout China and other Asia-Pacific markets. The two music companies are investing an undisclosed amount in Access China Media Solutions, a partnership created by Tokyo-based Access and Melodeo of Seattle. Western companies looking to enter China’s music market have had to navigate piracy-laden territory and the deal represents the music major’s efforts to encourage the growth a legitimate music business.

abstract: Broadcom said Henry T. Nicholas III, its co-founder and former chief executive, bore “significant responsibility” for improperly backdated stock options that led it to disclose $2.2 billion in unreported expenses on Tuesday. The computer-chip maker restated earnings to take the huge noncash charge, the largest reported so far by any of the nearly 200 companies caught up in the scandal over manipulating the timing of option grants.

abstract: Michael Eisner and Jann Wenner, who once joined forces to save a celebrity magazine, are about to reunite in the world of Internet video. Wenner Media and Veoh Networks announced a partnership Monday between Usmagazine.com, the Web site for Wenner’s Us Weekly, and Veoh.com, a video-sharing Web site and a competitor of YouTube.com, to create a celebrity entertainment channel on Veoh. Mr. Wenner leads the privately owned Wenner Media, while Mr. Eisner, the former chief executive of Walt Disney, is a major investor in Veoh and brokered the deal.

Mason Capital Management, a New York-based hedge fund, said it had increased its stake to 9.5 percent from 8 percent and might seek board seats at Internet Capital.

abstract: For undergraduates majoring in business, intersession — the time after January exams, but before the commence of the second semester — is apparently not the hibernating, beer-guzzling extravaganza that their less-finance minded peers appear to be enjoying. At least some of the college students gearing up for a career in banking use the vacation to get a head start on the competitive summer internship process with a whirlwind tour of some of New York’s most prestigious investment banks, according to BusinessWeek, which sent a reporter along with the students to check out the pitches the banks are giving. Advil, it seems, is a necessary component.

abstract: Wm. Wrigley Jr., the world’s largest chewing-gum maker, agreed to buy 80 percent of Russia’s A. Korkunov for $300 million in its first acquisition of a chocolate company. Closely held A. Korkunov, which was founded in 1999 by a pair of entrepreneurs, makes bonbons and chocolate bars and is Russia’s seventh-biggest chocolate maker. It had 2006 sales of $100 million, Chicago-based Wrigley said.

abstract: AMR plans to issue and sell 13 million shares of stock, an offering that would bring the parent of American Airlines about $500 million based on its offering price Tuesday of $38.70 a share.The company plans to use some of the proceeds to help pay off debt. Underwriters Credit Suisse, UBS and Merrill Lynch will also have a 30-day option to purchase an additional 1.95 million shares to cover any overallotments.

abstract: Conrad Black will be tried along with co-defendants when his criminal trial begins in Chicago next month, and “appropriate” instructions will be given to the jury to avoid “spill-over guilt,” the judge presiding over the case has ruled. Judge Amy St. Eve said that “because the counts are properly joined and because defendants have failed to establish any prejudice that would require severance, the court denies their respective motions to sever.”

abstract: Kraft Foods said Tuesday it would sell its hot cereal business, including the popular Cream of Wheat products, to a subsidiary of B&G Foods for $200 million. “Our decision to sell Cream of Wheat is part of a broader effort at Kraft to focus our portfolio,” Rick Searer, president of Kraft’s North America commercial segment, said in a statement.

abstract: Williams-Sonoma, the owner of kitchenware stores and the Pottery Barn home decor retail chain, denied Tuesday it had hired Goldman Sachs or any other investment bank to explore strategic options, calling it an “absolutely incorrect” rumor. Williams-Sonoma, whose shares rose more than 3 percent in after-hours trading following a Reuters report that the company had hired the investment bank, said in a statement it generally does not comment on market speculation, but it felt compelled to do so in this case because “this rumor is absolutely incorrect.”

abstract: The buyout firm Newbridge Capital agreed to take control of Union Insurance of Taiwan, part of the troubled Rebar Asia Pacific Group, for $100 million, Union Insurance said. Union will use the money to increase its capital, and Newbridge, which will receive at least 50 percent of the company’s stock in exchange, would become its controlling shareholder after the deal, Union Insurance said.

abstract: The Tokyo and New York stock exchanges are in the final stages of alliance talks and may come to an agreement as soon as the end of the month, the head of the Tokyo exchange told The Wall Street Journal. Taizo Nishimuro, president of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, said the two exchanges may make an announcement on their tie-up details after a planned two-day trip to New York starting next Tuesday.

abstract: The investing arms of Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are working on a $15 billion private-equity play for the oil-and-gas assets of the utility company Dominion Resources, The Wall Street Journal reported. Goldman and Morgan are said to be part of a consortium that includes the buyout shop Madison Dearborn Partners, Warburg Pincus, First Reserve and the Carlyle Group and its affiliate Riverstone Holdings. The Journal said that it may end up bidding against a rival consortium, made up of Blackstone Group, Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which is also exploring an offer.

abstract: Yet another media mogul has reportedly entered the fray for Tribune, Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation, whose holdings include Fox News and The New York Post. Mr. Murdoch’s goal, according to The New York Times, is to gain a stake in Newsday, the Long Island newspaper in Melville that is owned by Tribune, so that he can combine its back-office functions with those of the money losing Post as a way to cut costs.
lead_paragraph: Yet another media mogul has reportedly entered the fray for Tribune, Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation, whose holdings include Fox News and The New York Post. Mr. Murdoch’s goal, according to The New York Times, is to gain a stake in Newsday, the Long Island newspaper in Melville that is owned by Tribune, so that he can combine its back-office functions with those of the money losing Post as a way to cut costs.

headline.main: Will Murdoch Breathe Life into Tribune Auction?

abstract: Home Depot may pay its chief executive, Frank Blake $8.9 million this year, less than the $39.7 million it paid his predecessor, Robert Nardelli, who was ousted this month amid criticism of his compensation. abstract: Once again, the top New York law firms are leapfrogging each other to recruit talent by raising salary offers for first-year associates. The latest bump-up has attracted a lot of attention in legal circles, and raised some questions as well. For example: Will California firms follow? And what about the New York offices of California-based firms? Some of them are expected to come up with the extra cash — particularly the ones that consider themselves competitors with top firms either nationally or in New York.

abstract: This year’s overarching theme at Davos — the “shifting power equation” — apparently means many things to the throngs gathered here. For some, it crystallized a growing concern that established institutions are losing power. Rogue states and nonstate actors threaten disorder on the global stage, which could take the form of weapons proliferation, terrorism or the spread of AIDS and other deadly diseases. These threats “create an environment in which the things we treasure cannot prosper,” Richard N. Haas, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, said in a panel Wednesday called “The Shifting Power Equation: Geopolitics.”

abstract: Buyout firms often pool their resources together to make astronomical takeover offers for companies. But now it seems many of the biggest names in private equity are forming a consortium for a different reason. Reuters reports that about 800 people from throughout finance are stopping by London Wednesday evening to raise money for the Private Equity Foundation, a new nonprofit aimed at funding charities. Among those involved are top figures from the Blackstone Group, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital, Permira Advisors and Texas Pacific Group, many scheduled to appear at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

abstract: The boom in private equity will end either when big deals start to collapse or when banks start putting the squeeze on loans. Both stockholders and strategic buyers, Mr. Primack believes, are already starting to see private equity offers as being too low.

abstract: The fight over US Airways‘ proposed $9.8 billion takeover of bankrupt Delta Air Lines moved on Wednesday to Capitol Hill, where lawmakers questioned the top executives of both companies about what the deal would mean for consumers. US Airways’ chairman, W. Douglas Parker, defended the proposed bid, telling the Senate Commerce Committee that lower costs and operational efficiencies would cut fares in “dozens of new markets” for passengers. But Delta’s chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, said fares would not go down because the two airlines directly compete in many markets.

abstract: GLG Partners, a European hedge fund manager, and Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, were fined by the French market regulator for trading abuses stemming from a convertible bond sale in 2002. The regulator, the Autorité des Marchés Financiers, fined GLG 1.2 million euros ($1.6 million) for using privileged information before a convertible bond sale by the telecommunications-equipment manufacturer Alcatel in December 2002, the regulator said. The agency fined Deutsche Bank 300,000 euros for not abiding by rules when sounding out investors before the sale, according to the report.

abstract: The British economy grew at the fastest rate since 2004 in the fourth quarter as the financial-services boom in London created jobs and pushed house prices to a record. Gross domestic product increased 0.8 percent from the previous three months, the most since the second quarter of 2004, the Office for National Statistics said. The annual growth rate increased to 3 percent from 2.9 percent. Accelerating growth in the economy drove inflation to the highest in 10 years in December, prompting the Bank of England to raise its benchmark rate in January.

abstract: An Irish media tycoon, Tony O’Reilly, has renewed an attempt to take complete control of APN News and Media of Australia. Mr. O’Reilly, who already owns 40 percent of APN, teamed his Independent News and Media, which is based in Dublin, with the Carlyle Group, the buyout group in Washington, and Providence Equity Partners, an investment firm in Providence, R.I. His group bid 3.4 billion Australian dollars ($2.65 billion) for APN. Mr. O’Reilly first teamed with Providence to buy the rest of the media group in October. Those talks were abandoned in November. APN owns regional newspapers in Australia and New Zealand and operates 125 radio stations in the two nations, with Clear Channel Communications.

abstract: China’s economy grew 10.7 percent in 2006, closing in on Germany as the world’s third largest, fueled by investment in manufacturing and a boom in exports. Gross domestic product expanded to 20.94 trillion yuan ($2.69 trillion) after growing 10.4 percent in 2005, Xie Fuzhan, chief of the National Bureau of Statistics, said in Beijing. China’s economy expanded at more than twice the global average as record exports swelled foreign-currency reserves to more than $1 trillion. Premier Wen Jiabao wants to increase consumer spending to reduce the country’s reliance on shipments overseas and avoid igniting investment bubbles.

abstract: The practical effects of climate change continue to be the issue du jour here, if only because the weather seems to be making everyone’s trip to Davos difficult. The British opposition leader, David Cameron, arrived late Wednesday for a climate chnage dinner after his journey from London was disrupted by bad weather. Mr. Cameron said he had even tried to beat the delays by riding to Heathrow on the back of a motorcycle. Britain has been at the forefront of the climate change debate, but may have problems coping with hostile weather patterns.

abstract: Siemens, the German engineering company, agreed Wednesday to buy the software maker UGS for $3.5 billion, including debt, and separately announced plans to spin off its VDO automotive unit. Siemens said it would retain a majority stake in VDO, which makes electronic systems that help deploy air bags. The purchase and spinoff would accelerate an overhaul started by the chief executive, Klaus Kleinfeld. He shed the company’s mobile phone unit and is combining the communications network division with that of Nokia.

abstract: The Irish billionaire Tony O’Reilly revived his 3.8 billion Australian dollars ($2.97 billion) takeover offer for APN News & Media, Australia’s fourth-largest media company, after luring the Carlyle Group to his buyout group. The bidders, led by Mr. O’Reilly’s Independent News & Media, offered 6.05 Australian dollars a share for the 60 percent of APN it does not already own. But shares of the publisher of the New Zealand Herald closed unchanged at 6.15 Australian dollars Thursday, signaling the group, which includes Providence Equity Partners, may have to increase its offer.

abstract: Hewlett-Packard is once again at the center of a cloak-and-dagger brouhaha. A former Hewlett executive accused by the company of stealing trade secrets is now saying that he was instructed by the company’s management to spy on a rival, Dell, CNet News.com reported. Karl Kamb, Hewlett’s former vice president of business development and strategy, was named as a defendant in a federal lawsuit filed by the computer maker in 2005 alleging that he used trade secrets to launch a rival flat-screen TV company of his own while still on the payroll.

abstract: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that collapsed last year after losing more than $6 billion in energy markets, has returned more than half of its remaining capital, MarketWatch reports, citing a letter the firm sent to investors earlier this month. Almost 55 percent to 60 percent of the firm’s capital as of Sept. 30 was returned during the fourth quarter through investor redemptions and withdrawals, Amaranth’s founder, Nick Maounis, wrote in the letter obtained by MarketWatch. Apparently favorable market conditions allowed Amaranth to sell a swath of its remaining positions without incurring large losses.

headline.main: Amaranth Returns Chunk of Capital to Investors, Report Says

abstract: Endesa, the target of a 36.5 billion euro ($47.4 billion) takeover battle, beat its 2006 profit forecast and laid out profit estimates for the next three years including a higher goal for 2009, days before the German utility E.ON and Gas Natural were to make their final offers. Net income was 2.95 billion euros, or $3.82 billion, topping the 2.9 billion euros that Endesa forecast in July, according to preliminary earnings reported in a filing Wednesday. The strong earnings puts pressure on the bidders to table richer offers.

The strong earnings puts pressure on the bidders to table richer offers.

abstract: Delphi said it had signed an agreement for an investment of up to $3.4 billion by a bloc of funds that will take a controlling stake in the auto parts maker as it emerges from bankruptcy. The bankruptcy court overseeing Delphi’s reorganization approved the equity investment plan earlier this month over the objections of the hedge fund Highland Capital Management, which offered a rival $4.7 billion reorganization plan. Delphi said Tuesday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had signed the agreement cleared by the court with investors led by Appaloosa Management and Cerberus Capital Management last Thursday.

abstract: There was much ado in the press about German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s speech at the World Economic Forum on Wednesday, with several reports focusing on her stance on hedge funds. Ms. Merkel said proposals to shed more light on hedge funds’ operations would be a priority for her leadership of the Group of Eight industrial nations this year. “We want to minimize the systemic risks in international capital markets and to raise their transparency — above all, I see the need to catch up with hedge funds,” she said.

Shell Canada outlined Wednesday even more ambitious plans for its exploitation of the resource.

Meruelo Maddux sold 40 million shares at $10 each, well below the $12 to $14 a share the company was seeking. The stock was to begin trading Thursday on Nasdaq under the symbol MMPI.

abstract: GLG Partners, a European hedge fund manager, and Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, were fined by the French market regulator for trading abuses stemming from a convertible bond sale in 2002. The regulator, the Autorité des Marchés Financiers, fined GLG 1.2 million euros ($1.6 million) for using privileged information before a convertible bond sale by the telecom-equipment manufacturer Alcatel in December 2002, the regulator said. The agency fined Deutsche Bank 300,000 euros for not abiding by rules when sounding out investors before the sale, according to the report.
lead_paragraph: GLG Partners, a European hedge fund manager, and Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, were fined by the French market regulator for trading abuses stemming from a convertible bond sale in 2002. The regulator, the Autorité des Marchés Financiers, fined GLG 1.2 million euros ($1.6 million) for using privileged information before a convertible bond sale by the telecom-equipment manufacturer Alcatel in December 2002, the regulator said. The agency fined Deutsche Bank 300,000 euros for not abiding by rules when sounding out investors before the sale, according to the report.

headline.main: GLG and Deutsche Fined by French Regulators

abstract: The opening of Time Warner Cable shares on the public market faces yet another delay after a federal judge on Wednesday blocked Adelphia Communications, the cable television company, from moving ahead with its $15 billion plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection. The judge granted a request by an 11-member bondholder group, which includes Lehman Brothers and Bank of America, to appeal the Jan. 3 order approving the reorganization plan which they say undervalues their claims.

abstract: Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, made more than $48 million last year, an increase of 30 percent from 2005, the company said Wednesday in a regulatory filing. Mr. O’Neal received $700,000 in salary for 2006, a cash bonus of $18.5 million and stock valued at $28.8 million. The previous year, Merrill gave Mr. O’Neal $37 million in salary and bonuses.

abstract: Hedge fund money, which now exceeds $1 trillion, has emerged in the last several years as a potentially powerful force in politics, as underscored by the significant role it is playing in the presidential aspirations of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rudolph W. Giuliani, The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. says. During the 2006 election cycle, executives who work at the 30 biggest hedge funds made $2.8 million in contributions to political candidates or party committees, almost double the amount in 2000.

abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg’s Starr International will take a 50 percent stake in a 1 billion yuan ($129 million) private-equity fund to invest in Chinese companies. In the first confirmed investment in China since he was ousted from the American International Group, Mr. Greenberg’s company will invest alongside state-owned Citic Securities, China’s biggest publicly traded broker. During his tenure at AIG, Mr. Greenberg, who ran the insurance giant for 38 years before getting the boot, won the first insurance license in China for an overseas company since the country’s communist revolution in 1949.

headline.main: Greenberg Invests in China Buyout Fund

abstract: Venture capitalists may have a new ally in their rush to invest in clean technologies: President Bush. As the president outlined an aggressive plan to reduce gasoline use by 20 percent within a decade through a mandatory fuels standard in his State of the Union speech, several V.C.’s said that their investments in ethanol and other environmentally friendly fuels could pay off — and help the United States meet that goal. Companies like Khosla Ventures invested more than $2.9 billion in clean tech in 2006, according to the Cleantech Venture Network.

abstract: The American Stock Exchange said Thursday it had hired the investment bank Morgan Stanley to advise it on a demutualization plan, which would convert it to a for-profit corporation, as well as “potential strategic future initiatives.” Demutualization could be a step toward an initial public offering of the exchange.

abstract: The Blackstone Group increased its offer for Equity Office Properties Trust to $38.3 billion, or $54 a share, in cash, escalating the stakes in the pitched battle for the country’s largest office landlord. The new offer trumps a rival $37.6 billion, $52-a-share bid by a real estate consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust made earlier this month. Analysts and industry watchers had expected the private equity giant to top the Vornado group’s bid, as the agreement it reached with Equity Office last November — for $48.50 a share — allowed Blackstone to match rival offers. If completed, the offer would set a record for a leveraged buyout.
lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group increased its offer for Equity Office Properties Trust to $38.3 billion, or $54 a share, in cash, escalating the stakes in the pitched battle for the country’s largest office landlord. The new offer trumps a rival $37.6 billion, $52-a-share bid by a real estate consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust made earlier this month. Analysts and industry watchers had expected the private equity giant to top the Vornado group’s bid, as the agreement it reached with Equity Office last November — for $48.50 a share — allowed Blackstone to match rival offers. If completed, the offer would set a record for a leveraged buyout.

headline.main: Blackstone Raises Equity Office Bid to $38.3 Billion

abstract: As many of the world’s buyout kings were gathered in Davos, Switzerland, to mix with leaders and moguls at the World Economic Forum, their attention turned to an audacious move by someone in their midst. Stephen Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group, who was seen casually roaming the halls of the convention center earlier in the day showing little sign of what was to come, and his firm announced Thursday that they had raised their bid for Equity Office Properties Trust to $38.3 billion, including debt, making the biggest leveraged buyout in history even bigger. Blackstone increased its offer to $54 a share from its previous bid of $48.50, leapfrogging a $52-per-share offer from a rival bidding group led by Vornado Realty Trust.
lead_paragraph: As many of the world’s buyout kings were gathered in Davos, Switzerland, to mix with leaders and moguls at the World Economic Forum, their attention turned to an audacious move by someone in their midst. Blackstone increased its offer to $54 a share from its previous bid of $48.50, leapfrogging a $52-per-share offer from a rival bidding group led by Vornado Realty Trust.

headline.main: Buyout Showdown Wows Davos Dealmakers

abstract: Shortly after a German competitor dropped its hostile bid, the Swedish truck maker Scania reported healthy profits for last year, giving it a position of strength to negotiate a better deal, the Financial Times reported Thursday. The German company, MAN, dropped its 10.3 billion euro ($13.4 billion) hostile bid earlier this week and instead proposed a friendlier alliance. But one of Scania’s largest shareholders, the Investor holding vehicle of Sweden’s Wallenberg family, insisted that the company could “stand alone.” Scania posted an operating income of 8.75 million krona, up 28 percent for the year.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after a German competitor dropped its hostile bid, the Swedish truck maker Scania reported healthy profits for last year, giving it a position of strength to negotiate a better deal, the Financial Times reported Thursday. But one of Scania’s largest shareholders, the Investor holding vehicle of Sweden’s Wallenberg family, insisted that the company could “stand alone.” Scania posted an operating income of 8.75 million krona, up 28 percent for the year.

headline.main: Scania’s Profits Shore Up Bargaining Position with MAN

abstract: Deutsche Bank will acquire a minority stake in a boutique asset management firm specializing in private-equity investments, the investment bank said Thursday. The two will work together to create private-equity fund of funds products, Deutsche’s press release said. Both firms expect the deal to close in the first half of 2007.

abstract: France’s Pernod Ricard is interested in buying Swedish state-owned vodka Absolut when it comes up for sale, while talks on acquiring the Stolichnaya brand outside Russia continue, the company said on Thursday. When asked at a briefing in London if Pernod was interested in buying Vin & Sprit‘s Absolut, managing director Pierre Pringuet said “yes.” Absolut, known for its long-running, pun-filled ad campaign, is the world’s second-bestselling vodka after Diageo’s Smirnoff. Analysts have valued the brand at more than $4 billion.

Analysts have valued the brand at more than $4 billion.

abstract: Having been a player in one of the most dramatic stories of the dot-com boom and bust, Joe Kraus seems happy to be safely ensconced at the Internet giant Google. Mr. Kraus founded Excite, which went from a university-sponsored search engine to (as Excite@Home) one of the biggest names in the Internet business before its spectacular crash and burn at the turn of the latest century. He went on to found JotSpot, a maker of collaboration software that Google acquired in October.

abstract: Nearly half of the 49 hedge funds that had their headquarters in the Virgin Islands have left in the past two years. It’s not the heat or the bugs that sent them packing, but the Internal Revenue Service. A set of new laws and regulations have dashed the hopes of people who had counted on their Virgin Islands address cutting their tax bills by 90 percent. The I.R.S. suspects “rampant fraud,” according to a Bloomberg News account of the situation on St. Croix and other islands.

abstract: Bill Miller, the legendary stock picker who manages the Legg Mason Value Trust mutual fund, says he is often asked whether, on some level, he is relieved that his streak — 15 years of besting the Standard & Poor’s 500 — is over. “The answer is no,” he wrote in his latest letter to shareholders of the fund, which ended 2006 up 5.9 percent, far below the 15.8 percent gain in the S&P. He goes on to suggest that it is actually a silly question.

abstract: The once booming market for home loans to people with weak credit – known as subprime mortgages and made largely to minorities, the poor and first-time buyers stretching to afford a home – is coming under greater pressure. The evidence can be seen in rising default rates, increasingly strained finances at mortgage lenders and growing doubts among investors. Now, Wall Street firms, which had helped fuel the growth in the market by bankrolling and investing in subprime mortgage lenders, have begun to pinch off the money spigot.

Now, Wall Street firms, which had helped fuel the growth in the market by bankrolling and investing in subprime mortgage lenders, have begun to pinch off the money spigot.

headline.main: Tremors at the Door for Subprime Mortgage Lenders

abstract: Federal authorities have arrested a former treasurer of the media conglomerate NBC Universal on charges of stealing more than $800,000 to finance private jet flights, liquor and a vacation home. The former treasurer, Victor Jung, is charged in the indictment with two counts of wire fraud, according to the statement from the office of the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. He pleaded not guilty yesterday in federal court in Manhattan and was released on a $250,000 bond. “He plans to vigorously defend himself against these charges,” Mr. Jung’s lawyer, Christopher Brennan, told Reuters.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have arrested a former treasurer of the media conglomerate NBC Universal on charges of stealing more than $800,000 to finance private jet flights, liquor and a vacation home. The former treasurer, Victor Jung, is charged in the indictment with two counts of wire fraud, according to the statement from the office of the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. He pleaded not guilty yesterday in federal court in Manhattan and was released on a $250,000 bond. “He plans to vigorously defend himself against these charges,” Mr. Jung’s lawyer, Christopher Brennan, told Reuters.

headline.main: Ex-NBC Official Charged in Theft

abstract: Former Walt Disney Chairman and Chief Executive Michael Eisner has been exercising his deal-making skills since leaving the Mouse House more than a year ago. Through his investment vehicle Tornante, which is backed by the $1 billion he pocketed during his tenure at Disney, Mr. Eisner has been trying his hand at new media. He bought Team Baby Entertainment, which makes sport-themed DVDs for children, and, most recently, purchased in a a stake in YouTube challenger Veoh Networks.

abstract: A judge granted a request by former shareholders and investors suing Enron to drop several individuals and firms, including Enron’s late founder, Kenneth L. Lay, from the lawsuit. The regents of the University of California, the lead plaintiffs in securities litigation against Enron and several banks, asked for the dismissals last year. Judge Melinda Harmon of the U.S. District Court approved the request Wednesday in the class-action lawsuit.

abstract: Taking a page out of Delta Air Lines management’s playbook, the board of Midwest Air Group has recommended shareholders reject a buyout offer worth $345 million by AirTran Holdings, saying that it would be better off alone. The Milwaukee-based parent of Midwest Airlines said Thursday the board unanimously recommended that shareholders reject the revised $13.25-per-share offer and not tender their shares to AirTran.

abstract: One of the gazillion online video start-ups trying to take on YouTube has apparently come up with an new angle: serious thought. Instead of humorous videos of people dancing around their living rooms in their underpants, FORA.tv offers clips from a V.I.P. dinner the night of the State of the Union address, a talk by former President Jimmy Carter on C-SPAN and a presentation on global warming by a quantum physicist, CNEt News.com says.
