abstract: American Consolidated Media, a Dallas-based publisher of 40 local newspapers in Texas and Oklahoma, said Thursday that it has agreed to be acquired by Australia’s Macquarie Media for $80 million. The privately held newspaper group, whose owners include founder Jeremy Halbreich, BancBoston Ventures and Halyard Capital and Arena Capital Partner, will receive either cash or stock from the buyer, a subsidiary of Macquarie Bank.

abstract: Saskatchewan Wheat Pool added a cash component to its C$700 million ($591 million) hostile offer for Agricore United late Thursday in a move to persuade Agricore shareholders to back a proposed merger of Canada’s two biggest grain handlers. Under the new bid, Agricore shareholders may receive C$11.33 in cash or 1.3601 SaskPool shares or any combination of the two.

abstract: Pipeline giant Kinder Morgan‘s plan to go private through a $22 billion management-led buyout cleared a major regulatory hurdle Thursday when the Federal Trade Commission gave its blessing after settling antitrust issues that the agency said could have fueled higher gasoline prices in the Southeast. The F.T.C. approved the buyout on the condition that the Carlyle Group and Riverstone Holdings, two of the investment firms participating in the deal, become passive investors in Kinder Morgan competitor Magellan Midstream Partners.

headline.main: F.T.C. Approves Kinder Buyout, on One Condition

abstract: There’s no question that hedge funds and private equity investments have dominated the business headlines for the last year. But, asks Fortune, does that mean that individuals are actually flocking to these high-risk, high-return funds? The, answer, says the magazine: Not as much as you might think. It cites a recent study that shows that 40 percent of millionaire investors surveyed had no allocation whatsoever in alternative investments, including private equity, hedge funds and commodities.

headline.main: Many Who Can Invest in Hedge Funds Don’t

abstract: Eddie Bauer said Thursday that it delayed a shareholder meeting to vote on a $286 million buyout plan after finding tax accounting errors. The errors, which cover 2005 and earlier years, relate to the determination of deferred tax assets and goodwill on its balance sheets, arising from the treatment of leasehold improvements. In November, Eddie Bauer agreed to a buyout by private-equity firms Sun Capital Partners and Golden Gate Capital for $286 million, plus the assumption of $328 million in debt.

abstract: Discount brokerage Charles Schwab said Thursday that its chief financial officer since 1999, Christopher Dodds, will retire on May 18. Mr. Dodds, who is 47, joined the company in 1986. He will be succeeded by senior vice president and treasurer Joseph Martinetto. Forbes.com notes that Mr. Dodds is just the latest finance chief at a Wall Street firm to leave the post behind.

abstract: Lazard awarded Chairman and Chief Executive Bruce Wasserstein $18 million in restricted shares, 80 percent more than a year earlier, after the stock rose 48 percent in 2006, according to a federal filing. Mr. Wasserstein, received 359,425 shares on Jan. 23, when the stock closed at $50.08, the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission said. He can sell half of the shares on March 31, 2010, and the other half a year later.

abstract: As the biggest leveraged buyout ever got bigger Thursday when the Blackstone Group increased its bid for Equity Office Properties Trust to a whopping $54 a share, market watchers fell over themselves trying to guess if a consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust would be forced to up its bid. But even more than that, analysts and other industry watchers, who can sometimes take a been-there-done-that attitude toward bidding battles, seemed on the edge of their ringside seats, caught up in the high-stakes (and high-price) war for the nation’s largest office landlord, with nearly 600 buildings across the country.

Stockholm-based Investor and Morgan Stanley will buy the maker of surgical gloves from London-based Apax Partners. Investor said it is financing the purchase mainly with debt

abstract: What has become of the Sheriff of Wall Street? In what the New York Times’ Jenny Anderson describes as “an interesting about-face,” Eliot Spitzer, the newly-elected governor of New York, has added his voice to the growing battle cry that New York risks losing its pre-eminence if the Sarbanes-Oxley Act is not amended and litigation not curtailed. Interesting, Ms. Anderson says, because the enforcer turned laissez-faire governor was not long ago a prosecutor blazing through Wall Street’s boardrooms and ridiculing regulators for not cracking down enough.

abstract: The connection between the ouster of Todd S. Thomson, long viewed as a possible future chief executive of Citigroup, and his relationship with Maria Bartiromo, the popular CNBC anchor, has been the talk of the financial services community since the banking giant announced this week that Mr. Thomson would be leaving the company. Much ink has been spilled on reports of Citigroup executives being pushed off overseas flights on the corporate jet so that Mr. Thomson could fly alone with Ms. Bartiromo, expensive dinners at Daniel and other juicy tidbits.

abstract: Delta Air Lines‘s creditors may ask US Airways Group to extend the Feb. 1 deadline on its hostile takeover bid as they study competing plans for the bankrupt carrier’s future, Bloomberg News reported citing unnamed sources. The nine-member unsecured creditors committee is split between those favoring a quicker payback of their claims through a US Airways merger and those benefiting more if Delta stays independent, the unnamed sources said. An extension would give the creditors panel more time to debate US Airways’ merger plan as well as Atlanta-based Delta’s bid to leave bankruptcy as a stand-alone airline by mid-2007. Kelly Sullivan, a spokeswoman for US Air, said that the committee has not asked for an extension of the deadline.

An extension would give the creditors panel more time to debate US Airways’ merger plan as well as Atlanta-based Delta’s bid to leave bankruptcy as a stand-alone airline by mid-2007. Kelly Sullivan, a spokeswoman for US Air, said that the committee has not asked for an extension of the deadline.

headline.main: Delta Creditors May Ask US Airways to Extend Deadline

abstract: Nasdaq said it will not raise its 2.7 billion pounds ($5.3 billion) offer for London Stock Exchange, as the clock runs down on the bid. The U.S. stock market said Friday that the L.S.E. has not responded to its offer, and now “there is now insufficient time to effect any revision of the final offers via constructive dialogue.” Nasdaq had previously said it would only consider raising the bid if the British market’s board recommended the offer by Jan. 27. But the L.S.E. has repeated rejected the offer as inadequate.

The homebuilder’s chief executive, Bruce Karatz, stepped down in November after it was disclosed that he received favorably dated option awards.

abstract: There has been some grumbling on the ground here at Davos about this year’s celebrity-free (or nearly so) approach. “The no-celebrity thing was a big mistake,” one of the world’s largest financiers, who asked for anonymity, told The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin at a party sponsored by Forbes. “The celebs added a sense of energy and spice to the forum.”

abstract: Marsh & McLennan‘s chief executive, Michael Cherkasky, might yet throw a wrench into the insurance brokerage giant’s plans to sell its Putnam Investments unit. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Cherkasky said that he is keeping all options on the table — even backing away from selling the unit to Canada’s Power Corporation. Mr. Cherkasky told Reuters: “It is always complicated. It is a terrific company. … At the same time, if someone had the structure of a deal and the certainty for our shareholders, we would be interested. It is about weighing a number of factors.” Several analysts said they see an effort by Marsh to negotiate better terms from Power; specifics of that deal have not been publicly disclosed.

headline.main: Marsh Chief May Withdraw Putnam from Sale

abstract: France’s top soccer club, Olympique Lyonnais, plans to raise up to 103 million euros ($132.9 million) through the country’s first soccer-based I.P.O. soon, the Financial Times reported Friday. The Lyons-based club said that it hopes to sell up to 4.24 million new shares at 21 euros to 24.40 euros apiece. At the top end of the range, the I.P.O, would value parent company OL Group at 331 million euros, the paper said. The company’s two top shareholders, Chief Executive Jean-Michel Aulas and the French movie company Pathé, will retain control of the team.

abstract: A federal judge on Thursday dismissed a lawsuit against Hewlett-Packard by a former executive who claimed the computer maker obtained his phone records illegally. H.P. has accused Karl Lamb of stealing trade secrets to start up his own flat-panel display company. Mr. Lamb’s lawsuit briefly re-raised the specter of pretexting, or the obtaining of personal information under false pretenses. Former H.P. executives, including ex-chairwoman Patricia C. Dunn, still faces charges that they authorized private investigators to pretext board members and reporters in the course of a leak investigation.

abstract: The recent increase in private-equity deals in the technology sector raises what the Red Herring calls a “fundamental question”: Is private equity “good for an industry in which research and development, capital investment, and recruiting and retaining top talent are critical elements for long-term success?” It sounds like begging the question. Private equity players — “rightly or wrongly,” the Herring says — have a reputation for working against all those elements in one way or another, at least in the way they normally operate (piling on debt, slashing costs and taking a big payday for themselves upon their quick-as-possible exit).

abstract: In potentially another coup for Joe Perella, his boutique investment bank has snatched two high-level bankers from his old stomping grounds at Morgan Stanley, Reuters reported Friday. The newswire said that Perella Weinberg Partners had poached Scott Bruckner, who was co-head of the European technology group, and Arnaud Dassy, an executive director on the telecom team. Mr. Bruckner was to have transferred to New York from London to take the helm of the East Coast technology team.

abstract: In what is its really, truly, final offer, Nasdaq said Friday that it would extend its deadline for London Stock Exchange shareholders to accept its 2.7 billion pound ($5.3 billion) merger offer. That bid will now expire Feb. 10, pushed back from Feb. 1. Earlier Friday, the U.S. exchange said that it would not raise the price it was offering for its British counterpart. Now, Nasdaq cannot raise its offer unless the L.S.E. agrees, or if it comes in response to another party. The U.S. exchange already owns almost 30 percent of the L.S.E.; but under British law, if this deal fails it must wait six months before it can bid again.

abstract: Bank of America and Countrywide Financial have held discussions about an “alliance” that could eventually lead to an acquisition of Countrywide by Bank of America, The Financial Times reported Friday afternoon, citing unnamed sources. Such a deal would create the biggest mortgage lending group in the United States, joining Bank of America’s size and Countrywide’s significant lending business. Analysts said a Countrywide buyout could cost BofA about $30 billion.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America and Countrywide Financial have held discussions about an “alliance” that could eventually lead to an acquisition of Countrywide by Bank of America, The Financial Times reported Friday afternoon, citing unnamed sources. Analysts said a Countrywide buyout could cost BofA about $30 billion.

abstract: Facing heat from the United Auto Workers over proposed pay cuts, hedge fund Cerberus Capital Management may withdraw a planned $3.4 billion investment in Delphi, Bloomberg News reported Friday, citing unnamed sources. Cerberus, which agreed last month to lead an investment in the bankrupt auto parts maker, has been wrangling with the U.A.W. since then. If discussion stall, Delphi can ask a bankruptcy judge to void the union’s contract, potentially leading to a strike that would cripple Delphi’s biggest customer, General Motors.

abstract: ECONOMIC BAROMETERS Two critical economic events are scheduled to take place this week. First, on Wednesday, the Federal Open Market Committee is expected to meet and issue its decision on short-term interest rates; expectations are that the federal funds rate will remain at 5.25 percent. Investors have been hoping that rates would be lowered, but positive economic reports last week about new home sales and big factory orders have made that less likely. On Friday, the government is expected to report on unemployment for December, with forecasters predicting an increase of 140,000 jobs.

On Friday, the government is expected to report on unemployment for December, with forecasters predicting an increase of 140,000 jobs.

abstract: The Altria Group will formally announce its plan to spin off its Kraft Foods unit Wednesday, according to The Financial Times, marking the end of a 20-year era marked by tobacco litigation. Altria, which acquired Kraft in 1988 for $13.1 billion cash, will release details of what will be one of the largest tax-free corporate spin-offs on the day it reports fourth-quarter earnings, The newspaper said. It added that Altria is likely to spin its 88.6 percent stake in Kraft by giving its shareholders 1.46 billion Kraft shares.

headline.main: Altria Expected to Announce Kraft Spin-Off This Week

abstract: Deutsche Bank  has a problem in equities that is not going away soon enough, says Bloomberg News. While the bank, Germany’s largest, earned more revenue last year trading bonds than any competitor except Goldman Sachs, income from stocks rose at the slowest pace of the 10 biggest securities firms, Bloomberg says, citing company reports and analysts’ estimates. Two years after he started his revamp of the equities division, the managing director, Anshu Jain, is still searching for the winning hand in the United States and a golden touch with hedge funds.

headline.main: Deutsche Bank’s Achilles Heel

abstract: For the first time since the Internet bubble burst at the start of this decade, technology stocks really matter – even to investors who are wary of them. Tech has turned in the worst performance of any group of stocks over the past five years, but investment managers are more bullish on tech than they are on any other segment of the economy, according to a survey by the Russell Investment Group.

abstract: The Mayfield Fund of Menlo Park, Calif., raised a $200 million early-stage venture fund dedicated to investment in China, formalizing a two-year relationship with China’s GSR Ventures to become a general partner in GSR Ventures II. GSR Ventures II will be a Menlo Park- and Beijing-based fund to succeed GSR Ventures I, a $75 million Beijing-based fund in which Mayfield was a limited partner.

abstract: Compared with buttoned-down stock jockeys at Fidelity or T. Rowe Price, hedge fund managers may be the James Bonds of the financial world. They have a reputation for being secretive risk takers who use an array of specialized financial weaponry like derivatives and short-selling. (No license to kill, of course, though their lightly regulated funds do allow managers tremendous, nonlethal latitude.)

abstract: A British buyout shop, the 3i Group, doesn’t seem to be having much luck lately closing deals on its home turf. On Friday 3i walked away from its proposed acquisition of the British real estate concern, Countrywide, after shareholders rejected its 1 billion pound ($1.96 billion) offer, without further raising its 490 pence a share bid. The private equity shop’s offer garnered 57.8 percent of votes at the extraordinary meeting, falling short of the 75 percent needed under British takeover rules. On Jan. 18, a British support services group, Enterprise, also rejected a 528 million pound offer from 3i Group, arguing the proposal undervalued the company.

headline.main: 3i Walks Away from Countrywide After Rebuff

abstract: Greenlight Capital, a hedge fund that has been locked in a dispute with Allied Capital, filed a lawsuit on behalf of the United States alleging that Allied’s Business Loan Express unit submitted fraudulent loan documents to the Small Business Administration. Last week, after a former executive at Business Loan Express was indicted in Michigan, Greenlight called on Allied to replace its management team.

headline.main: Greenlight Files Suit Claiming Loan Fraud

abstract: Sterling Investment Partners has agreed to buy a majority stake in Fairway Markets, one of New York City’s best-known food institutions, in a deal that The Deal.com reports is worth about $150 million. CapitalSource Finance is providing $87 million of debt financing, and Sterling is putting in about $50 million of equity, The Deal said. Fairway’s managers will retain a significant stake. From its roots as a produce market on the city’s Upper West Side, the chain has morphed to become a much larger, specialty food purveyor to the city’s foodies, offering fresh fruits and vegetable and gourmet fare.

headline.main: Sterling Stops By Fairway to Pick Up a Stake

abstract: As buyout firms cast an eye over Gap and the retailer’s interim chief executive, Robert Fisher, passes out memos to improve business, The New York Times looks at at the anachronism that is the Gap: a single chain, selling only its own brand, with one point of view, chasing shoppers from birth to death. Mr. Fisher passed out a memo last week entitled “How we’ll be great again,” according to The New York Post. But retail analysts, it seems, have their own list of how the struggling chain could bring back its cachet. First, they told The Times, the chain could start by shrinking. Next, its should experiment with brands. And finally, they said, Gap could focus on a narrow group of consumers, and tailor clothing to meet their needs.
lead_paragraph: As buyout firms cast an eye over Gap and the retailer’s interim chief executive, Robert Fisher, passes out memos to improve business, The New York Times looks at at the anachronism that is the Gap: a single chain, selling only its own brand, with one point of view, chasing shoppers from birth to death. Mr. Fisher passed out a memo last week entitled “How we’ll be great again,” according to The New York Post. But retail analysts, it seems, have their own list of how the struggling chain could bring back its cachet. First, they told The Times, the chain could start by shrinking. Next, its should experiment with brands. And finally, they said, Gap could focus on a narrow group of consumers, and tailor clothing to meet their needs.

headline.main: Gap Is in Need of a Niche

abstract: As SunPower announced explosive growth in the fourth quarter Thursday, the solar-power company also disclosed that a senior-level employee is under federal scrutiny for actions he took while working for a former employer. Peter Aschenbrenner, currently vice president of marketing, has been accused of playing a role in the bankrupt AstroPower‘s “allegedly improper recognition of revenue,” and regulators accuse him of insider trading, according to SunPower’s amended quarterly filing.

abstract: After five years of job losses, Silicon Valley is hiring again. The turnaround coincides with a huge increase of investment in the emerging category of clean environment technology. In Silicon Valley, investment in clean technology – from alternative energy products, like solar panels and hybrid cars, to the use of nanotechnology to solve environmental problems – went from $34 million in the first quarter of 2006 to $290 million in the third quarter, according to an annual report released Sunday by Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network, a research organization in San Jose, Calif.
lead_paragraph: After five years of job losses, Silicon Valley is hiring again. The turnaround coincides with a huge increase of investment in the emerging category of clean environment technology. In Silicon Valley, investment in clean technology – from alternative energy products, like solar panels and hybrid cars, to the use of nanotechnology to solve environmental problems – went from $34 million in the first quarter of 2006 to $290 million in the third quarter, according to an annual report released Sunday by Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network, a research organization in San Jose, Calif.

headline.main: Silicon Valley Rebounds, Led by Green Technology

abstract: Laureate Education, a for-profit operator of universities, said Sunday it had agreed to be acquired for about $3.1 billion by a group led by its chairman, Douglas L. Becker. The buyout group also included the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the hedge fund SAC Capital.

abstract: Levi Strauss is becoming a leader in a new arena: lawsuits. The company, once the undisputed king of denim and now a case study in missed opportunities, has emerged as the most litigious in the apparel industry when it comes to trademark infringement lawsuits, firing off nearly 100 against its competitors since 2001. That’s far more than General Motors, Walt Disney or Nike, according to an analysis by a research firm, Thomson West.

abstract: President Bush set broad goals last week for the adoption of alternative energy. Hoping to take on the role of filling in the details is an unlikely group: Silicon Valley’s technology investors. These venture capitalists, backers of giants like Google and Genentech, have traditionally been free-market advocates, favoring ideas and innovation over government intervention. Now they are heading to Washington on a crusade to influence energy policy because they have a big stake in the outcome.

abstract: A former executive with Computer Associates who pleaded guilty to securities fraud and who prosecutors said was instrumental in the prosecution of the company’s former chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, was sentenced to seven months in prison and seven months of home detention. According to Thomson Financial, the value of mergers and acquisitions involving Canadian companies soared to $230 billion last year, nearly doubling the action a year earlier. The biggest player: private equity firms.

abstract: Everyone, it seems, is hopping on the buyout bandwagon these days. Even the big public companies once thought untouchable are now wistfully talking about the success of firms like the Blackstone Group, says Andrew Ross Sorkin in his DealBook column. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Blackstone’s Stephen A. Schwarzman — whose firm has now offered $38.3 billion to take Equity Office Properties private — told Mr. Sorkin that the head of a major public company confided that he wished he could go private.

abstract: Merrill Lynch said Monday it would acquire the First Republic Bank, a bank that specializes in serving wealthy individuals, for $1.8 billion in cash and stock. Merrill said its offer for San Francisco-based First Republic represented a price of $55 a share, or 44 percent more than First Republic’s closing stock price on Friday. The deal would be Merrill’s largest acquisition in almost 10 years, Bloomberg News reported.

abstract: Tycoons, politicians and big thinkers climbed into limousines, trains and private planes on Sunday as this year’s World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, came to an end. Among dealmakers and corporate executives there, the push to go private was a major topic of discussion. Strolling out of a session called “Is Bigger Better in Private Equity?” Blackstone Group‘s Stephen Schwarzman told DealBook an anecdote about how the chief executive of an unnamed company worth more than $125 billion recently remarked, “Geez, I wish you could buy us, but we’re too big.” Amid all this talk about going private, John Thain, chief executive of the NYSE Group, predicted that the tide would eventually turn and companies would make their way back to the public markets.
lead_paragraph: Tycoons, politicians and big thinkers climbed into limousines, trains and private planes on Sunday as this year’s World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, came to an end. Among dealmakers and corporate executives there, the push to go private was a major topic of discussion. Strolling out of a session called “Is Bigger Better in Private Equity?” Blackstone Group‘s Stephen Schwarzman told DealBook an anecdote about how the chief executive of an unnamed company worth more than $125 billion recently remarked, “Geez, I wish you could buy us, but we’re too big.” Amid all this talk about going private, John Thain, chief executive of the NYSE Group, predicted that the tide would eventually turn and companies would make their way back to the public markets.

headline.main: Davos 2007 in Review

abstract: Shares of the Cowen Group have risen nearly 30 percent from last year’s initial public offering, but Merrill Lynch analyst Guy Moszkowski is concerned that there may be little upside left. On Monday, Mr. Moszkowski cut his rating on Cowen to “neutral” from “buy,” writing that, at Friday’s close of $20.70, the investment bank’s stock had topped his $18 price target. He also said that Cowen’s merger advisory business looks weak, especially in the fourth quarter of 2006.

abstract: For months, certain outside investors have criticized the New York Times Company over its two-tiered stock structure. abstract: Shares of the drug giant Bristol-Myers Squibb, which has been the subject of takeover speculation for months, soared to near a three-year high Monday after a French financial publication said it might be close to merging with Sanofi-Aventis. The report did not name its sources, and both companies declined to comment. Nevertheless, shares of Bristol-Myers, which sells the blockbuster anticoagulant drug Plavix, were up 4.6 percent to $27.41 in late-afternoon trading, giving it a market capitalization of nearly $54 billion.

abstract: SHOELESS IN RENO? Unisys plans to open its first Registered Traveler program kiosk at the Reno-Tahoe International Airport in mid-February. But it is unlikely that the program will initially offer shoe-scanning technology, said Larry Zmuda, the company’s partner for homeland-security-related business. In an interview, Mr. Zmuda said the major concern for Unisys was ensuring the program’s “predictability” for members, who will undergo a federal background check and pay an annual fee to receive biometrically encoded I.D. cards and access to a special lane for expedited passage through the security checkpoint. Mr. Zmuda cited early snags with shoe-scanning technology being tested in Orlando by Verified Identity Pass, which already operates a Registered Traveler program called Clear at Orlando and four other airports. The Clear shoe-scanning technology, developed by General Electric Security, was intended to detect traces of explosives and suspicious metal, and to allow most travelers to pass through Clear lanes without having to remove their shoes. But the scanner rejected an unexpectedly high number of travelers’ shoes in Orlando, requiring members to remove their shoes just as they would at regular checkpoints. Mr. Zmuda said Unisys, which plans to be operating in 6 to 10 airports within a year, will probably offer only a special lane for the I.D. cards in Reno while the company continues to study options that will provide more benefits. Steven Brill, the founder of Verified Identity, has said that not having to remove shoes is the biggest potential benefit sought by customers. But Mr. Zmuda said that “all of our survey data” show that not having to remove laptops from cases is the biggest benefit sought by potential members.

abstract: Japan’s factory output in December rose more than expected, to a record, fueled by higher overseas demand for automobiles and machinery. Industrial production climbed a seasonally adjusted 0.7 percent, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said in Tokyo. In the labor market, Japan’s seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose to 4.1 in December, slightly more than the 4.0 percent that was expected. In a sign of an improving employment market, the jobs-to-applicant ratio was 1.08 in December, meaning 108 jobs were available per 100 applicants.

abstract: SAC Capital Partners, the giant hedge fund managed by Steven Cohen, grew to prominence by making fast trades for quick profits. In recent years, it has sometimes taken larger positions in companies and held them longer, occasionally even playing the role of activist investor. Now it has teamed up with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, a veteran of the relatively long-term business of private equity investing, as well as a slew of other firms in the $3.1 billion, management-led buyout of Laureate Education, which runs campus-based and online universities.

abstract: A hedge fund that owns 5 percent of Northwest Airlines is calling for the bankrupt carrier to meet with shareholders to develop a reorganization plan that returns their investment. “To start, the company must agree to give its stockholders a voice in the bankruptcy,” said Jeffrey Altman, founder of the hedge fund, Owl Creek Asset Management, in a letter to Northwest dated Jan. 26. Under its reorganization plan, Northwest will cancel existing stock and current shareholders are expected to receive nothing.

abstract: Two former executives of Cendant were spared prison time on Monday for their roles in an accounting scandal that cost the company and its investors more than $3 billion. One of them, Anne Pember, 47, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy in 2000, was sentenced to two years’ probation and 200 hours of community service. The other, Casper Sabatino, 54, a former accountant who admitted wire-fraud charges and cooperated with federal prosecutors, was sentenced to two years’ probation.

abstract: A former Coca-Cola aide said at her federal trial on Monday that, although she routinely took copies of company documents and e-mails home, she did not conspire to steal and sell trade secrets about the beverage company to its chief rival. “No. We never talked about anything like that whatsoever,” Joya Williams said when asked if she planned with two other defendants to steal and sell Coca-Cola documents to PepsiCo.

abstract: Bank of America was fined $3 million by the NASD Monday to settle charges it failed to follow rules designed to stop money laundering in its handling of accounts held by a single family. While the NASD did not identify the family, Reuters said that the accounts are identical to those held by Dallas billionaire Sam Wyly and his brother Charles, as described in an August 2006 report, “Tax Haven Abuses: The Enablers, the Tools and Secrecy,” by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

abstract: Will another billion dollars make the difference between a stand-alone airline and a willing merger partner? That’s what US Airways may find out this week after some behind-the-scenes negotiating with Delta Air Lines creditors. According to press reports, US Air was asked over the weekend by some Delta creditors to again raise its $9.87 billion bid. The pro-merger creditors, which include a group of hedge funds, reportedly suggested that the airline raise its offer by $2 billion. US Air has been frustrated because the official creditors committee in Delta’s bankruptcy, the only party that can force Delta to allow due diligence by US Airways and otherwise get the merger talks started, has been silent.
lead_paragraph: Will another billion dollars make the difference between a stand-alone airline and a willing merger partner? That’s what US Airways may find out this week after some behind-the-scenes negotiating with Delta Air Lines creditors. US Air has been frustrated because the official creditors committee in Delta’s bankruptcy, the only party that can force Delta to allow due diligence by US Airways and otherwise get the merger talks started, has been silent.

headline.main: Behind the Scenes of the Battle for Delta

abstract: Shares of Alitalia, Italy’s largest airline, jumped as much as 4.9 percent as a plan to sell the state’s stake in the unprofitable carrier attracted 11 possible bidders, including the Texas Pacific Group and UniCredit. The stock gained as much as 5.4 cents to 1.15 euros ($1.49) a share and was up 3.4 percent in Milan, valuing Rome-based Alitalia at 1.57 billion euros ($2 billion). Texas Pacific, which is part of a consortium buying Qantas Airways Ltd., Australia’s biggest carrier, said it would invite Italian and foreign investors to join an eventual offer to buy the company.

abstract: BAA, the world’s biggest airport operator, will pledge at least $15.7 billion of assets from Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted to back a sale of bonds in the largest deal of its kind. BAA will sell the securities in March or early April to pay for debt that funded its takeover last year, according to Michael Wilkins, head of infrastructure finance at Standard & Poor’s. Bloomberg News said that BAA’s deal would exceed the record $12 billion of bonds and loans that Japan’s richest man, Masayoshi Son, issued last October to fund the acquisition of the cellphone operator Vodafone K.K. by pledging the company’s assets, income and shares as security.

abstract: Henry Blodget has some harsh words for James Cramer, the popular market pundit who hosts CNBC’s “Mad Money” show. Writing in a column for Slate, Mr. Blodget, the former Internet analyst, calls Mr. Cramer “perhaps the worst thing to happen to the financial security of average Americans since the crumbling of the Social Security system”. And that’s before he really gets going.

abstract: Another analyst is advising caution to shareholders of Clear Channel Communications  as the radio giant continues to seek support for a proposed $18.7 billion buyout. Jonathan Jacoby of Banc of America Securities on Tuesday cut his rating on Clear Channel to “neutral” from “buy,” writing that, even in the most optimistic scenarios, there is little room for the stock to continue rising. The downgrade comes amid reports that some major Clear Channel shareholders, including mutual-fund giant Fidelity, will vote against the $37.60-per-share offer to take it private.

abstract: The long-awaited listing of shares in Time Warner Cable — the United States’ No. 2 cable provider after Comcast — could be delayed until March because of the legal wrangling in Adelphia Communications‘ bankruptcy case. That is one of the possibilities considered by Bear Stearns analyst Spencer Wang, who wrote in a research note Tuesday that, if the internecine battles among Adelphia’s creditors continue, Time Warner could decide to try a traditional initial public offering as opposed to floating the stock through a court-approved reorganization plan.
lead_paragraph: The long-awaited listing of shares in Time Warner Cable — the United States’ No. 2 cable provider after Comcast — could be delayed until March because of the legal wrangling in Adelphia Communications‘ bankruptcy case. abstract: Private investments in public equities, known as PIPEs, can be a valid source of financing for publicly traded companies. But they also have a controversial reputation, in part because of their susceptibility to stock manipulation. Forbes’ Nathan Vardi — in an article colorfully headlined “Sewer Pipes” — describes some particularly troubling examples. This week’s magazine offers a litany of cases of hedge-fund managers involved in PIPEs who allegedly duped investors, ran afoul of regulations and were convicted of fraud. “When it comes to dicey partners, though, few are as accomplished as the Grins,” Mr. Vardi writes.

abstract: In these are dire times for Detroit’s automakers, and even bleaker ones for thousands of auto-parts suppliers, why are big name investors like Carl C. Icahn, Wilbur L. Ross and Cerberus Capital pouring their cash into what seems like a losing proposition? The answer, suggests The New York Times, is that, while business for auto suppliers has evaporated in Detroit, it is expanding in the rest of the world as vehicle sales increase globally. Of course, the cheap price tags and low interest rates are not hurting either.

abstract: In what at first glance may seem counterintuitive, Wall Street’s enthusiasm for Altria‘s plans to spin off its Kraft Foods unit is not because Kraft, the world’s second-largest food company, will finally shed the taint of tobacco, but rather that the tobacco giant will finally be rid of Kraft. Altria is expected to announce a timetable for the spinoff on Wednesday. After cutting Kraft loose, Altria may step up the pace of its tobacco-related takeovers, analysts told Bloomberg News.

abstract: Michael J. Kopper, a former finance executive at Enron who ran illicit partnerships allowing the company to conceal debt, started serving a three-year prison sentence Tuesday in Big Spring, Tex. Mr. Kopper, 42, entered the prison about 11 a.m. yesterday, a United States Bureau of Prisons official said. The former executive, a top lieutenant of Enron’s chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, managed daily operations for Fastow-controlled partnerships in the fraud that ultimately destroyed the company.

abstract: ElkCorp, a maker of roofing and building products, said Tuesday that it planned to accept a bid for the company from the Building Materials Corporation of America and terminate a planned sale to the private equity firm Carlyle Group. The move gives the buyout firm five days to raise its latest bid.

abstract: Admitting for the first time that former officials intentionally priced stock options retroactively and falsified documents, KLA-Tencor restated its past results on Monday to include $370 million in charges related to those backdated options. Scott Sacane, who owned and controlled Durus, waived indictment in December 2005 and pleaded guilty to one count of violating the Investment Advisers Act of 1940.

abstract: MySQL, one of the leading open source database vendors, is preparing itself for an initial public offering and could be ready to go public before the end of the year, the Swedish company’s chief executive, Marten Mickos, told Computer Business Review. “We are planning to go public,” Mr. Mickos told the publication. However, he added that the company was in no hurry to go public after raising $18.5 million in venture capital at the beginning of last year.

headline.main: MySQL Mulls I.P.O.

abstract: Perhaps emboldened by the emergence of climate change as one of the top issues at this year’s World Economic Forum, global-warming activists stepped up their fight against Merrill Lynch for its role in financing TXU‘s $10 billion plan to build 11 coal-fueled power plants in Texas. TXU’s plans for the plants, which would emit about 78 million tons of carbon dioxide into the air, and Merrill’s involvement have already drawn sharp criticism from environmentalists, as well as a coalition of institutional investors and politicians.

headline.main: Power Plant Protesters Descend on Merrill Headquarters

abstract: Shares of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange fell after the company said fourth-quarter profit was below some analysts’ estimates because of higher-than-anticipated costs. Net income rose 35 percent to $102.6 million, or $2.91 a share, from $76.3 million, or $2.18 a share a year earlier. Higher operating expenses and equity losses in unconsolidated subsidiaries cut 11 cents a share from earnings, the exchange said.

headline.main: Chicago Merc’s Profit Falls Short of Expectations

abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug maker, is beefing up its banking team ahead of possible takeover approaches from rivals, notably Sanofi-Aventis, by retaining the services of three Wall Street banks, The Financial Times reported. Bristol-Myers in the past week appointed Lehman Brothers to work alongside Citigroup and Morgan Stanley to examine its options ahead of an expected takeover approach from Sanofi, the paper said.

headline.main: Bristol-Myers Hires Bankers for Bidding War, Report Says

abstract: The New York Stock Exchange and the Tokyo Stock Exchange have sealed a pact that could point the world’s two largest financial markets toward an eventual combination. The broad agreement will allow both sides to cooperate on joint developments, such as financial products, mutual listings and technology, according to The Associated Press. Further, it sets into motion the possibility of a true combination once Japan’s biggest stock exchange becomes a public company in 2009.
lead_paragraph: The New York Stock Exchange and the Tokyo Stock Exchange have sealed a pact that could point the world’s two largest financial markets toward an eventual combination. Further, it sets into motion the possibility of a true combination once Japan’s biggest stock exchange becomes a public company in 2009.

headline.main: NYSE in a Deal With Tokyo Exchange

abstract: Ford Motor is expected to receive revised offers on Wednesday for its Aston Martin brand, which it hopes to sell for more than 450 million pounds ($879 million), according to The Financial Times. Bidders left in the auction include Simon Halabi, the Syrian-born property tycoon; a British private equity firm, Doughty Hanson; Magna, the Canadian car parts group; and a consortium including James Packer, the Australian media billionaire, the report said. The paper said that there may be a third round of bidding if several of the offers come in at the same level.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor is expected to receive revised offers on Wednesday for its Aston Martin brand, which it hopes to sell for more than 450 million pounds ($879 million), according to The Financial Times. The paper said that there may be a third round of bidding if several of the offers come in at the same level.

headline.main: Ford Expects Aston Martin Bids Today, Report Says

abstract: Relativity Media, the privately held firm that helped finance “Smokin’ Aces” and “Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby,” has joined with Citigroup in a deal to fund at least 45 studio films in the next five years, and possibly as many as 100, according to reports. Variety said the overall investment could reach $1.1 billion, and The New York Post said the co-financing agreement could be one of the largest pools of outsider money to make its way to Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Relativity Media, the privately held firm that helped finance “Smokin’ Aces” and “Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby,” has joined with Citigroup in a deal to fund at least 45 studio films in the next five years, and possibly as many as 100, according to reports. headline.main: Private Firm Joins Citi in Big Hollywood Bet

abstract: As Tribune reviews bids for its assets, management at one of its crown jewels, The Los Angeles Times, is trying to keep its employees from running for the door. The announcement that Dean Baquet, the editor of The Los Angeles Times who was fired in November for refusing to cut jobs from his newsroom, is returning to The New York Times as chief of its Washington bureau and an assistant managing editor, has the L.A. newspaper worried that the move will spark a mass exodus from its newsroom.

headline.main: As Tribune Considers Offers, a Former Editor Moves On

abstract: As the clock ran down on US Airways‘ $10 billion bid for bankrupt Delta Air Lines, US Airways’ chief executive, W. Douglas Parker, said in a conference call Tuesday that the offer, a mix of cash and stock, was firm, and that he had no intention of extending the Thursday deadline for the the official committee of Delta’s creditors to respond. Also on Tuesday, US Airways reported a $12 million profit for the fourth quarter of 2006, and Delta said it had secured $2.5 billion in financing to fund its emergence as a standalone airline.
lead_paragraph: As the clock ran down on US Airways‘ $10 billion bid for bankrupt Delta Air Lines, US Airways’ chief executive, W. Douglas Parker, said in a conference call Tuesday that the offer, a mix of cash and stock, was firm, and that he had no intention of extending the Thursday deadline for the the official committee of Delta’s creditors to respond. Also on Tuesday, US Airways reported a $12 million profit for the fourth quarter of 2006, and Delta said it had secured $2.5 billion in financing to fund its emergence as a standalone airline.

headline.main: US Airways Stands Firm As Deadline Looms for Delta Bid

abstract: In introducing its long article about Global Alpha, Goldman Sachs‘ highly secretive flagship hedge fund, Bloomberg News writer Richard Teitelbaum recounts how one of the fund’s managers, Mark Carhart, recently made fun of Warren Buffett for insisting on investing on solid companies with good management and well-known brands. During an investor conference, Mr. Carhart cited several studies showing that big companies with high price-earning ratios make for “poor bets,” as Mr. Teitelbaum put it.

abstract: Asked about recent reports that Bank of America was in talks that might lead to an acquisition of Countrywide, Bank of America Chief Executive Kenneth Lewis said Wednesday his company would follow a mortgage strategy of “organic growth.” Speaking at a financial-services conference, he also said the odds were “pretty low” that his company would buy a large United States bank this year, Reuters reported.
